Ord. No. 723, § 1, 6-10-2013; Ord. No. 723-B, 8-13-2018)
Sec. 26-98. Supplemental effect.
The provisions of this article are supplemental and shall be cumulative with
all other laws and ordinances applicable in any manner to juveniles
(Code 2014, § 26-102; Ord. No. 532, § 6, 6-10-2003; Ord. No. 656, § 6, 9-8-
2008; Ord. No. 723, § 6, 6-10-2013; Ord. No. 723-B, § 6, 8-13-2018)
Secs. 26-99—26-114. Reserved.
DIVISION 2. CURFEW
Editor's note(s)—The provisions of this division are effective as of September
1, 2023.
Sec. 26-115. Established; penalty.
   (a)   It shall be unlawful for any minor, under the age of 18 years, to
remain, walk, run, stand, drive or ride about, in or upon any public place in
the city during the hours as follows:
      (1)   11:00 p.m. Sunday and 6:00 a.m. Monday.
      (2)   11:00 p.m. Monday and 6:00 a.m. Tuesday.
      (3)   11:00 p.m. Tuesday and 6:00 a.m. Wednesday.
      (4)   11:00 p.m. Wednesday and 6:00 a.m. Thursday.
      (5)   11:00 p.m. Thursday and 6:00 a.m. Friday.
      (6)   12:00 midnight Friday and 6:00 a.m. Saturday.
      (7)   12:00 midnight Saturday and 6:00 a.m. Sunday.
   (b)   It shall be unlawful for any minor, under the age of 18 years, to
remain, walk, run, stand, drive or ride about, in or upon any public place in
the city, on school days, between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 2:00 p.m. on
Monday through Friday, inclusive.
   (c)   It shall be unlawful for the parent or guardian having legal custody
of a minor, or a responsible adult selected by the parent or legal guardian to
supervise the minor, to allow or permit the minor to be in violation of the
curfew imposed in subsection (a) of this section.
   (d)   It shall be unlawful to intentionally, knowingly, recklessly, or with
criminal negligence violate this section. Such violation shall be a Class C
misdemeanor and, upon conviction, punishable by a fine consistent with state
statutes.
(Code 2014, § 26-98; Ord. No. 532, § 2, 6-10-2003; Ord. No. 656, § 2, 9-8-2008;
Ord. No. 723, § 2, 6-10-2013; Ord. No. 723-B, § 2, 8-13-2018)
Sec. 26-116. Defenses.
   (a)   It is a defense to prosecution under section
26-115 that:
      (1)   The minor was accompanied by the minor's parent or legal guardian;
      (2)   The minor was accompanied by a responsible adult (at least 21 years
of age) authorized by the parent or legal guardian to supervise the minor;
      (3)   The minor was on an errand made necessary by a medical emergency;
      (4)   The minor was attending a school, religious, or government-
sponsored activity;
      (5)   The minor was engaged in a lawful employment activity or was going
directly to or coming directly from lawful employment;
      (6)   The minor was on the sidewalk, yard, or curtilage of the place
where the minor permanently resides;
      (7)   The minor was engaged in, participating in, or traveling to or from
any event, function or activity for which the application of section
26-115 would contravene the minor's rights protected by the state or United
States Constitution;
      (8)   The minor is married or had been married or had disabilities of
minority removed in accordance with V.T.C.A., Family Code ch. 31.
   (b)   It is a defense to prosecution under this section that the minor has
been directed by his parent or legal guardian, or a responsible adult selected
by the parent or legal guardian to supervise the minor, to engage in a specific
activity or to carry out express instructions, during the time that the minor
is actually engaged in fulfilling those directions or responsibilities.
(Code 2014, § 26-101; Ord. No. 532, § 5, 6-10-2003; Ord. No. 656, § 5, 9-8-
2008; Ord. No. 723, § 5, 6-10-2013; Ord. No. 723-B, § 5(A),(C), 8-13-2018)
Secs. 26-117—26-129. Reserved.
DIVISION 3. SCHOOL ATTENDANCE
State law reference(s)—Compulsory school attendance, V.T.C.A., Education Code §
25.085.
Sec. 26-130. Parental duties; defense; penalty.
Compulsory school age to be in attendance at school, parental duties imposed.
      (1)   No minor under the age of 18 years, other than a minor that has
been suspended or expelled from school, shall be at any place within the city
except in attendance at school between the hours 9:00 a.m. and 2:00 p.m. during
any school day, unless the minor has written proof from school authorities
excusing him from attending school at that particular time, or unless the minor
is accompanied by a parent or legal guardian, or a responsible adult selected
by the parent or legal guardian to supervise the minor.
      (2)   Each parent or legal guardian of a minor under the age of 18 years
shall have a duty to prohibit the minor from behaving contrary to subsection
(1) of this section. No person shall fail to fulfill the duty imposed by this
section.
      (3)   Any person who violates subsection (2) of this section shall be
subject to prosecution for failing to supervise a minor of compulsory school
age.
      (4)   It shall be unlawful to intentionally, knowingly, recklessly, or
with criminal negligence violate this section. Such violation shall be a Class
C misdemeanor, and upon conviction, punishable by a fine consistent with state
statutes.
      (5)   It is defense to prosecution under this section that the minor, at
the time he was found at a place other than in school, was not required by law
to be in attendance at school.
      (6)   It is a defense to prosecution under this section that the minor
has been directed by his parent or legal guardian, or a responsible adult
selected by the parent or legal guardian to supervise the minor, to engage in a
specific activity or to carry out express instructions, during the time that
the minor is actually engaged in fulfilling those directions or
responsibilities.
(Code 2014, § 26-99; Ord. No. 532, § 3, 6-10-2003; Ord. No. 656, § 3, 9-8-2008;
Ord. No. 723, § 3, 6-10-2013; Ord. No. 723-B, §§ 3, 5(B), (C), 8-13-2018)
State law reference(s)—Compulsory school attendance, V.T.C.A., Education Code §
25.085.
Sec. 26-131. Children suspended or expelled from school to remain under
supervision; parental duties imposed.
   (a)   If a minor under the age of 18 years is suspended or expelled from
school, then each parent or legal guardian of the minor shall have the
following duties for the duration of the suspension or expulsion:
      (1)   The duty to personally supervise the minor, or to arrange for a
responsible adult to supervise the minor, at the times that the minor would
have been required to be in attendance at school had he not been suspended or
expelled; and
      (2)   The duty to prohibit the minor from being at any public place at
the times that: the minor would have been required to be in attendance at
school had he not been suspended or expelled, except in the following
circumstances:
         a.   When the minor is accompanied by the parent or legal guardian to
supervise the minor; or
         b.   When the minor is on an emergency errand; or
         c.   The minor is married or had been married or had disabilities of
minority removed in accordance with chapter 31 of the Texas Family Code; or
         d.   When the minor is employed pursuant to approval of school
authorities, during the times that the minor is actually on the job or
traveling directly from the job site
No person shall negligently fail to fulfill the duties imposed by this section.
   (b)   No minor under the age of 18 years that has been suspended or expelled
from school shall fail to comply with supervision provided or arranged by a
parent or legal guardian pursuant to subsection (a)(1) of this section.
   (c)   No minor under the age of 18 years that has been suspended or expelled
from school shall be in any public place at the times that he would have been
required to be in attendance at school had he not been suspended or expelled,
except in the circumstances described in subsection (a)(2)a, (a)(2)b, (a)(2)c,
or (a)(2)d of this section.
   (d)   It shall be unlawful to intentionally, knowingly, recklessly, or with
criminal negligence violate this section. Such violation shall be a Class C
misdemeanor and upon conviction punishable by a fine consistent with state
statutes.
   (e)   It is a defense to prosecution under this section that the minor has
been directed by his parent or legal guardian, or a responsible adult selected
by the parent or legal guardian to supervise the minor, to engage in a specific
activity or to carry out express instructions, during the time that the minor
is actually engaged in fulfilling those directions or responsibilities.
(Code 2014, § 26-100; Ord. No. 532, § 4, 6-10-2003; Ord. No. 630, 10-10-2006;
Ord. No. 656, § 4, 9-8-2008; Ord. No. 723, § 4, 6-10-2013; Ord. No. 723-B, §§
4, 5(C), 8-13-2018)
Secs. 26-132—26-149. Reserved.
ARTICLE VI. WEAPONS
Sec. 26-150. Possession.
All persons, including employees of the city are prohibited from possessing a
weapon, as hereafter defined in section
26-151, while on any premises, building or facility, including parks, owned,
leased, or otherwise controlled by the city. The term "premises" includes
parking areas, sidewalks and walkways that adjoin buildings and facilities
owned, leased, or controlled by the city.
(Code 2014, § 26-126; Ord. No. 533, § I, 5-14-2001)
Sec. 26-151. Definition; concealed weapon.
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have
the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly
indicates a different meaning:
   Person means and includes any person who has a license to carry a concealed
weapon issued by the state.
   Weapon means a club, explosive weapon, firearm, handgun, illegal knife,
knuckles, machine gun, short-barrel firearm, hoax bomb, chemical dispensing
devise, and zip gun as defined and set out in V.T.C.A., Penal Code ch. 46.
(Code 2014, § 26-127; Ord. No. 533, § II, 5-14-2001)
Sec. 26-152. Exceptions.
There is excepted from the prohibition contained herein the following:
      (1)   A peace officer as defined by state law;
      (2)   A reserved law enforcement officer as defined by state law while
such officer is on duty; and
      (3)   A commissioned security officer in uniform who is authorized to
carry a firearm and who is then on duty with his employer and who is then
acting within the scope and course of his employment.
(Code 2014, § 26-128; Ord. No. 533, § III, 5-14-2001)
Sec. 26-153. Signage.
There shall be placed at each public entrance to a building or facility and at
entry ways into premises owned, leased, or controlled by the city a sign that:
      (1)   States in English and Spanish, "No weapon of any kind shall be
permitted on these premises or in this building. Pursuant to V.T.C.A., Penal
Code § 30.06 (Trespass by holder of license to carry a concealed handgun), a
person licensed under V.T.C.A., Government Code ch. 411, subch. H (V.T.C.A.,
Government Code § 411.171 et seq.) (concealed handgun law) may not enter this
property with a concealed handgun;"
      (2)   Appears in contrasting colors with block letters at least one inch
in height; and
      (3)   Is displayed in a conspicuous manner clearly visible to the public.
(Code 2014, § 26-129; Ord. No. 533, § IV, 5-14-2001)
Sec. 26-154. Violation.
It shall be unlawful and an offense for any person to violate or fail to comply
with any provisions hereof, regardless of whether or not the verbiage of each
section hereof contains the specific language that such violation or failure to
comply is unlawful and is an offense. Any person who shall violate any of the
provisions of this article or any of the provisions of a license issued
pursuant hereto, or who shall fail to comply with the terms hereof, shall be
guilty of a Class A misdemeanor and shall, on conviction thereof, be punished
with and by the penalties provided by state law for such classification of
offense.
(Code 2014, § 26-129; Ord. No. 533, § V, 5-14-2001)
Secs. 26-155—26-164. Reserved.
ARTICLE VII. SMOKING MATERIALS AND PARAPHERNALIA
State law reference(s)—Sale of tobacco products to minors, V.T.C.A., Health and
Safety Code § 161.082; possession, etc. of tobacco products by minors,
V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 161.252; smoking prohibited, V.T.C.A., Penal
Code § 48.01.
Sec. 26-165. Findings.
The recitals in the whereas clauses in the ordinance from which this article
was derived are hereby found to be true and correct and are incorporated hereby
adopted by the city council and made a part hereof for all purposes, as
findings of fact. The city council hereby further finds and determines that the
rules, regulations, terms, conditions, provisions and requirements of this
article are reasonable and necessary to protect the public health, safety and
quality of life.
(Code 2014, § 26-165; Ord. No. 683, § 1, 11-8-2010)
Sec. 26-166. Purpose.
The purpose of this article is to prohibit the sale, delivery, or gift of
restricted smoking materials as defined herein to any individual within the
city limits of the city and to prohibit the possession of restricted smoking
materials by any individual with the city limits of the city. Any form of
delivery to include a simple gift constitutes a violation of this article.
(Code 2014, § 26-166; Ord. No. 683, § 2, 11-8-2010)
Sec. 26-167. Definitions.
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have
the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly
indicates a different meaning:
   Possession means actual care, custody, control, or management, as the terms
"actual care," "custody," control" or "management" are interpreted by state
courts in construing the definition of "possession" as set forth in V.T.C.A.,
Health and Safety Code ch. 481, as amended from time to time.
   Restricted smoking material means any substance, however marketed, which can
reasonably be converted for smoking purposes whether it is presented as
incense, tobacco, herbs, spices or any blend thereof if it includes any of the
following chemicals or a comparable chemical:
      (1)   Salvia divinorum or salvinorin A; all parts of the plant presently
classified botanically as salvia divinorum, whether growing or not, the seeds
thereof, any extract from any part of such plant, and every compound,
manufacture, salts, derivative, mixture or preparation of such plant, its seeds
or extracts;
      (2)   2-{'{'}(1R, 3S)-3-hydroxycyclohexyl{'}'}-d-(2-methyloctan-2-
yl)phenol (also known as CP47, 497) and homologues;
      (3)   (6aS,10aS)-9-(hydroxymethyl)-6, 6-dimethyl-3-(2-methylocatan-2-yl)-
6a, 7, 10, 10a-tetrahydrobenzol{'{'}c{'}'}chromen-1-ol) (also known as HU-211
or Dexanabinol);
      (4)   1-pentyl-3-(1-naphthoyl)indole (also known as JWH-018);
      (5)   1-butyl-3-(1-naphthoyl)indole (also known as JWH-073);
      (6)   1-pentyl-3-(4-methoxynaphthoy)indole (also known as JWH-081); or
      (7)   Products containing some of the above substances are currently
being marketed under the following commercial names: "K-2," "K-2 Summit," "K-
2 Sex," "Genie," "Dascents," "Zohai," "Sage," "Spice," "KO Knock-Out 2," "Spice
Gold," "Spice Diamond," "Yucatan Fire," "Solar Flare," "Pep Spice," "Fire n'
Ice," and "Salvia Divinorum."
It is anticipated that new products will be marketed under different names but
will be subject to this definition if they contain any of the chemical
components set forth above.
   Restricted smoking material paraphernalia means any equipment, product,
material, or utensil that is used or intended for use in packaging, storing,
containing, or concealing restricted smoking material or ingesting, inhaling,
consuming, or otherwise introducing into the human body restricted smoking
material, and may include, but is not limited to:
      (1)   A metal, wooden, acrylic, glass, stone, plastic, or ceramic pipe
with or without a screen, permanent screen, hashish head, or punctured metal
bowl;
      (2)   A water pipe;
      (3)   A carburetion tube or device;
      (4)   A smoking or carburetion mask;
      (5)   A chamber pipe;
      (6)   A carburetor pipe;
      (7)   An electric pipe;
      (8)   An air-driven pipe;
      (9)   A chillum;
      (10)   A bong; or
      (11)   An ice pipe or chiller.
(Code 2014, § 26-167; Ord. No. 683, § 3, 11-8-2010)
State law reference(s)—Definitions, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code § 481.002.
Sec. 26-168. Sale, delivery, offer, or gift.
It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, offer to sell, deliver to or to
give any restricted smoking material to anyone within the corporate city
limits.
(Code 2014, § 26-168; Ord. No. 683, § 4, 11-8-2010)
Sec. 26-169. Use or possession of restricted smoking material.
It shall be unlawful for any person to have in his possession or to use
restricted smoking materials within the corporate limits of the city.
(Code 2014, § 26-169; Ord. No. 683, § 5, 11-8-2010)
Sec. 26-170. Use or possession of restricted smoking material paraphernalia.
It shall be unlawful for any person to use or to possess with the intent to use
restricted smoking material paraphernalia to package, store, contain, or
conceal restricted smoking material or to ingest, inhale, consume or otherwise
introduce restricted smoking material into the human body. If an individual is
found using or in possession of restricted smoking material paraphernalia, it
will be a violation of this article if appropriate testing is done on the
paraphernalia and traces of restricted smoking material are present on the
device.
(Code 2014, § 26-170; Ord. No. 683, § 6, 11-8-2010)
Sec. 26-171. Location of sale of restricted smoking material and restricted
smoking material paraphernalia.
   (a)   It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, offer to sell, deliver or
give restricted smoking material or restricted smoking paraphernalia to any
person within 1,000 feet of the following:
      (1)   A church.
      (2)   A public or private elementary or secondary school.
      (3)   A licensed day care center.
      (4)   A public park, recreation center or water park.
      (5)   A public library.
   (b)   For purposes of this section, measurement shall be made in a straight
line, without regard to intervening structures or objects, from the nearest
portion of the building or structure used for purpose of selling, offering to
sell, or delivering the restricted smoking material or restricted smoking
material paraphernalia to the nearest property line of the premises of the
church, public or private elementary or secondary school, licensed day care
center, public library, public park, recreation center or water park.
(Code 2014, § 26-171; Ord. No. 683, § 7, 11-8-2010)
Sec. 26-172. Defenses to prosecution.
   (a)   It shall be a defense to prosecution for a violation of this section
if the use of the restricted smoking material is at the direction or under a
prescription issued by a licensed physician or dentist authorized to prescribe
controlled substances within the state.
   (b)   It shall be a defense to prosecution under the terms of this section
if an individual charged with a violation can provide proper and complete
historic documentation that the use of such materials is a portion of a
religious undertaking or activity of a religious denomination in which they
have long-standing historic membership supported by documentation from clergy
or spiritual leader recognized by the state.
(Code 2014, § 26-172; Ord. No. 683, § 8, 11-8-2010)
Sec. 26-173. Exception.
A person does not violate section
26-168,
26-169 and
26-170 if the person possesses or delivers such smoking material or restricted
smoking paraphernalia if it is to be used to introduce tetrahydrocannabinols or
their derivatives into the human body, for use in compliance with a federally
approved therapeutic research program.
State law reference(s)—Similar provisions, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety Code §
481.111(c).
Sec. 26-174. Conflicting ordinances.
That all ordinances of the city in conflict with the provisions of this article
are, and the same are hereby, amended to the extent of any conflict with this
article and all other ordinances of the city not in conflict with the provision
of the ordinance shall remain in full force and effect.
(Code 2014, § 26-173; Ord. No. 683, § 9, 11-8-2010)
Sec. 26-175. Penalty.
Any person violating any of the provisions of this article or this Code, as
amended hereby, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction in
the municipal court of the city, shall be punished be a fine not less than
$200.00 and not to exceed the sum of $2,000.00 for each offense, and each and
every day any such violation shall continue shall be deemed to constitute a
separate offense.
(Code 2014, § 26-175; Ord. No. 683, § 11, 11-8-2010)
Secs. 26-176—26-203. Reserved.
ARTICLE VIII. TRESPASSING
State law reference(s)—Authority to prevent and punish trespassing, V.T.C.A.,
Local Government Code § 217.003.
Sec. 26-204. Prohibited without consent.
It shall be unlawful for any person to go upon the premises of another person
without the consent of the occupant or the person in charge of such premises
and break, cut, pull or take from the premises or trample upon the flowers,
shrubbery, grass, or garden vegetables, growing on such premises.
(Code 2014, § 26-204; Ord. No. 146, § I, 8-17-1965)
Sec. 26-205. Peddlers; salespersons; solicitors.
It shall be unlawful for any peddler, salesperson, solicitor, or any other
person who goes upon the premises of another person to remain on such premises
after he has been requested by the owner or his agent or representative or by
any person in charge of such premises, to leave the premises.
(Code 2014, § 26-205; Ord. No. 146, § II, 8-17-1965)
Sec. 26-206. Trespass after warning.
It shall be unlawful for any person to go upon the premises of another person
without the consent of the occupant and after such person has been forbidden or
warned by the occupant or person in charge of such premises not to go upon said
premises; provided, the provisions of this section shall not apply to
licensees, tenants in common of such premises, landlords, meter readers, police
officers, firefighter and other persons who go upon such premises in pursuit of
lawful business, or who go on such premises in discharge of their duties.
(Code 2014, § 26-206; Ord. No. 146, § III, 8-17-1965)
State law reference(s)—Criminal trespass, V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 30.05.
Sec. 26-207. Minors.
It shall be unlawful for any parent or guardian of any minor child to knowingly
permit such child to go upon the premises of another person after such parent
or guardian has been requested by the person in charge of such premises not to
permit such child to go thereon.
(Code 2014, § 26-207; Ord. No. 146, § IV, 8-17-1965)
Sec. 26-208. Looking into private residence.
It shall be unlawful for any person to intentionally enter upon the private
residence of any person and peep or look through the doors, windows or other
openings in such residence for the purpose of spying into such residence for
the a lewd or unlawful purpose.
(Code 2014, § 26-208; Ord. No. 146, § V, 8-17-1965)
State law reference(s)—Similar provisions, V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 42.01(a)(11)
(A).

indicates a different meaning:
   Traffic control device or signal means and includes stop signs, yield signs,
one-way signs, speed limit signs, traffic lights, blinking lights, school zone

(Code 2014, § 28-40; Ord. No. 223, § 1, 8-25-1980)
Sec. 28-41. Disregard for traffic signal or traffic control device.
In any prosecution for any violation of an operation of a motor vehicle in
disregard for a traffic signal indication or a traffic control device, it shall
not be necessary for the state to prove the installation or authority therefor,
of any traffic control device or signal.

Sec. 28-42. Defense.

shall have the right to prove the sign, signal or device was not so installed
or authorized as a defense.
(Code 2014, § 28-42; Ord. No. 223, § 3, 8-25-1980)

ARTICLE VI. ABANDONED/JUNKED MOTOR VEHICLES
State law reference(s)—Abandoned vehicles, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code §
683.001 et seq.; junked vehicles, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 683.071 et
seq.
DIVISION 1. GENERALLY
Secs. 28-346—28-363. Reserved.
DIVISION 2. ABANDONED VEHICLES
State law reference(s)—Abandoned vehicles, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code §
683.001 et seq.
Sec. 28-364. Adoption of Texas Abandoned Motor Vehicle Act.
   (a)   All provisions of the Texas Abandoned Motor Vehicle Act, V.T.C.A.,
Transportation Code § 683.001 et seq., are hereby expressly incorporated into
this division and adopted.
   (b)   All references to the Texas Abandoned Motor Vehicle Act shall mean
V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 683.001 et seq., and any amendments thereto.
(Code 2014, § 28-364; Ord. No. 347, § A(1), 9-9-1996; Amd. of 4-10-2007, § A
(1))
Secs. 28-365—28-386. Reserved.
DIVISION 3. JUNKED VEHICLES
State law reference(s)—Junked vehicles, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 683.071
et seq.
Sec. 28-387. Definition and applicability.
   (a)   The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division,
shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the
context clearly indicates a different meaning:
   Junked vehicle means a vehicle that is:
      (1)   Self-propelled; and
      (2)   Wrecked, dismantled or partially dismantled, or discarded; or
      (3)   Inoperable and has remained inoperable for more than:
         a.   72 consecutive hours, if the vehicle is on public property; or
         b.   30 consecutive days, if the vehicle is on private property.
The term "junked vehicle" includes a motor vehicle, aircraft, or watercraft.
   (b)   This division applies only to:
      (1)   A motor vehicle that does not have lawfully attached to it an
unexpired license plate or does not display a license plate
      (2)   An aircraft that does not have lawfully printed on the aircraft an
unexpired federal aircraft identification number registered under FAA aircraft
registration regulations in 14 CFR 47; or
      (3)   A watercraft that:
         a.   Does not have lawfully on board an unexpired certificate of
number; and
         b.   Is not a watercraft described by V.T.C.A., Parks and Wildlife
Code § 31.055.
(Code 2014, § 28-387; Ord. No. 347, § A(2), 9-9-1996; Amd. of 4-10-2007, § A
(2))
State law reference(s)—Similar provision, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code §
683.071.
Sec. 28-388. Declaration of nuisance.
   (a)   A junked vehicle, including a part of a junked vehicle that is visible
at any time of the year from a public place or public right-of-way:
      (1)   Is detrimental to the safety and welfare of the public;
      (2)   Tends to reduce the value of private property;
      (3)   Invites vandalism;
      (4)   Creates a fire hazard;
      (5)   Is an attractive nuisance creating a hazard to the health and
safety of minors;
      (6)   Produces urban blight adverse to the maintenance and continuing
development of municipalities; and
      (7)   Is a public nuisance.
   (b)   The presence of any junked motor vehicle, or parts thereof, on any
public property or private lot, tract or parcel of land, or portion thereof;
occupied or unoccupied, improved or unimproved, within the city, shall be
deemed a public nuisance regardless of whether such nuisance was by wrecking,
dismantling, partially dismantling or discarding any motor vehicle on the real
property of such person or of another or whether such person shall suffer,
permit or allow any junked or abandoned motor vehicle to be parked, left or
maintained on such person's own real property, or that of another.
   (c)   This section shall not apply with regard to:
      (1)   Any junked motor vehicle, or part thereof which is parked or stored
within an enclosed building in a lawful manner where it is not visible from the
street or any other public or private property;
      (2)   Any junked motor vehicle, or part thereof: stored or parked in a
lawful manner on private property in connection with the business of a licensed
vehicle dealer or a junkyard;
      (3)   Any junked motor vehicle, or part thereof, parked in an appropriate
storage place or depository maintained at a location officially designated and
in a manner approved by the city.
(Code 2014, § 28-388; Ord. No. 347, § A(3), 9-9-1996; Amd. of 4-10-2007, § A
(3))
State law reference(s)—Junked vehicle determined a nuisance, V.T.C.A.,
Transportation Code § 683.072.
Sec. 28-389. Order to remove.
If the information is available at the location of the nuisance, a resolution
or order requiring removal of the nuisance must include:
      (1)   For a motor vehicle, the vehicle's:
         a.   Description;
         b.   Vehicle identification number; and
         c.   License plate number;
      (2)   For an aircraft, the aircraft's:
         a.   Description; and
         b.   Federal aircraft identification number as described by FAA
aircraft registration regulations in 14 CFR 47; and
      (3)   For a watercraft, the watercraft's:
         a.   Description; and
         b.   Identification number as set forth in the watercraft's
certificate of number.
(Code 2014, § 28-389)
State law reference(s)—Similar provision, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code §
683.076(d).
Sec. 28-390. Order to owner or occupant to abate nuisance; performance by city;
appeal; on occupied premises.
   (a)   Whenever any such public nuisance exists on-premises within the city
in violation of section
28-388, the city, through any official or officer, or a duly authorized agent,
shall order the owner of the premises, if in possession thereof; or the
occupant of the premises whereon such a public nuisance exists, to abate or
remove same. Such order shall:
      (1)   Be in writing.
      (2)   Specify the public nuisance and its location.
      (3)   Specify the corrective measures required.
      (4)   Provide the compliance within ten days after the date on which the
notice was personally delivered or mailed.
   (b)   Such order shall be in the form of a notice as provided in section
28-389 served upon the owner or occupant of the premises whereupon such public
nuisance exists by personal service or by certified or registered mail with a
five-day return receipt requested. If the notice is returned undelivered by the
United States post office, official action to abate such nuisance shall be
continued to a date not less than ten days from the return of such notice.
   (c)   If the owner or occupant of the premises fails or refuses to comply
with the order and has not requested a hearing as provided in section
28-392 within the ten-day period after notice thereof, as provided herein the
city shall take possession of such junked motor vehicle and remove it from the
premises.
   (d)   If the owner or occupant of such premises so desires, such owner or
occupant may, within such ten-day period after service of notice to abate the
nuisance, request the clerk of the municipal court of the city, either in
person or in writing, and without the requirement of bond, that a date and a
time be set when such person may appear before the judge of the municipal court
for a hearing to determine whether or not such person is in violation of this
article, and such hearing be set as provided in section
28-392.
(Code 2014, § 28-390; Ord. No. 347, § A(4), 9-9-1996; Amd. of 4-10-2007, § A
(4))
State law reference(s)—Required provisions in procedure, V.T.C.A.,
Transportation Code § 683.074.
Sec. 28-391. Contents of notice.
   (a)   The notice must be personally delivered, sent by certified mail with a
five-day return requested, or delivered by the United States Postal Service
with signature confirmation service to:
      (1)   The last-known registered owner of the nuisance;
      (2)   Each lien holder of record of the nuisance; and
      (3)   The owner or occupant of:
         a.   The property on which the nuisance is located; or
         b.   If the nuisance is located on a public right-of-way, the property
adjacent to the right-of-way.
   (b)   The notice must state that:
      (1)   The nuisance must be abated and removed not later than the tenth
day after the date on which the notice was personally delivered or mailed; and
      (2)   Any request for a hearing must be made before that ten-day period
expires.
   (c)   If the post office address of the last-known registered owner of the
nuisance is unknown, notice may be placed on the nuisance or, if the owner is
located, personally delivered.
   (d)   If notice is returned undelivered, action to abate the nuisance shall
be continued to a date not earlier than the 11th day after the date of the
return.
(Code 2014, § 28-391)
State law reference(s)—Similar provision, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code §
683.075.
Sec. 28-392. Preliminaries to hearing in municipal court.
   (a)   Upon receiving a request for a hearing made pursuant to section
28-390, the clerk of the municipal court shall set a date and a time for such
hearing on the court docket. The clerk of the municipal court shall notify the
person for whom notice is required under V.T.C.A., Transportation Code §
683.075(a)(3) and the city attorney of the date and time of such hearing. The
hearing shall be held not earlier than the 11th day after the date of the
service of notice.
   (b)   At the hearing, the junked motor vehicle is presumed, unless
demonstrated otherwise by the owner, to be inoperable.
(Code 2014, § 28-392; Ord. No. 347, § A(6), 9-9-1996; Amd. of 4-10-2007, § A
(6))
State law reference(s)—Hearing requested by person served by the notice,
V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 683.076.
Sec. 28-393. Hearing in municipal court.
   (a)   The judge of the municipal court shall hear any case brought before
said court, as set out in section
28-392, and shall determine whether or not the defendant is, in fact, in
violation of this article.
   (b)   The judge of said court shall order such defendant to remove and abate
said nuisance within ten days, the same being a reasonable time. If the
defendant shall fail or refuse within the said ten days to abate or remove said
nuisance, the judge of the municipal court shall issue an order directing the
chief of police to have the same removed, and the chief of police, or the
chief's duly authorized agent, shall take possession of said junked motor
vehicle and remove it from the premises. Such order shall include a description
of the vehicle and the correct identification number and license number if
available at the site.
(Code 2014, § 28-393; Ord. No. 347, § A(7), 9-9-1996; Amd. of 4-10-2007, § A
(7))
Sec. 28-394. Removal with permission of owner or occupant.
If, within ten days after the receipt of notice from the city to abate the
nuisance as herein provided, the owner or occupant of the premises shall give
written permission to the city for removal of the junked motor vehicle from the
premises; the giving of such permission shall be considered compliance with the
provisions of this article.
(Code 2014, § 28-394; Ord. No. 347, § A(8), 9-9-1996; Amd. of 4-10-2007, § A
(8))
Sec. 28-395. Removal from unoccupied premises by order of municipal court.
If there is a junked motor vehicle, as herein defined, on-premises that are
unoccupied, and neither the owner of the premises nor the owner of such vehicle
can be found and notified to remove the same, then, upon a showing of such
facts to the judge of the municipal court, the court may issue an order
directing the city to have the same removed and the chief of police or the
chief's duly authorized agent, shall take possession of such junked motor
vehicle and remove it from the premises.
(Code 2014, § 28-395; Ord. No. 347, § A(9), 9-9-1996; Amd. of 4-10-2007, § A
(9))
Sec. 28-396. Administration of article.
   (a)   Junked motor vehicles shall be removed by the chief of police or the
chief's duly authorized agent. A junked motor vehicle which has been removed
under this article shall not be reconstructed or made operable.
   (b)   Within five days after the date of removal, notice shall be given to
the state department of motor vehicles identifying the vehicle or part thereof
so the department may cancel the certificate of title to the vehicle motor
vehicles removed under this article shall be disposed of in accordance with
state law.
   (c)   The administration of this article shall be executed by regularly
salaried, full-time employees of the city, except that the removal of vehicles,
or parts thereof from the property may be by any other duly authorized person.
   (d)   A person authorized to administer the procedures may enter private
property to examine a public nuisance, to obtain information to identify the
nuisance, and to remove or direct the removal of the nuisance.
   (e)   The relocation of a junked vehicle that is a public nuisance to
another location in the city after a proceeding for the abatement and removal
of the public nuisance has commenced has no effect on the proceeding if the
junked vehicle constitutes a public nuisance at the new location.
   (f)   On receipt of notice of removal of a watercraft under this article,
the department of motor vehicles shall notify the parks and wildlife department
of the removal. On receipt of the notice from the department, the parks and
wildlife department shall immediately cancel the certificate of title issued
for the watercraft.
(Code 2014, § 28-396; Ord. No. 347, § A(10), 9-9-1996; Amd. of 4-10-2007, § A
(10))
State law reference(s)—Similar provisions, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code §
683.074.
Sec. 28-397. Offense.
   (a)   In addition or in the alternative, a person commits an offense if the
person maintains a public nuisance described by section
28-388.
   (b)   The city attorney shall cause to be prepared, filed and served on the
defendant, a written complaint charging that the owner or occupant of the
premises, as the case may be, has violated this article. After service, such
complaint shall be on file with the clerk of the municipal court not less than
ten days prior to the date of trial.
   (c)   Upon a finding that the defendant is in violation of this article,
said defendant shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and subject to a fine in
accordance with the provisions of this section.
   (d)   An offense under this section is a misdemeanor punishable by a fine
not to exceed $200.00.
   (e)   The court shall order abatement and removal of the nuisance upon
conviction.
(Code 2014, § 28-397; Ord. No. 347, § A(6), 9-9-1996; Amd. of 4-10-2007, § A
(6), (11))
State law reference(s)—Offense, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 683.073.
Secs. 28-398—28-448. Reserved.
ARTICLE VII. TRUCK AND HAZARDOUS MATERIAL ROUTES
State law reference(s)—Permit for moving certain heavy equipment, V.T.C.A.,
Transportation Code § 623.071 et seq.
Sec. 28-449. Definitions.
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have
the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly
indicates a different meaning:
   Hazardous material means a substance or material in a quantity and/or form
which may pose an unreasonable risk to health and safety or property. Hazardous
material may include products which are described as explosive, radioactive,
etiologic agents, flammable or combustible liquids or solids, poisons,
oxidizing or corrosive, and compressed gases.
   Motor vehicle means every device in or by which any person or property may
be transported or drawn upon a public highway and which device is self-
propelled.
   Road tractor means every motor vehicle designed or used for drawing other
vehicles or loads, and not so constructed as to carry a load independently or
any part of the weight of the drawn load or vehicle.
   Semi-trailer means vehicles of the trailer type so designed or used in
conjunction with a motor vehicle that some part of its own weight and that of
its load rests upon or is carried by another vehicle.
   Truck means any motor vehicle designed, used, or maintained primarily for
the transportation of property with a manufacturer's rated carrying capacity
exceeding 2,000 pounds and is not intended to include those trucks commonly
known as pickup trucks, panel delivery trucks, and carryall trucks unless they
are carrying "hazardous material," as defined in this section.
   Truck tractor means every motor vehicle designed or used for drawing other
vehicles, and not so constructed as to carry a load other than a part of the
weight of the vehicle and load, as drawn.
(Code 2014, § 28-449; Ord. No. 440, § 1(exh. A, § 1), 9-14-1998)
Sec. 28-450. Routes established.
There is hereby established and created certain truck routes and hazardous
material routes in, around, and through the city, for all trucks, semitrailers,
road tractors, and truck tractors or any vehicle or conveyance entering or
exiting the city as follows:
      (1)   State Highway 21;
      (2)   State Highway 75;
      (3)   State Highway 90;
      (4)   F.M. 978;
      (5)   Interstate Highway 45.
(Code 2014, § 28-450; Ord. No. 440, § 1(exh. A, § 2), 9-14-1998)
Sec. 28-451. Through traffic prohibited.
Through traffic of any trucks, semitrailers, road tractors, and truck tractors
or any vehicle or conveyance or hazardous material carrier on any street within
the city, other than those streets or highways specifically designated in
section
28-450, is expressly prohibited and is declared to be unlawful.
(Code 2014, § 28-451; Ord. No. 440, § 1(exh. A, § 3), 9-14-1998)
Sec. 28-452. Exceptions.
The terms, provisions, and regulations set forth in this article do not, and
are not intended to apply to trucks, semitrailers, road tractors, and truck
tractors or any vehicle or conveyance or hazardous material carriers entering
the city and traveling on streets other than those designated herein for the
purpose of pickup or delivery to a specific location, or to obtain service
repairs, lodging, fuel, or other legitimate purposes requiring a stop in the
city. All vehicles departing from an established truck and/or hazardous
material route under one of the stated exceptions herein shall return to said
route by the most direct means practical.
(Code 2014, § 28-452; Ord. No. 440, § 1(exh. A, § 4), 9-14-1998)
Sec. 28-453. Signs.
The director of public works of the city is hereby directed to erect
appropriate signs upon the streets as approved by the state department of
transportation and may, at his discretion, place signs upon other local streets
notifying the public that no trucks and/or hazardous material is allowed
thereon.
(Code 2014, § 28-453; Ord. No. 440, § 1(exh. A, § 5), 9-14-1998)
Sec. 28-454. Penalty for violation.
Any person violating, disobeying, or refusing to comply with any provision of
this article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall, upon conviction, be
punishable by a fine in accordance with state laws.
(Code 2014, § 28-454; Ord. No. 440, § 1(exh. A, § 6), 9-14-1998)
Secs. 28-455—28-476. Reserved.
ARTICLE VIII. PARADES AND PROCESSIONS
State law reference(s)—Following distance in procession, V.T.C.A.,
Transportation Code § 545.062.
Sec. 28-477. Certificate of registration; illegal gatherings; penalty.
   (a)   Obstructing streets and sidewalks by assembling crowds, preaching,
hawking, etc.; a certificate of registration is required. It shall be unlawful
for any person to obstruct or impede the ordinary use of the streets and
sidewalks of the city by assembling crowds thereon or use the same for the
purposes of preaching, begging, speechmaking, hawking goods or merchandise, or
by selling medicine or other commodities, without first obtaining a certificate
of registration authorized by the city council.
   (b)   Gatherings that are annoying to abutting property owners. It shall be
unlawful for persons to gather together in squads or crowds on the sidewalks or
in the streets or at street corners to the annoyance of the owners or occupants
of the premises abutting the same. Any person who violates the provisions of
this section, after being warned by a police officer or the owner or occupant
of such premises, to remove themselves from the area affected, shall be subject
to prosecution.
   (c)   Processions, parades restricted to terms of certificate of
registration. No procession or parade shall occupy, march, or proceed along any
street in the city except funeral processions, forces of the United States
Army, Navy, or Marine Corps, the military forces of this state, the forces of
the police and fire department, except in accordance with a certificate of
registration issued by authority of the police department.
   (d)   Penalty for violation of provisions. Every person violating any
provision of this section shall, upon conviction, be fined in accordance with
state statutes.
(Code 2014, § 28-477; Ord. No. 584, § 1(exh. A, § I), 1-14-2003)
Secs. 28-478—28-505. Reserved.
ARTICLE IX. TAXICAB REGULATIONS
State law reference(s)—Authority to regulate taxicabs, V.T.C.A., Local
Government Code § 215.004; regulation of transportation network companies
preempted by the state, V.T.C.A., Occupations Code § 2402.001 et seq.
DIVISION 1. GENERALLY
Sec. 28-506. Definitions.
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have
the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly
indicates a different meaning:
   Applicant means any individual, firm or corporation in the process of
attaining either a license to operate or a city taxi driver permit.
   Driver means an individual who drives or operates a taxicab.
   Flat rate charge schedule means a schedule of charges are to be determined
by the city council, which may be amended on an annual basis, as needed.
   Holder means a person who is granted an annual operating permit to operate a
taxicab service under the provisions of this article.
   Manifest means a daily record prepared by a taxicab driver of all trips made
by the driver, showing time and place of origin, destination, number of
passengers and the amount of fare of each trip.
   Operating permit means the permission granted by the city to operate a
taxicab service inside the city for a period of one year, renewable under the
provisions of this article.
   Rate card means a card for display in each taxicab which contains the rates
of fare in force.
   Taxicab means a motor vehicle regularly engaged in the business of carrying
passengers for hire and not operated on a fixed route, other than a limousine
and transportation network personal vehicle defined in V.T.C.A., Occupations
Code § 2402.001.
   Taxicab business means a service consisting of the provision and operation
of motor vehicles for hire which carry passengers and are not operated on a
fixed route, and does not include limousine services.
(Code 2014, § 28-506; Ord. No. 717, § 1, 1-14-2013)
Sec. 28-507. Vehicle inspection.
   (a)   Before being allowed to operate upon the streets of the city, each
taxicab shall be inspected and approved annually by the chief of police or his
representative.
   (b)   No taxicab shall be driven or operated upon the streets of the city
unless the same is in safe condition and free from mechanical defects, and must
further meet the following requirements:
      (1)   Be in compliance with the safety requirements of the state Motor
Vehicle Code, as amended;
      (2)   Have a seat belt for each passenger;
      (3)   Have an operating heater and air conditioner;
      (4)   Have a fire extinguisher that is in good operating order; and
      (5)   Have a taxi-top light.
   (c)   The vehicle identification number and license number of each taxicab
must match the numbers listed for that taxicab on the permit application.
   (d)   The insignia of the taxicab must be the same as that indicated on the
permit application.
(Code 2014, § 28-507; Ord. No. 717, § 2, 1-14-2013)
Sec. 28-508. Condition of vehicles.
Every vehicle operating under this article shall be kept clean and in sanitary
condition.
(Code 2014, § 28-508; Ord. No. 717, § 3, 1-14-2013)
Sec. 28-509. Designation of taxi.
   (a)   Each taxicab shall have painted on both sides the trade name of the
organization under whose operating permit such taxicab is being operated, the
taxicab unit number, and the business telephone number of the holder of the
operating permit. Such letters and numbers shall be not less than three inches
high with one-half-inch stroke, painted on each taxicab with permanent, non-
washable paint of a color sharply contrasting to the color of the taxicab so
that the same will be readily apparent.
   (b)   No design shall be approved that, in the opinion of the city,
conflicts with or imitates that of any vehicle already operating under an
operating permit granted under this article.
(Code 2014, § 28-509; Ord. No. 717, § 4, 1-14-2013)
Sec. 28-510. Fare rates; rate card required.
   (a)   This section establishes maximum fares that the owner or operator of a
taxicab can charge.
   (b)   Flat rates for fares within the city limits and outside of the city
limits are established in the taxicab rates which are on file with the city and
incorporated herein by reference the same as if fully set forth herein. The
city council may establish or adjust the taxicab rates as the city council
deems necessary from time to time.
   (c)   Every taxicab operated under this article shall have a rate card
setting forth the rates of fare established by this section and approved by the
city council, displayed in a place in view of all passengers. The approved rate
card shall instruct customers to call the city police department at (936) 348-
3317 or any successor non-emergency telephone number if they have questions or
concerns about the rates.
   (d)   In January of each year, the chief of police shall review the rates of
fare to determine whether the fares need to be reconsidered. The chief of
police shall base such the determination on the consumer price index, the costs
of gasoline, and other reasonable costs of operating a taxicab service. The
chief of police shall report his findings each year to the city council.
(Code 2014, § 28-510; Ord. No. 717, § 5, 1-14-2013)
Sec. 28-511. Attempt to defraud passenger.
A person who operates a taxicab commits an offense if the person intentionally
extends the distance or time for a trip beyond the distance and time necessary
for the trip for the purpose of increasing the fare for the trip.
(Code 2014, § 28-511; Ord. No. 717, § 6, 1-14-2013)
Sec. 28-512. Solicitation of business.
It shall be unlawful for any driver of any taxicab or for any other person
acting for the driver to seek or solicit patrons or passengers for any such
taxicab by word or sign while driving any such taxicab over, through or on any
public street or public place of the city. Drivers may solicit business when
the taxicab is legally parked.
(Code 2014, § 28-512; Ord. No. 717, § 7, 1-14-2013)
Sec. 28-513. Additional passengers.
   (a)   No driver shall permit any other person to occupy or ride in the
taxicab, unless the person first employing the taxicab shall consent to the
acceptance of the additional passenger.
   (b)   No driver shall permit more people to occupy a taxicab than the number
of seatbelts installed and operational in that taxicab.
(Code 2014, § 28-513; Ord. No. 717, § 1, 8-14-2013)
Sec. 28-514. Refusal to carry orderly passengers prohibited.
No taxicab driver shall refuse or neglect to convey any orderly person, upon
request, unless:
      (1)   The taxicab is previously engaged;
      (2)   The person is disorderly;
      (3)   The driver is engaged in answering a previous request for service;
      (4)   The driver is in fear of his personal safety; or
      (5)   The driver reasonably believes, based on a person's behavior that
transporting the person would damage the taxicab.
(Code 2014, § 28-514; Ord. No. 717, § 9, 1-14-2013)
Sec. 28-515. Service.
   (a)   An operating permit holder shall maintain a central place of business
and shall remain open for the purpose of receiving calls and dispatching cabs,
and shall offer taxi service at all times that the taxicab service is available
to provide taxicab services to the public.
   (b)   All calls for services inside the city during these hours shall be
answered as soon as reasonably possible. If the services cannot be rendered
within a reasonable time, the holder shall notify the prospective passenger how
long it will be before the call can be answered and the reason for the delay.
Any holder who refuses to accept a call anywhere in the city during these hours
when the holder has available cabs, or who fails or refuses to provide high
quality service, shall be deemed to violate this article and the violation
shall be grounds for revocation of the operating permit.
   (c)   In addition to operating during the hours described in subsection (a)
of this section, an operating permit holder may operate cabs during other hours
at the holder's discretion. During the additional hours of operation, the
holder shall comply with all requirements of this article.
(Code 2014, § 28-515; Ord. No. 717, § 10, 1-14-2013)
Sec. 28-516. Manifest.
Every driver of a vehicle operated pursuant to this article shall maintain a
daily manifest upon which are recorded all trips made each day, showing time
and place of origin and destination of each trip and the amount of fare. All
completed manifests shall be returned to the designated agent of the holder of
an operating permit at the conclusion of each tour of duty. The forms for each
manifest shall be furnished to the driver by the holder. The holder shall
retain and preserve all drivers' manifests in a safe place for at least the
calendar year next preceding the current calendar year, and the manifests shall
be available to the city at all times.
(Code 2014, § 28-516; Ord. No. 717, § 11, 1-14-2013)
Sec. 28-517. Holder's records and reports.
Every operating permit holder shall keep accurate records of receipts from
operations, operating and other expenses, capital expenditures and any other
operating information required by the city. Every holder shall maintain the
records containing this information and other data required by this article at
a place readily accessible for examination by the city.
(Code 2014, § 28-517; Ord. No. 717, § 12, 1-14-2013)
Secs. 28-518—28-530. Reserved.
DIVISION 2. OPERATING PERMIT
Sec. 28-531. Required.
No person shall engage, directly or indirectly, in the taxicab business upon
the city streets without having first obtained an operating permit from the
city council.
(Code 2014, § 28-518; Ord. No. 717, § 13, 1-14-2013)
Sec. 28-532. Application.
An application for an operating permit required in section 28-231 shall be
filed with the city clerk upon forms provided by the city. The application
shall contain the following information:
      (1)   The name and address of the applicant.
      (2)   If the applicant is a partnership, the information in subsection
(1) of this section shall be provided for each partner.
      (3)   If the applicant is a corporation, the name and place of residence
of all of the officers of the corporation, a duly certified copy of its charter
and bylaws, the amount of capital stock, the character and value of its assets,
its liabilities and the security therefor and, if the corporation is a foreign
corporation, a duly certified copy of its certificate of authority to transact
business in the state.
      (4)   The experience of the applicant in the transportation of
passengers.
      (5)   Any facts the applicant believes tend to prove that public
convenience and necessity require the granting of an operating permit.
      (6)   The name, usual trade description, seating capacity, equipment,
motor number, state license number, rated horsepower and factory number of each
motor vehicle to be operated or controlled by applicant, and the year in which
each automobile was manufactured.
      (7)   The location of any stand at which the taxicabs will remain when
not in actual service.
      (8)   The name and address of the person who will be in active charge and
control of the taxicab business.
      (9)   The proposed fares.
      (10)   The color scheme or insignia to be used to designate the vehicles
of the applicant.
(Code 2014, § 28-519; Ord. No. 717, § 14, 1-14-2013)
Sec. 28-533. Fees.
No operating permit required under this division shall be issued or continued
in operation unless the holder thereof has paid an annual license fee of
$200.00 and a $20.00 fee each year for each vehicle operated under an operating
permit. The fees shall be paid to the city to compensate the city for its
superintendence of the taxicab business operated under this division and for
the use of the city streets, alleys, and public ways.
(Code 2014, § 28-520; Ord. No. 717, § 15, 1-14-2013)
Sec. 28-534. Public hearing.
   (a)   Upon the filing of an application for a certificate under this
division, a time and place shall be set for a public hearing thereon. Notice of
the hearing shall be given to the applicant and to all persons to whom
operating permits have been previously issued. Due notice shall also be given
to the general public by publication of the notice, at least ten days prior to
the date set for the hearing, in a newspaper of general circulation in the
city.
   (b)   Any interested person may file with the city council a statement in
support of or opposition to the issuance of an operating permit.
(Code 2014, § 28-521; Ord. No. 717, § 16, 1-14-2013)
Sec. 28-535. Issuance.
If the city council, after the public hearing required by section
28-534, finds that further taxicab service in the city is required by the
public convenience and necessity and that the applicant is fit, willing and
able to provide the public transportation and to conform to this division, the
city council shall issue an operating permit stating the name and address of
the applicant, the number of vehicles authorized under the certificate and the
date of issuance; otherwise the application shall be denied.
(Code 2014, § 28-522; Ord. No. 717, § 17, 1-14-2013)
Sec. 28-536. Insurance required.
Each holder of an operating permit for the operation of a taxicab business
shall at all times during the term of the operating permit maintain a policy of
liability insurance issued by an insurance company authorized to do business in
the state on each and every motor vehicle operated under the terms of the
operating permit in the amount of $100,000.00 for bodily injury to anyone
person; in the amount of $300,000.00 for injuries to more than one person which
are sustained in the same accident; and $100,000.00 for property damage
resulting from any one accident. The policy shall list the city as an
additional insured. The policies shall be approved by the city attorney and
filed with the city secretary. The policies of insurance shall not be canceled
or surrendered except after ten days' written notice to the city secretary.
Failure of the operating permit holder to procure and file the policies of
insurance as required by the section or failure to keep the policies in force
shall immediately forfeit and make the operating permit null and void, and all
rights thereunder shall at once cease.
(Code 2014, § 28-523; Ord. No. 717, § 18, 1-14-2013)
Sec. 28-537. Transferability.
No operating permit required under this division may be sold, assigned,
mortgaged, or otherwise transferred without the consent of the city council.
(Code 2014, § 28-524; Ord. No. 717, § 19, 1-14-2013)
Sec. 28-538. Suspension and revocation.
   (a)   Upon complaint alleging violation of any of the provisions of this
division filed by any person with the chief of police, or upon the person's
motion, the chief of police, after five days' notice of the grounds of such
complaint to the owner or operators of the taxicab service against whom
complaint is made, shall hear evidence with reference to such compliant, and
after such hearing, the chief of police may revoke or suspend the operating
permit of such holder with good cause shown.
   (b)   Due cause for the suspension or revocation of an operating permit will
include, but not be limited to, the following:
      (1)   Failure of the operating permit holder to maintain any and all of
the general qualifications applicable to the initial issuance of the permit as
set forth in this division;
      (2)   Obtaining an operating permit by providing false information;
      (3)   Discontinuing operations for more than ten days;
      (4)   Violating any ordinance of the city, the laws of the United States
or of the state, the violation of which adversely affects the ability of the
holder to offer public transportation; or
      (5)   Violation of any part of this division.
   (c)   The holder shall have the right to appeal the suspension or revocation
to the city manager within ten business days of the notice of suspension or
revocation. Such appeal will be submitted by a letter addressed to the city
manager stating that an appeal from the decision of the chief of police is
desired to the city manager. Upon receiving such notice of appeal, the city
manager, as soon as practical thereafter, shall conduct a hearing at which the
appealing party will be given an opportunity to present evidence and make
argument in the person's behalf. The formal rules of evidence do not apply to
an appeal hearing under this section. The city manager shall make its ruling on
the basis of a preponderance of the evidence at the hearing.
   (d)   The city manager will affirm, modify or reverse the decision of the
chief of police. The decision of the city manager is final.
   (e)   If no appeal is taken from the ruling of the chief of police in the
time and manner provided in this division, the ruling of the chief of police
shall be final.
   (f)   Any person who continues to operate a taxicab under a permit that has
been suspended or revoked for any reason while the suspension or revocation is
in effect shall be considered guilty of misdemeanor and upon conviction
thereof, shall be assessed a penalty accordingly. Every day's violation shall
be considered to be a separate offense.
(Code 2014, § 28-525; Ord. No. 717, § 20, 1-14-2013)
Secs. 28-539—28-550. Reserved.
DIVISION 3. TAXICAB DRIVER'S PERMIT
Sec. 28-551. Required.
No person shall operate a taxicab for hire upon the city streets and no person
who owns or controls a taxicab shall permit it to be so driven, unless the
driver of the taxicab shall have in force a taxicab driver's permit issued
under this division.
(Code 2014, § 28-526; Ord. No. 717, § 21, 1-14-2013)
Sec. 28-552. Application.
   (a)   The holder of an operating permit shall file with the city secretary
an application for a taxicab driver's permit for each driver employed by the
holder. On the application, the holder shall certify that there is currently in
effect an insurance policy covering the driver while the driver is engaged in
providing taxi service.
   (b)   It is the responsibility of the holder to immediately notify the city
clerk if the insurance required by subsection (a) of this section is no longer
in effect for a driver holding a driver's permit and employed by the holder.
(Code 2014, § 28-527; Ord. No. 717, § 22, 1-14-2013)
Sec. 28-553. Issuance; duration.
   (a)   Upon submission of the application for a taxicab driver's permit, a
permit shall be issued which shall bear the name, address, signature, and
photograph of the driver.
   (b)   The driver's permit shall be in effect for one calendar year.
(Code 2014, § 28-528; Ord. No. 717, § 23, 1-14-2013)
Sec. 28-554. Display.
Every driver operating pursuant to this division shall post the driver's permit
in full view of all passengers while the driver is operating a taxicab. The
permit shall be in sufficiently large type that a person with normal eyesight
can read the permit from the back seat of the taxicab.
(Code 2014, § 28-529; Ord. No. 717, § 24, 1-14-2013)
Sec. 28-555. Failure to comply with laws.
Every driver receiving a driver's permit under this division shall comply with
all city, state, and federal laws. Failure to do so will justify the suspension
or revocation of the permit. The police chief shall initiate the revocation or
suspension. No permit shall be suspended or revoked unless notice and an
opportunity to be heard have been provided to the holder of the permit.
(Code 2014, § 28-530; Ord. No. 717, § 25, 1-14-2013)
Sec. 28-556. Suspension and revocation.
   (a)   Upon complaint alleging violation of any of the provisions of this
division filed by any person with the chief of police, or upon the person's
motion, the chief of police, after five days' notice of the grounds of such
complaint to the driver and to the owner or operators of the taxicab service
against whom complaint is made, shall hear evidence with reference to such
complaint, and after such hearing, the chief of police may revoke or suspend
the driver's permit of such driver with good cause shown.
   (b)   Due cause for the suspension or revocation of a driver's permit will
include, but not be limited to, the following:
      (1)   Failure of the driver's permit holder to maintain any and all of
the general qualifications applicable to the initial issuance of the permit as
set forth in this division;
      (2)   Obtaining a driver's permit by providing false information;
      (3)   Violating any ordinance of the city, the laws of the United States,
or of the state, the violation of which adversely affects the ability of the
holder to offer public transportation; or
      (4)   Violation of any part of this division.
   (c)   The holder shall have the right to appeal the suspension or revocation
to the city manager within ten business days of the notice of suspension or
revocation. Such appeal will be submitted by a letter addressed to the city
manager stating that an appeal from the decision of the chief of police is
desired to the city manager. Upon receiving such notice of appeal, the city
manager, as soon as practical thereafter, shall conduct a hearing at which the
appealing party will be given an opportunity to present evidence and make
argument in the person's behalf. The formal rules of evidence do not apply to
an appeal hearing under this section. The city manager shall make its ruling on
the basis of a preponderance of the evidence at the hearing.
   (d)   The city manager will affirm, modify or reverse the decision of the
chief of police. The decision of the city manager is final.
   (e)   If no appeal is taken from the ruling of the chief of police in the
time and manner as provided in this division, the ruling of the chief of police
shall be final.
   (f)   Any person who continues to drive a taxicab under a driver's permit
that has been suspended or revoked for any reason while the suspension or
revocation is in effect shall be considered guilty of a misdemeanor and upon
conviction thereof, shall be assessed a penalty accordingly. Every day's
violation shall be considered to be a separate offense.
(Code 2014, § 28-531; Ord. No. 717, § 26, 1-14-2013)
Secs. 28-557—28-570. Reserved.
DIVISION 4. TAXICAB DRIVERS
Sec. 28-571. Driver's conduct.
   (a)   While on duty, a driver shall:
      (1)   Act in a professional and courteous manner; and
      (2)   Maintain a well-groomed appearance.
   (b)   While on duty, a driver may not:
      (1)   Consume an alcoholic beverage, controlled substance, or other
substance that could adversely affect the driver's ability to drive a motor
vehicle, and may not drive a vehicle while under the influence of an alcoholic
beverage, controlled substance, or other substance that could adversely affect
the driver's ability to drive a motor vehicle;
      (2)   Sell or otherwise provide an alcoholic beverage or a controlled
substance to a passenger in a ground transportation service vehicle;
      (3)   Monitor the communication frequency of a ground transportation
service other than the driver's own frequency or respond to a service call
assigned to another driver; or
      (4)   Possess communication equipment, including scanners, capable of
receiving the frequency of a service other than the driver's own.
   (c)   If a person is convicted of an offense prescribed in subsection (b)(2)
of this section, the conviction results in the automatic revocation, without
further notice, of all chauffeur's permits held by the person.
(Code 2014, § 28-532; Ord. No. 717, § 27, 1-14-2013)
Sec. 28-572. Soliciting for other business prohibited.
A driver may not solicit business for a hotel, motel, or similar business or
attempt to divert patronage from one lodging business to another.
(Code 2014, § 28-533; Ord. No. 717, § 28, 1-14-2013)
Sec. 28-573. Unlawful acts.
A driver may not knowingly permit an unlawful act to be conducted in the
taxicab.
(Code 2014, § 28-534)
Sec. 28-574. Distracting driver.
   (a)   A person may not distract or attempt to distract the driver of a
taxicab by physical contact or disorderly behavior while the driver is
operating the taxicab.
   (b)   Violation of this section is a misdemeanor punishable by a fine not to
exceed $500.00.
(Code 2014, § 28-535; Ord. No. 717, § 30, 1-14-2013)
Sec. 28-575. Training required.
   (a)   Before applying for a driver's permit, each applicant must attend and
complete training on recognizing the symptoms of alcohol poisoning and what to
do when they observe someone with the symptoms.
   (b)   Before applying for a driver's permit, each applicant must attend
hospitality training.
   (c)   The chief of police will provide the training free of charge to the
applicant.
(Code 2014, § 28-536; Ord. No. 717, § 31, 1-14-2013)
Secs. 28-576—28-590. Reserved.
ARTICLE X. VEHICLE TOWING AND IMMOBILIZATION
State law reference(s)—Vehicle towing and booting, V.T.C.A., Occupations Code §
2308.001 et seq.
Sec. 28-591. Authority to remove vehicles.
A police officer is authorized to remove or cause the removal of a vehicle or
other property of any description from a street to a place designated by the
chief of police when:
      (1)   The vehicle or property is left unattended upon a bridge or viaduct
or underpass and the vehicle is obstructing traffic;
      (2)   The vehicle is illegally parked so as to block the entrance to any
private driveway;
      (3)   The vehicle is found upon a street and a report has previously been
made that the vehicle has been stolen or a complaint has been filed and a
warrant issued charging that the vehicle has been unlawfully taken from the
owner;
      (4)   The vehicle is unattended and the officer has reasonable grounds to
believe that the vehicle has been abandoned for longer than 48 hours;
(5) a. A vehicle upon a street is so disabled that its normal operation is
impossible or impractical and the owner or person in charge of the vehicle is
incapacitated by reason of physical injury or other reason to such an extent as
to be unable to provide for its removal or custody, or are not in the immediate
vicinity of the disabled vehicle;
         b.   The vehicle is disabled so that normal operation is impossible or
impractical and the owner or person in charge of the vehicle does not designate
a particular towing or storage company;
      (6)   An officer arrests any person driving or in control of a vehicle
for an alleged offense and the officer is by law required to take the person
arrested into custody;
      (7)   The vehicle is standing, parked, or stopped in any portion of a
street, and the officer has reason to believe that the vehicle constitutes a
hazard or interferes with the normal function of a governmental agency, or
because of a catastrophe, emergency, or unusual circumstance the safety of the
vehicle is imperiled;
      (8)   The vehicle is standing, parked, or stopped in violation of the
parking ban regulations;
      (9)   The vehicle standing, parked, or stopped in violation of any
provision of this article;
      (10)   The vehicle is the subject of a hearing officer's order for a
parking violation and impoundment of the vehicle is authorized;
      (11)   The vehicle is in an accident and the vehicle's owner or operator
fails to show evidence of financial responsibility as required under V.T.C.A.,
Transportation Code ch. 601, as amended; or
      (12)   The vehicle is stopped by a police officer for an alleged
violation of a city or state traffic law or other law applicable to the
operation of a vehicle on the roadway and the vehicle's owner or operator fails
to show evidence of financial responsibility as required under V.T.C.A.,
Transportation Code ch. 601, as amended.
(Code 2014, § 28-553; Ord. No. 707, § 1, 7-9-2012)
State law reference(s)—Impoundment of vehicle under certain circumstances,
V.T.C.A., Transportation Code §§ 545.305, 545.3051; impoundment of vehicle for
failure to maintain evidence of financial responsibility, V.T.C.A.,
Transportation Code § 601.261.
Sec. 28-592. Redemption of towed vehicle.
A vehicle removed and towed under section
28-591 must be kept at the place designated by the chief of police until
application for redemption is made by the owner or the owner's authorized
agent, who will be entitled to possession of the vehicle upon payment of costs
of towing, notification, impoundment, and storage. The chief of police shall
authorize fees for storage of vehicles that are towed in accordance with the
following regulations:
      (1)   The storage fee is $20.00 for each day or portion of a day that a
vehicle not longer than 25 feet is stored and $35.00 for each day or portion of
a day that a vehicle longer than 25 feet is stored, except that a storage fee
may not be charged for more than one day if the vehicle is stored for less than
12 hours.
      (2)   Storage fees on a stolen vehicle will be charged as outlined in
subsection (1) of this section, commencing on the second day following the date
notice is received by the owner of the vehicle, or the owner's agent, that the
vehicle may be claimed.
      (3)   Storage fees on a vehicle owned by an arrested person will be
charged as outlined in subsection (1) of this section, commencing on the date
of impoundment.
      (4)   Storage fees will not be collected when a vehicle is not involved
in an accident, but is taken into protective custody and the driver is
incapacitated due to physical injury or other illness to the extent that the
driver is unable to care for the vehicle.
      (5)   Storage fees on any vehicle involved in a motor vehicle accident
will be charged as outlined in subsection (1) of this section, commencing on
the date of impoundment.
(Code 2014, § 28-554; Ord. No. 707, § 1, 7-9-2012)
State law reference(s)—Charges for impoundment, etc., V.T.C.A., Occupations
Code § 2303.155;
Sec. 28-593. Vehicle to be left at scene of crime.
A police officer may, at his discretion, with the express written permission of
an arrested person, leave an arrested person's vehicle at the scene of the
arrest or other location. In these instances, the arresting officer shall
ensure that the vehicle is legally parked and secure.
(Code 2014, § 28-555; Ord. No. 707, § 1, 7-9-2012)
Sec. 28-594. Fees exempted under certain circumstances.
   (a)   The chief of police or a designated representative may release a
vehicle without payment of towage or storage fees under the following
circumstances:
      (1)   A vehicle was taken into protective custody when the incident did
not involve an arrest, violation, or automobile accident.
      (2)   A vehicle is owned by or belongs to an individual who is not a
citizen of the United States, who does not permanently reside in the United
States, and who is entitled to diplomatic immunity;
      (3)   Subsequent investigation results in a determination that there was
no violation of this Code or the state motor vehicle laws or that the arrested
person did not commit a criminal offense; or
      (4)   A vehicle is owned by or belongs to the victim of a violent crime
and was taken into custody for evidentiary purposes.
   (b)   If a vehicle was towed and stored for an evidentiary or examination
purpose, the chief of police or a designated representative shall release the
vehicle without payment of towage and storage fees when required to do so under
Vernon's Ann. C.C.P. art. 18.23, as amended.
(Code 2014, § 28-556; Ord. No. 707, § 1, 7-9-2012)
Sec. 28-595. Offense; commercial purpose.
   (a)   A person commits an offense if he removes or attempts to remove a
vehicle from a storage location without first paying the towage and storage
fees that have accrued on the vehicle.
   (b)   As a consequence of the fees to be charged for vehicle stored at all
storage locations and for the purposes of state law, the city council hereby
designates all storage facilities as storage facilities operated for commercial
purpose.
(Code 2014, § 28-557; Ord. No. 707, § 1, 7-9-2012)
Sec. 28-596. Evidence of financial responsibility.
All storage facilities towing vehicles for failure to show evidence of
financial responsibility shall require on retrieval or reclaim of said vehicle,
proof of financial responsibility from the owner of said vehicle. A copy of the
proof of financial responsibility showing the vehicle with valid coverage shall
be delivered, mailed or faxed to the chief of police of the city.
(Code 2014, § 28-558; Ord. No. 707, § 1, 7-9-2012)
State law reference(s)—Evidence of insurance or financial responsibility
required for release of vehicle, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 601.262.
Chapter 30 MUNICIPAL COURT
State law reference(s)—Municipal court created in each municipality, V.T.C.A.,
Local Government Code § 29.001 et seq.
ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL
Secs. 30-1—30-18. Reserved.
ARTICLE II. JUDGE
State law reference(s)—Municipal court judge, V.T.C.A., Government Code §
29.004.
Sec. 30-19. Appointment.
The city council shall appoint a municipal judge of the municipal court.
(Code 2014, § 30-19; Ord. No. 123, § 1, 7-22-1960; Ord. No. 195, § 1, 8-23-
1976; Ord. No. 324, § 1, 6-14-1994)
Sec. 30-20. Requirements.
The municipal judge so appointed shall be over the age of 21 years and shall be
a resident of the county.
(Code 2014, § 30-20; Ord. No. 123, § 2, 7-22-1960; Ord. No. 195, § 2, 8-23-
1976; Ord. No. 324, § 2, 6-14-1994)
Sec. 30-21. Term.
Such municipal judge shall hold his office for a term of two years, and shall
hold his office for the term appointed and until his successor shall be
appointed and qualified.
(Code 2014, § 30-21; Ord. No. 123, § 3, 7-22-1960; Ord. No. 195, § 3, 8-23-
1976; Ord. No. 324, § 3, 6-14-1994)
State law reference(s)—Term of office, V.T.C.A., Government Code § 29.005.
Secs. 30-22—30-45. Reserved.
ARTICLE III. PROSECUTION PROCEDURES
State law reference(s)—Proceedings in municipal courts, Vernon's C.C.P. art.
45.001 et seq.
DIVISION 1. GENERALLY
Secs. 30-46—30-60. Reserved.
DIVISION 2. PRIMA FACIE EVIDENCE
Sec. 30-61. Vehicles.
In any prosecution charging a violation of the stopping, standing or parking of
a vehicle, proof that the particular vehicle described in the complaint was
parked in violation of this division, together with proof that the defendant
named in the complaint was, at the time of such parking, the registered owner
of such vehicle, shall constitute in evidence a prima facie presumption that
the registered owner of such vehicle was the person who parked or placed such
vehicle at the point where, and for the time during which, such violation
occurred.
(Code 2014, § 30-54(a); Ord. No. 560, § 10, 2-11-2002)
State law reference(s)—Presumption of violation by motor vehicle owner,
V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 682.008.
Sec. 30-62. Properties.
In any prosecution charging a violation regarding nuisances upon a property,
the failure to comply with any notice or order regarding a nuisance on a
property or building in violation of an ordinance of the city, including, but
not limited to, failure to apply for a building permit or other permit or
