license required herein, proof that the particular property described in the
complaint was in violation of an ordinance regulating the property, together
with proof that the defendant named in the complaint was, at the time of such
notice, violation or order or at the time when work was performed without a
permit, the registered owner of such property, shall constitute in evidence a
prima facie presumption that the registered owner of such property was the
person who failed to comply with the notice or order or failed to apply for a
permit for the time during which such violation occurred in violation of the
charged ordinance of the city.
(Code 2014, § 30-54(b); Ord. No. 560, § 10, 2-11-2002)
Sec. 30-63. Animals.
In any prosecution charging a violation of an ordinance or statute regulating
or governing the abuse, neglect or ownership of an animal or failure to license
an animal as required, proof that the particular property described in the
complaint was the premises upon which the animal resided, was harbored or
maintained and a violation of an ordinance or statute regulating or governing
the animal alleged in the complaint together with proof that the defendant
named in the complaint was, at the time of such complaint or at the time when
the animal was in violation of said ordinance or statute, the registered owner
of such animal or the person with legal rights to reside on said property,
shall constitute in evidence a prima facie presumption that the registered
owner of such property or the person with legal rights to reside on said
property was the owner of the animal and the person who failed to comply with
or violated the ordinance or statute.
(Code 2014, § 30-54(c); Ord. No. 560, § 10, 2-11-2002)
Secs. 30-64—30-80. Reserved.
ARTICLE IV. FINES, FEES AND FUNDS
State law reference(s)—Fines and fees as court costs authorized, Vernon's Ann.
C.C.P. art. 45.203.
DIVISION 1. GENERALLY
Sec. 30-81. Findings.
The recitals set forth in the ordinance from which this article is derived are
hereby found to be true and correct and are hereby adopted by the city council
and made a part hereof for all purposes as findings of fact.
(Code 2014, § 30-46; Ord. No. 560, § 1, 2-11-2002)
Sec. 30-82. Definitions.
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have
the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly
indicates a different meaning:
   Access device means a card, plate, code, account number, personal
identification number, electronic serial number, mobile identification number,
or other telecommunications service, equipment, or instrument identifier or
means of account access that alone or in conjunction with other access devices
may be used to:
      (1)   Obtain money, goods, services, or another thing of value; or
      (2)   Initiate a transfer of funds other than a transfer originated
solely by paper instrument.
   Conviction or convicted means any person for whom the municipal court
imposes any penalty or sentence, the person receives community service,
supervision or deferred adjudication, or the court defers final disposition of
the case.
   Rules of the road means offenses committed under V.T.C.A., Transportation
Code §§ 541.001 through 600.004.
   School crossing zone means a reduced-speed zone designated on a street by a
local authority to facilitate safe crossing of the street by children going to
or leaving a public or private elementary or secondary school during the time
the reduced speed limit applies.
(Code 2014, § 30-47; Ord. No. 560, § 2, 2-11-2002)
Sec. 30-83. Imposition and collection of fees and court costs.
   (a)   The fines imposed in the municipal court may be the same as are
prescribed for like offenses by the penal statutes of the state, but shall
never be greater. Where any offense is covered solely and alone by ordinance of
the city, such ordinance shall control. The municipal court clerk shall collect
and report all court costs as required.
   (b)   The city shall enforce the collection of fines, costs and special
expenses as provided in Vernon's Ann. C.C.P. art. 45.203.
(Code 2014, § 30-48; Ord. No. 560, § 3(part), 2-11-2002)
Sec. 30-84. Waiver of fines, fees and costs of court.
   (a)   The municipal court judge may hold a hearing to determine the economic
capabilities of any defendant filing a written motion seeking a finding of the
court that the defendant is per se indigent and each alternative method of
discharging the fine or costs of court under Vernon's Ann. C.C.P. art. 43.09
would impose an undue hardship on the defendant. The municipal court judge
shall review the motion of the defendant, including any other evidence deemed
necessary, and on a finding that the defendant is indigent or does not have
sufficient resources or income to pay all or part of the fine or costs as a
matter of law and that the alternative methods of discharge would work an undue
hardship on the defendant, the municipal court judge may waive payment of any
fines or costs for which the defendant has defaulted.
   (b)   The municipal court judge may waive payment of all or part of a fine
or costs imposed on a defendant if the defendant at the time the offense was
committed was a child as defined by Vernon's Ann C.C.P. art. 45.058(h).
(Code 2014, § 30-49; Ord. No. 560, § 5, 2-11-2002)
State law reference(s)—Discharge of fine, Vernon's Ann. C.C.P. art. 43.09;
waiver of payment of fines and costs for indigent defendants and children,
Vernon's Ann. C.C.P. art. 43.091.
Secs. 30-85—30-99. Reserved.
DIVISION 2. POST-JUDGMENT COLLECTION OF FINES AND COURT COSTS
Sec. 30-100. Assessing fines, appealing court judgments, and paying fees and
costs.
As provided in the ordinances of the city and state statutes, the municipal
court judge shall assess fines and court costs against each defendant entering
a plea of guilty or no contest or based on the verdict of the court or jury
finding a defendant guilty. Defendants having not timely appealed the judgment
of the court and who fail to timely pay fines, fees, costs or restitution as
ordered shall be subject to permitted post-judgment collection procedures.
(Code 2014, § 30-50(intro. ¶); Ord. No. 560, § 6, 2-11-2002)
Sec. 30-101. Capias pro fine.
The municipal court judge may order a capias pro fine be issued for any
defendant failing to satisfy a judgment of the court according to the terms of
the judgment. The municipal court clerk shall ensure that each capias states
the amount of the judgment and sentence and commands a peace officer to bring
the defendant before the court or place the defendant in jail until the
defendant can be brought before the court.
(Code 2014, § 30-50(1); Ord. No. 560, § 6, 2-11-2002)
State law reference(s)—Capias or capias pro fine may be issued, Vernon's Ann.
C.C.P. art. 43.06.
Sec. 30-102. Commitment.
Defendants failing to satisfy any judgment may be committed as provided in
Vernon's Ann. C.C.P. art. 45.046, to satisfy the judgment. Any defendant
committed to jail serving less than eight consecutive hours in jail shall not
be given credit for time served. A defendant serving more than 24 consecutive
hours shall be given a $50.00 credit for each full consecutive 24 hours served
as credit.
(Code 2014, § 30-50(2); Ord. No. 560, § 6, 2-11-2002)
State law reference(s)—Commitment for failure to pay fine, Vernon's Ann. C.C.P.
art. 45.046; civil collection of fine, Vernon's Ann. C.C.P. art. 45.047;
discharge, failure to pay fine, Vernon's Ann. C.C.P. art. 45.048.
Sec. 30-103. Private collection contract.
At all times that the city council has authorized a private collection contract
with a private attorney or a public or private vendor for collection services
relating to fines, fees, restitution or other debts or costs, other than
forfeited bonds, the municipal court is authorized to collect an additional 30
percent on each such debt or account receivable that is more than 60 days past
due and has been collected as a result of the action of a duly authorized
contractor. The municipal court clerk shall report the 30 percent as payable to
the contractor. Should the contractor collect less than the full sum due from
the defendant, the municipal court clerk shall ensure that the payment is
distributed first in an amount sufficient to fully compensate the contractor
and then in equal shares to the comptroller and the city until the comptroller
is paid in full. If the city has entered into a contract under Vernon's Ann.
C.C.P. art. 103.031(a) and a person pays an amount that is less than the
aggregate total to be collected under Vernon's Ann. C.C.P. art. 103.031(a) and
(b), the allocation to the comptroller, the county or city, and the private
attorney or vendor shall be reduced proportionately.
(Code 2014, § 30-50(3); Ord. No. 560, § 6, 2-11-2002)
State law reference(s)—Collection contracts, Vernon's Ann. C.C.P. art.
103.0031.
Sec. 30-104. Civil assessment against property.
The municipal court judge may review judgments in which the defendant has
defaulted in payment, either in whole or part after sentencing, and may order
the fine and costs be collected by execution against the defaulting defendant's
property in the same manner as a judgment in a civil suit.
(Code 2014, § 30-50(4); Ord. No. 560, § 6, 2-11-2002)
State law reference(s)—Civil collection of fines, Vernon's Ann. C.C.P. art.
45.047.
Secs. 30-105—30-120. Reserved.
DIVISION 3. MISCELLANEOUS CHARGES AND COSTS
Sec. 30-121. Copying charges for public records.
The following service charge for copying governmental and public records shall
be as follows:
      (1)   For readily available information on standard size pages (up to 8½
inches by 14 inches), the copying charge shall be $0.25 per page.
      (2)   For information which is not readily available, the copying charge
shall be $0.15 per page plus actual labor costs incurred by the city in
providing the requested information.
      (3)   In addition, the city may also add any postal expenses which may be
necessary to transmit the reproduced documents to the requesting party.
      (4)   The city secretary shall establish the copying or reproduction
charge for nonstandard sized pages or documents (maps, books, etc.).
(Code 2014, § 30-51; Ord. No. 560, § 7, 2-11-2002)
State law reference(s)—Charges for public information provided by court clerk,
V.T.C.A., Government Code § 552.266.
Sec. 30-122. Jury duty pay.
The city shall pay each person appearing in response to a duly noticed jury
summons $6.00 for service in municipal court for each day or fraction of each
day they serve as a juror.
(Code 2014, § 30-52; Ord. No. 560, § 8, 2-11-2002)
State law reference(s)—Jury fee, Vernon's Ann. C.C.P. art. 102.004; jury pay
and expenses, Vernon's Ann. C.C.P. art. 104.001.
Sec. 30-123. Confidential payment and communication records.
The municipal court clerk shall separately file from the records of any case in
the municipal court any documents collected, assembled or otherwise maintained
containing a credit card, debit card, charge card, or other access device
number. The municipal court clerk shall redact the e-mail address from any
communications received via e-mail or shall maintain such documents separately
of the documents of the case. The e-mail address of any individual
communicating with the court shall not be disclosed to a member of the public
without express consent of the individual. Any requests for documents
containing this information shall be immediately referred to the city
attorney's office.
(Code 2014, § 30-53; Ord. No. 560, § 9, 2-11-2002)
State law reference(s)—Confidentiality of credit card numbers, etc., V.T.C.A.,
Government Code § 552.136; confidentiality of email addresses, V.T.C.A.,
Government Code § 552.137.
Secs. 30-124—30-140. Reserved.
DIVISION 4. STATE COURT COSTS
Sec. 30-141. Collection of court costs; deposit of costs; report.
   (a)   The municipal court clerk shall collect each and every court cost
statutorily mandated to be collected for the state. The municipal court clerk
shall keep a record of each court cost collected for the benefit of the state
and report the collection to the city treasurer including forwarding the monies
to be deposited with the city treasurer as required by internal policy.
   (b)   The city treasurer may deposit the money in an interest-bearing
account. The city treasurer shall keep records of the money collected and on
deposit in the treasury and shall remit the court costs collected for the
benefit of the state to the comptroller of public accounts not later than the
last day of the month following the calendar quarter in which the court costs
were collected.
   (c)   The municipal court clerk shall forward a completed quarterly report
form to be reviewed and confirmed by the city treasurer.
   (d)   The city treasurer shall ensure the accuracy of the report and, for
all fees collected for the consolidated court cost fund (CCC fund) to be
forwarded to the state, the city treasurer shall retain ten percent as a
service fee and deposit the retained sums to the general fund to offset
administrative expenses, save and except the ten percent shall not be retained
on sums not timely forwarded to the comptroller of public accounts.
(Code 2014, § 30-82; Ord. No. 560, § 3(part), 2-11-2002)
Secs. 30-142—30-160. Reserved.
DIVISION 5. WARRANT OF ARREST, FAILURE TO APPEAR FEES
State law reference(s)—Services of peace officers, Vernon's Ann. C.C.P. art.
102.011; special expense fee, Vernon's Ann. C.C.P. art. 45.203(c);
administrative fee, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 706.006.
Sec. 30-161. Warrant of arrest fee.
The municipal court clerk shall collect a warrant fee of $50.00 from any
defendant upon whom a peace officer executed a warrant issued by the municipal
court at the time of conviction. For arrests made by a state trooper, the
municipal court clerk shall report $10.00 as payable to the comptroller. Law
enforcement agencies other than state troopers and city police officers
executing a warrant must submit a request for payment within 15 days of the
conviction in order to be paid the warrant fee. If demand is not made within 15
days or a city police officer executed the warrant, the municipal court clerk
shall report the warrant fees collected as payable to the city police
department. The city shall refund the fees in cases where the defendant pleas
and demonstrates within 30 days of payment of such fee that the court failed to
give the person proper notice.
(Code 2014, § 30-108(a); Ord. No. 560, § 3(part), 2-11-2002)
State law reference(s)—Services of law enforcement agency for executing or
processing an issued arrest warrant, Vernon's Ann. C.C.P. art. 102.011
Sec. 30-162. Failure to appear fees.
The municipal court clerk shall collect a special expense of $25.00 for the
issuance and service or a warrant of arrest from each defendant served with a
warrant for failure to appear or violation of a promise to appear, V.T.C.A.,
Penal Code § 38.01 or V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 543.009. The municipal
court clerk shall report each special expense collected to the city treasurer
for deposit into the general funds of the city.
(Code 2014, § 30-108(b)(1); Ord. No. 560, § 3(part), 2-11-2002)
State law reference(s)—Special expense fee, Vernon's Ann. C.C.P. art. 45.203
(c).
Sec. 30-163. Contract with the state department of public safety.
At all times that the city has a contract with the state department of public
safety to deny renewal of licenses for individuals failing to appear at court
as directed, the municipal court clerk shall collect an additional $30.00
administrative fee at the time of the following:
      (1)   The court enters judgment on the underlying offense reported for
which the failure to appear was submitted;
      (2)   The underlying offense is dismissed; or
      (3)   Bond or other security is posted to reinstate the charge for which
the warrant was issued.
Distribution of the funds shall be as provided by agreement with the state
department of public safety. The municipal court clerk shall maintain a copy of
the agreement and report each failure to appear fee collected as well as the
distribution of the fee to the city treasurer. Should a defendant fail to pay
the $30.00 administrative fee as required, the municipal court clerk shall
report such failure to the state department of public safety and request the
department deny renewal of the defendant's license.
(Code 2014, § 30-108(b)(2); Ord. No. 560, § 3(part), 2-11-2002)
State law reference(s)—Administrative fee. V.T.C.A., Transportation Code §
706.006.
Sec. 30-164. Establishment of one-time payment fee.
   (a)   Each defendant being permitted to make payments on any part of a fine,
court cost or restitution on or after the 31st day after the date on which a
judgment is entered, including deferred adjudication and deferred disposition,
shall pay a fee of $25.00 on or before the 31st day after the judgment is
entered assessing the fine, court costs, or restitution.
   (b)   The municipal court clerk shall keep separate records of the time
payment fees collected. Each month 50 percent of the time payment fees
collected shall be forwarded to the comptroller, 40 percent shall be deposited
in the general revenue account of the city, and ten percent shall be deposited
in the general fund of the city to be allocated to improving the efficiency of
the administration of justice in the city.
   (c)   No defendant shall be permitted more than 180 days to pay fines, fees,
costs, restitution or any other fees ordered to be paid in the judgment of the
court.
(Code 2014, § 30-108(c); Ord. No. 560, § 3(part), 2-11-2002)
State law reference(s)—Time payment fee, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code §
133.103.
Sec. 30-165. Notice to appear/arrest fee.
The municipal court clerk shall collect a $5.00 fee for services of peace
officer for issuing a written notice to appear in court or for making an arrest
without a warrant with each conviction. The fees shall be reported quarterly to
the comptroller of public accounts. For each citation submitted to the
municipal court by a state officer for which a conviction occurs, the municipal
court clerk shall report $1.00 of the arrest fee as payable to the comptroller
with the remaining $4.00 being reported as distributable to the city police
department. For any law enforcement agency other than the state trooper or a
city police officer submitting a citation to the municipal court for which a
conviction occurs, the municipal court shall hold the $5.00 arrest fee for 15
working days. Should the law enforcement agency fail to claim the arrest fee in
15 working days after the conviction, the municipal court clerk shall report
the arrest fee as payable to the city police department. For each citation that
the city police department issues a citation and a conviction occurs, the full
arrest fee shall be reported as payable to the city police department.
(Code 2014, § 30-108(d); Ord. No. 560, § 3(part), 2-11-2002)
State law reference(s)—Fees for arrest warrant, Vernon's Ann. C.C.P. art.
102.011.
Sec. 30-166. Dishonored check fee.
A service charge of $30.00 shall be assessed against any person who pays the
city with a check, draft or money order which is returned unpaid for lack of
sufficient funds or closed or nonexistent account.
(Code 2014, § 30-108(e); Ord. No. 560, § 3(part), 2-11-2002)
State law reference(s)—Check fees, Vernon's Ann. C.C.P. art. 102.007; check,
etc., processing fee, V.T.C.A., Business and Commerce Code § 3.506.
Sec. 30-167. Peace officer's time.
For any trial at which a peace officer is required to testify while off duty,
the municipal court clerk shall calculate the officers' overtime for time spent
testifying at trial and time spent traveling to or from home if the officer was
not at work that day or scheduled to be at work and add such costs as court
costs to be paid by the defendant.
(Code 2014, § 30-108(f); Ord. No. 560, § 3(part), 2-11-2002)
State law reference(s)—Fees for services of peace officers, Vernon's Ann.
C.C.P. art. 102.011.
Sec. 30-168. Jury fee.
The municipal court clerk shall collect a $3.00 fee from each defendant
requesting a jury and being convicted thereby or requesting a postponement or
accepting a conviction less than 24 hours before the time of trial.
(Code 2014, § 30-108(g); Ord. No. 560, § 3(part), 2-11-2002)
State law reference(s)—Jury fee, Vernon's Ann. C.C.P. art. 102.004.
Sec. 30-169. Rules of the road fee.
The municipal court clerk shall collect an additional $3.00 fee as court costs
for each defendant convicted of violating the rules of the road. The municipal
court clerk shall deposit the fee collected with the city treasurer. Fines and
fees collected for violations of the rules of the road shall be deposited to
the general fund of the city and utilized to construct and maintain roads,
bridges and culverts in the city and to enhance the enforcement of laws
regulating the use of highways.
(Code 2014, § 30-108(h); Ord. No. 560, § 3(part), 2-11-2002)
State law reference(s)—Disposition of certain fines, V.T.C.A., Transportation
Code § 542.402; misdemeanor court costs, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code §
542.403.
Secs. 30-170—30-190. Reserved.
DIVISION 6. ADMINISTRATIVE FEES WHEN CERTAIN
CHARGES ARE DISMISSED
Sec. 30-191. Vehicle inspection.
On the finding of the municipal court judge, having been presented credible
evidence, that a defendant remedied the failure to have a valid vehicle
inspection report not later than the 20th working day after the date of a
citation or before the defendant's first court appearance date, whichever is
later; and not later than the 40th working day after the applicable deadline
provided by V.T.C.A., Transportation Code ch. 548, V.T.C.A., Health and Safety
Code ch. 382 or the state department of highway safety administrative rules
regarding inspection requirements , the municipal court clerk shall collect a
$10.00 administrative fee from the defendant at the time of dismissal.
Inspections expired more than 40 days on the date of the citation shall not be
dismissible on proof of correction.
(Code 2014, § 30-108(i)(1); Ord. No. 560, § 3(part), 2-11-2002)
State law reference(s)—Dismissal of charge fee, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code §
548.605(b)(1).
Sec. 30-192. Vehicle registration.
On the finding of the municipal court judge, having been presented credible
evidence, that a defendant remedied the failure to register the motor vehicle
alleged in the offense not more than ten working days from the date of the
offense and within the discretion of the judge the court grants the request to
dismiss, the municipal court clerk shall collect a $10.00 administrative fee
from the defendant at the time of dismissal. Vehicle registration corrected
more than ten working days after the date of the citation shall not be
dismissible on proof of correction.
(Code 2014, § 30-108(i)(2); Ord. No. 560, § 3(part), 2-11-2002)
State law reference(s)—Expired license plate, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code §
502.407.
Sec. 30-193. Proof of driver's license.
On the finding of the municipal court judge, having been presented credible
evidence, that a defendant remedied the expired driver's license within 20
working days or before the defendant's first court appearance date, whichever
is later and within the discretion of the judge, the court may grant the
request to dismiss. The judge may assess the defendant an administrative fee of
$20.00 and the municipal court clerk shall collect such fee from the defendant
at the time of dismissal.
(Code 2014, § 30-108(i)(3); Ord. No. 560, § 3(part), 2-11-2002)
State law reference(s)—Dismissal of charge of expired license, V.T.C.A.,
Transportation Code § 521.026.
Sec. 30-194. Deferred disposition.
If a defendant pleads no contest or guilty and requests a driving course or
motorcycle operator training and safety program as provided in Vernon's Ann.
C.C.P. art. 45.0511, the judge shall require the defendant to successfully
complete the applicable course. Upon granting such request, the municipal court
clerk shall collect, in addition to the other court costs and fees authorized
in state law, an administrative fee of $10.00 to be distributed to the city
treasurer for deposit in the general fund of the city.
State law reference(s)—Driving safety course or motorcycle course, Vernon's
Ann. C.C.P. art. 45.0511
(Code 2014, § 30-108(i)(4); Ord. No. 560, § 3(part), 2-11-2002)
Secs. 30-195—30-210. Reserved.
DIVISION 7. FUNDS
Subdivision I. In General
Sec. 30-211. Court costs.
In addition to the court costs mandated to be collected under state statute for
the state and remitted to the comptroller as court costs and as set out in
sections
30-161 and
30-162, the court costs in this subdivision shall be collected for each
conviction as provided herein.
(Code 2014, § 30-130; Ord. No. 560, § 4(part), 2-11-2002)
Secs. 30-212—30-230. Reserved.
Subdivision II. Child Safety Fund
State law reference(s)—Child safety fund, Vernon's Ann. C.C.P. art. 102.014.
Sec. 30-231. Fees; creation of fund.
There is hereby created a "Child Safety Fund" (the "CS Fund") which shall be
maintained and reported as a separate fund of the city. The CS Fund may be
maintained in an interest bearing account and may be maintained in the general
revenue account.
(Code 2014, § 30-159(d); Ord. No. 560, § 4(a), 2-11-2002)
Sec. 30-232. School crossing fee.
Each defendant convicted of violating any provisions of the Rules of the Road,
V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 541.001 et seq., , within a school crossing
zone or convicted for passing a school bus, in violation of V.T.C.A.,
Transportation Code § 545.066, shall pay an additional $25.00 taxable as court
costs.
(Code 2014, § 30-159(a); Ord. No. 560, § 4(a), 2-11-2002)
State law reference(s)—Authority for additional court cost, Vernon's Ann.
C.C.P. art. 102.014(c).
Sec. 30-233. Failure to attend school fee.
Each defendant convicted of violating V.T.C.A., Education Code § 25.093, Parent
Contributing to Nonattendance, shall pay an additional $20.00 taxable as court
costs.
(Code 2014, § 30-159(b); Ord. No. 560, § 4(a), 2-11-2002)
State law reference(s)—Authority for additional court cost, Vernon's Ann.
C.C.P. art. 102.014(d).
Sec. 30-234. Collection and deposit.
The municipal court clerk shall collect such court costs, including the school
crossing fee and pay such court costs to the city treasurer for all offenses
governed by this section. For all fines collected pursuant to V.T.C.A.,
Education Code § 25.093, Thwarting Compulsory Attendance Parent Contributing to
Nonattendance, the municipal court clerk shall report 50 percent of the fine to
be deposited to the credit of the operating fund of the school district in
which the child attends or to the juvenile justice alternative education
program, if the child has been ordered to attend such a program. The remaining
50 percent of the fine collected under V.T.C.A., Education Code § 25.093 shall
be reported as payable to the general fund of the city. The city treasurer
shall deposit the $25.00 school crossing fee and the $20.00 parent contributing
to nonattendance fee portion of such court costs into the "Child Safety Fund."
The city treasurer shall quarterly forward 50 percent of the fine collected
under V.T.C.A., Education Code § 25.093 payable to the school district which
the convicted children attend or, if the children were sentenced to a juvenile
justice alternative education program, the city treasurer shall forward 50
percent to the program. The remaining 50 percent shall be deposited to the
general fund of the city.
(Code 2014, § 30-159(c); Ord. No. 560, § 4(a), 2-11-2002)
State law reference(s)—Use of funds, Vernon's Ann. C.C.P. art. 102.014(g).
Sec. 30-235. Designated use of the funds and administration.
All school crossing fees and failure to attend school fees collected shall be
deposited in the child safety fund which shall be administered by the city
council. No expenditures or withdrawals shall be made from the fund except to
finance eligible items listed in Vernon's Ann. C.C.P. art. 102.014(g), and as
authorized by a majority vote of the city council. On the finding of the city
council that an expenditure is authorized, funds may be removed from the child
safety fund solely to be used to improve child safety, including:
      (1)   School crossing guard program; if one is established all money must
first fund this program; and
      (2)   Programs designed to enhance child safety, health, or nutrition,
including child abuse prevention and intervention and drug and alcohol abuse
prevention.
(Code 2014, § 30-159(e); Ord. No. 560, § 4(a), 2-11-2002)
Secs. 30-236—30-250. Reserved.
Subdivision III. Municipal Court Security Fund
State law reference(s)—Municipal court security fund, Vernon's Ann. C.C.P. art.
102.017.
Sec. 30-251. Creation of fund.
There is hereby created a municipal court building security fund (the "security
fund") which shall be maintained and reported as a separate fund of the city.
(Code 2014, § 30-187(c); Ord. No. 560, § 4(b), 2-11-2002)
Sec. 30-252. Fees; collection.
   (a)   A defendant convicted of a misdemeanor offense in a municipal court
shall pay a $3.00 security fee as a cost of court.
   (b)   The municipal court clerk shall collect such court costs, including
the security fee, and pay such court costs to the city treasurer.
   (c)   The city treasurer shall deposit the $3.00 security fee portion of
such court costs into the municipal court building security fund.
(Code 2014, § 30-187(a), (b); Ord. No. 560, § 4(b), 2-11-2002)
Sec. 30-253. Designated use of the fund and administration.
All security fees collected shall be deposited in the fund which shall be
administered by the city council. No expenditures or withdrawals shall be made
from the fund except to finance eligible items listed in Vernon's Ann. C.C.P.
art. 102.017(d), and as authorized by a majority vote of the city council. On
the finding of the city council that an expenditure is authorized, funds may be
removed from the security fund solely to be used to finance items to be used
for the purpose providing security personnel, services and items related to
buildings that house the operations of the municipal court of the city,
including:
      (1)   The purchase or repair of X-ray machines and conveying systems;
      (2)   Handheld metal detectors;
      (3)   Walk-through metal detectors;
      (4)   Identification cards and systems;
      (5)   Electronic locking and surveillance equipment;
      (6)   Video teleconferencing systems;
      (7)   Signage;
      (8)   Confiscated weapons inventory and tracking systems;
      (9)   Locks, chains, alarms or similar security devices;
      (10)   The purchase or repair of bullet-proof glass;
      (11)   Continuing education on security issues for court personnel and
security personnel; and
      (12)   Bailiffs, deputy sheriffs, deputy constables or contract security
personnel during times when they are providing appropriate security services;
Warrant officers and related equipment.
(Code 2014, § 30-187(d); Ord. No. 560, § 4(b), 2-11-2002)
State law reference(s)—Similar provision, Vernon's Ann. C.C.P. art. 102.017(d-
1).

Subdivision IV. Seat Belt Fund

Chapter 32 PARKS AND RECREATION
State law reference(s)—Municipal parks and other recreational and cultural
activities, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code ch. 306 et seq., municipal bands,
V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 308.001 et seq.; cultural resources,
V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 315.001 et seq.
ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL
Secs. 32-1—32-30. Reserved.
ARTICLE II. PARKS
DIVISION 1. GENERALLY
Secs. 32-31—32-66. Reserved.
DIVISION 2. PARK HOURS
Sec. 32-67. Hours of operation.
   (a)   Except as provided in subsection (b), the city's parks shall be open
to the public during the hours of 6 a.m. to 10 p.m.
   (b)   During the summer season (July 1st through September 30th), city parks
shall be open to the public during the hours of 6:00 a.m. to 12:00 a.m.
(midnight).
   (c)   When facilities at a city park are rented, the city manager may extend
the closing time for guests of the rented facility to 12 a.m. midnight,
regardless of season.
   (d)   Organized activities at recreation facilities may extend beyond
closing time, but only until the conclusion of the planned recreational
activity.
   (e)   It shall be an affirmative defense to prosecution that a violator has
permission from the city manager to be at a city park outside the hours of
operation.
(Code 2014, § 32-67; Ord. No. 373, § 1, 3-10-1997; Ord. No. 797A, § 1, 12-12-
2022; Ord. No. 884, § 1, 7-14-2025)
Sec. 32-68. Violation.
Any person violating the provisions of this division shall be deemed guilty of
a misdemeanor and upon conviction shall be fined as provided in section
1-16.
(Code 2014, § 32-68; Ord. No. 373, § 2, 3-10-1997)
Sec. 32-69. Compliance.
The city may also file in the appropriate court of law a suit for injunction
and may enjoin the use of the streets and alleys of said city park until the
provisions of this division have been complied with.
(Code 2014, § 32-69; Ord. No. 373, § 3, 3-10-1997)
Secs. 32-70—32-98. Reserved.
DIVISION 3. LAKE MADISON AND MARIAN ANDERSON PARKS
Sec. 32-99. Rules and regulations.
The following rules and regulation shall be in effect to the users of Lake
Madison Park and Marian Anderson Park:
      (1)   Speed limit 15 mph.
      (2)   No dumping of any kind.
      (3)   No swimming.
      (4)   No wake zone.
      (5)   No alcohol or drugs.
      (6)   No skiing.
      (7)   No horses.
      (8)   No overnight camping.
      (9)   No motor vehicles on trails.
(Code 2014, § 32-99; Ord. of 5-14-2007, § 1; Ord. No. 814, § 1, 10-9-2018)
Sec. 32-100. Violation.
Lake Madison is designated a no wake zone. Watercraft in park must be operated
at a speed of less than five miles per hour (mph), or in a manner that does not
cause a wake. Hydroplanes, jet boats, Jet Skis, Sea-Doos, Wave Runners or other
watercraft which are powered by a motor using the principle of water coming
through tubes are prohibited. Watercrafts which are powered by a motor using
the principle of water coming through tubes are prohibited. Watercraft must be
propelled by an external propeller
(Code 2014, § 32-100; Ord. of 5-14-2007, § 5; Ord. No. 814, § 2, 10-9-2018)
Sec. 32-101. Applicable time period.
This division applies only to offenses committed on or after the effective date
of the ordinance from which this division is derived, and an action for an
offense committed before the effective date of the ordinance from which this
division is derived is governed by the ordinance existing and in effect at that
time, which ordinance is to be continued in effect for this purpose as if the
ordinance were not in force.
(Ord. No. 814, § 3, 10-9-2018)
Sec. 32-102. Penalty.
Any person violating any of the provisions of this division shall be deemed
guilty of a Class C misdemeanor, and upon conviction thereof shall be fined in
any sum not more than $500.00. Each violation under this division shall
constitute a separate offense.
(Ord. No. 814, § 6, 10-9-2018)
Chapter 34 SIGNS
State law reference(s)—Regulation of signs, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code §
216.001 et seq.
ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL
Sec. 34-1. Purpose and scope.
The purpose of this chapter is to provide minimum standards to safeguard life,
health, property, and public welfare by regulating and controlling the quality
of materials, construction, illumination, installation, and maintenance of all
signs and sign structures, to avoid unusual clutter, to preserve and improve
the appearance of the community, and to avoid traffic problems caused by
distracting signs or structures. This chapter relates to all outdoor signs in
the city and its extraterritorial jurisdiction. 
(Code 2014, § 34-1; Ord. No. 642, § 1-2, 7-9-2007)
State law reference(s)—Authority to regulate signs, V.T.C.A., Local Government
Code § 216.001.
Sec. 34-2. Definitions.
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have
the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly
indicates a different meaning:
   Billboard means a sign advertising goods or services not available on the
premises where the sign is located. Billboards are not permitted anywhere in
the city.
   Building code means the latest edition of the International Building Code
published by the International Code Council.
   Building official means the administrative officer charged with enforcement
of the building code, zoning chapter, and this chapter, and/or his agents or
inspector acting on his behalf.
   Building plot means a separately owned piece of property (under one
ownership) upon which a building may be situated and which may be subdivided
only by sale by approved plat.
   District andzoning district mean those districts established by the zoning
chapter and zoning map regulating the uses of land in each district.
   Electric sign means a sign containing electric wiring which has characters,
letters, figures, designs, faces, backgrounds, or outlines illuminated by
incandescent or fluorescent lamps or luminous tubes as part of the sign proper.
   Home occupation means an enterprise which may be conducted in a residential
district under the provisions of the zoning chapter.
   Noncombustible means incapable of supporting progressive combustion. The
term "noncombustible" does not include fire-retardant-treated wood.
   Nonconforming use means a sign use, land use, or a structure which existed
prior to the passage of any regulation prohibiting it, or which existed prior
to annexation.
   Off-premises sign means a sign displaying advertising copy that pertains to
a business, person, organization, activity, event, place, service, or product
not principally located or primarily manufactured or sold on the premises on
which the sign is located. Off-premises commercial signs are prohibited in the
city.
   On-premises sign means a freestanding sign identifying or advertising a
business, person, or activity, and installed and maintained on the same
premises as the business, person, or activity.
   Ordinary minor repairs means replacement of faces, repainting, copy change
or change of panels obviously designed to be readily replaceable without
structural alteration.
   Outdoor advertising display means any mark, copy, structure, advice or
merchandise whose principal purpose in use is to attract the public's
attention.
   Planning and zoning commission means an appointed board whose purpose is to
hear appeals from decisions of the building official in enforcement of the
zoning chapter, building code, and this chapter, to authorize extension of
nonconforming uses or require their abatement, or to grant variances.
   Public easement means any easement upon which the general public has the
right of access and does not include easements for special purposes such as
utilities and drainage.
   Public street means any public right-of-way from property line to property
line and not limited only to the main traveled way.
   Sign means and includes every sign billboard, ground sign, roof sign, wall
sign, projection sign, temporary sign, portable sign, and marquee, and shall
include any announcement, declaration, demonstration, display illustration or
insignia used to advertise or promote the interests of any person or
corporation when the same is placed out-of-doors in view of the general public.
   Spectacular sign means an outdoor advertising display with flashing or
perceptible moving parts.
   Temporary sign (for sale sign) means a sign pertaining to the sale or lease
of rental property, located on the property offered and whose term of use
expires upon the sale or lease of the property.
   Traffic directions sign means a sign required for the sole purpose of
enhancing traffic flow.
(Code 2014, § 34-2; Ord. No. 642, § 1-3, 7-9-2007)
State law reference(s)—Definitions, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 216.002.
Secs. 34-3—34-22. Reserved.
ARTICLE II. ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT
DIVISION 1. GENERALLY
Sec. 34-23. Appeals.
   (a)   Any person aggrieved by any decision or order of the building official
in the enforcement of this chapter may appeal to the board of adjustments and
appeals by filing a written notice of appeal with the city manager within 30
days. An appeal stays the action unless there exists imminent peril to life or
property.
   (b)   Appeals to the building code and zoning chapter may be made in a
similar fashion.
(Code 2014, § 34-23; Ord. No. 642, § 1-11, 7-9-2007)
Sec. 34-24. Violations and penalties.
   (a)   When a violation is reported or found, the owner and/or manager of the
sign and of the property will be notified by the building official and required
to correct the situation within a stated reasonable time. The time allowed will
be based upon that work, if any, which must be done to correct the violation.
   (b)   If the corrections are made within the time stated, no charges will be
filed other than one charge of failure to obtain a building permit. Otherwise,
charges will be filed each following day until such time as the problem is
corrected or all of the cases filed have been dismissed by the municipal court.
   (c)   Conviction of violation of this article is punishable by a fine as
provided in section
1-16 for each day that the violation is allowed to continue. Both the owner and
operator of the sign and the owner of the property are charged with separate
violations each day.
(Code 2014, § 34-24; Ord. No. 642, § 1-12, 7-9-2007)
Secs. 34-25—34-51. Reserved.
DIVISION 2. PERMIT
Sec. 34-52. General permitting standards; installation of signs.
   (a)   Permits required; application; fee.
      (1)   No sign shall hereafter be erected, relocated, constructed, altered
or renewed, except as provided by this division and a permit for the same has
been issued by the building official.
      (2)   Application for a building permit shall be made in writing upon
forms furnished by the building official. Such application shall contain the
location by street and number of the proposed sign as well as the name and
address of the owner and the sign contractor or erector. Also the application
must state whether or not there is any electrical permit to be issued, the
zoning classification and the value of the sign and work to be done. The
building official must require the filing of plans or other pertinent
information such as the method of construction, the method of installation or
support, etc.
      (3)   [See
Appendix B, Fee Schedule, for details on fees.]
      (4)   Moving of building or structures. For the moving of any building or
structure, the fee shall be $100.00.
      (5)   Demolition of building or structures. For the demolition of any
building or structure, the fee shall be $50.00.
      (6)   Where work for which a permit is required by this Code is started
or proceeded with prior to obtaining said permit, the fees herein specified
shall be doubled, but the payment of such double fee shall not relieve any
persons from fully complying with the requirements of this Code in the
execution of the work nor from any other penalties prescribed herein.
      (7)   Plan fees. Site plan fee will be $100.00 which covers staff time
and other interoffice expenses.
   (b)   Exemptions.
      (1)   A permit is not required for a ground temporary "for sale" or "for
rent" sign which advertises either the sale or rental of the premises upon
which it is maintained and does not exceed eight square feet of display surface
in residential districts and 15 square feet in business districts. This
exemption shall apply only to the requirements of the permit and shall not be
construed as relieving the owner of the sign from the responsibility for its
erection and maintenance in a safe condition.
      (2)   No permit shall be required to change the advertising copy or
message on a painted, printed or changeable-letter sign. Painting, repainting,
cleaning or repair maintenance shall not be considered an erection or
alteration which requires a permit unless a structural change is made.
      (3)   No permit will be required for portable signs which are less than
ten square feet in area and extend no higher than 48 inches above the sidewalk
or curb level.
      (4)   No separate sign permit will be required for garage or yard sales
permitted, as provided in section
2-400 et seq., but each sign must have a name, date and address on the sign and
such signs shall be removed within 24 hours after the sale.
      (5)   Handbills and circulars are prohibited except that hand delivery to
individual persons is allowed.
      (6)   No permit is required for political signs but they may be erected
on any private property, provided that such signs comply with other applicable
requirements of this division and provided further that the owner or occupant
of the property on which the sign is displayed shall not erect or cause to be
erected special purpose political signs until 90 days prior to any primary or
general election; and shall remove the signs within ten days after the general
or runoff elections to which a sign pertains or after the termination of a
person's candidacy, whichever occurs first.
(Code 2014, § 34-52; Ord. No. 642, § 1-4(a), (b), 7-9-2007; Ord. No. 642A, 8-
11-2008; Ord. No. 711, 9-17-2012; Ord. No. 642B, § 1-4, 1-14-2013; Ord. No.
809, § 5, 7-9-2018)
State law reference(s)—Political signs, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code §
216.903.
Sec. 34-53. Alterations.
A sign which was erected before the adoption of the ordinance from which this
division is derived shall not be rebuilt, relocated, nor altered without
conforming to the requirements of this division.
(Code 2014, § 34-53; Ord. No. 642, § 1-4(c), 7-9-2007; Ord. No. 642A, 8-11-
2008)
Sec. 34-54. Maintenance.
The building official shall require the proper maintenance of all signs. All
signs together with all of their supports, braces, guys, and anchors shall be
kept in repair and in proper state of preservation. The display surfaces of all
signs shall be kept neatly painted or posted at all times. The building
official may order the removal of any sign that is not maintained.
(Code 2014, § 34-54; Ord. No. 642, § 1-4(d), 7-9-2007; Ord. No. 642A, 8-11-
2008)
Sec. 34-55. Regulations by type of sign.
Ground signs are limited in area to one square foot of sign for each two feet
of frontage on public streets, with a maximum of 100 square feet of area for
any sign related to one business entity.
(Code 2014, § 34-55; Ord. No. 642, § 1-5, 7-9-2007; Ord. No. 642B, § 1-5, 1-14-
2013)
Secs. 34-56—34-83. Reserved.
DIVISION 3. NONCONFORMITIES AND VARIANCES
Sec. 34-84. Nonconforming uses.
   (a)   Signs which lawfully existed prior to the adoption of the ordinance
from which this division is derived may continue in use for the remainder of
their structurally useful economic life. They may not be structurally altered
or rebuilt unless the modifications result in conformity with the present
ordinances. Spectacular signs do not come under nonconforming use and must be
specially permitted if in existence at the time of adoption of the ordinance
from which this division is derived.
   (b)   The provisions for the extended use of nonconforming signs will
terminate when the business entity no longer exists at the location.
   (c)   Copy change, preventive maintenance or replacement of panels designed
to be readily changeable are not considered structural modifications.
(Code 2014, § 34-84; Ord. No. 642, § 1-6, 7-9-2007)
Sec. 34-85. Variances.
The board of adjustments and appeals has the power to grant variances to sign
or setback regulations with the approval of the city council where all three of
the following criteria are proven by the applicant:
      (1)   Unique and special circumstances exist on the land in question and
are found on other lands in the districts.
      (2)   Hardship would result from the action of the city. Hardship in
general means that all lawful economic use of land would be lost if the
regulation were applied, and cannot be self-created by the present or prior
owners. It does not include loss of anticipated revenue which might be or is
being realized by violation of this division or the comparative cost of
compliance versus noncompliance.
      (3)   The public interest will not be adversely affected by the variance
sought.
(Code 2014, § 34-85; Ord. No. 642, § 1-7, 7-9-2007)
Sec. 34-86. Relation to electrical code.
   (a)   Electrically lighted or activated signs require no inspection at the
point of manufacture or for repairs or alterations to internal wiring of the
sign itself. However, any sign found to be internally unsafe will be required
to be corrected.
   (b)   All electrical supply to the point of connection at the sign must be
installed by a licensed electrician and must be in compliance with the
technical codes adopted by the city.
(Code 2014, § 34-86; Ord. No. 642, § 1-8, 7-9-2007)
Secs. 34-87—34-115. Reserved.
ARTICLE III. REGULATIONS
Sec. 34-116. Regulations by type of sign.
   (a)   Ground signs.
      (1)   Ground signs shall not be placed so that any part of the sign is
nearer to the back of curb (or pavement edge) than eight feet, and no part of
the sign may extend into the right-of-way.
      (2)   Signs erected at the intersection of two streets shall not create a
traffic hazard by obstructing the view of drivers. The guidelines would be to
have the sign seven feet above street level, or to be far enough from the
intersection of the streets that it did not obstruct the view of drivers.
      (3)   Ground signs are limited in area to one square foot of sign for
each two feet of frontage on public streets, with a maximum of 100 square feet
of area for any sign related to one business entity.
      (4)   In multiple business areas, such as shopping malls or strip centers
where a common sign base is used for several businesses, the aggregate sign
surface shall not exceed one square foot for each two feet of public street
frontage or 300 square feet, whichever is smaller.
      (5)   If ground signs are erected in a shopping mall or strip center that
are separate from the common sign discussed in subsection (a)(4) of this
section, the sign area shall be limited by the frontage of the business entity
erecting the separate sign.
      (6)   Ground signs are limited in height to 24 feet except along four-
lane divided, limited access highways where the limit is 48 feet in height.
   (b)   Roof signs.
      (1)   Roof signs are outdoor advertising displays erected, constructed,
or maintained above the roof of any building.
      (2)   Roof signs are not permitted in residential districts.
      (3)   Refer to the building code for complete construction details.
      (4)   A roof sign may not extend beyond the wall of the building. Roof
signs must be at least six feet above the roof deck to the bottom edge and must
have at least five feet horizontal distance supports.
      (5)   A roof sign may be located on the roof edge if it covers less than
50 percent of the edge upon which it faces.
      (6)   A roof sign must be entirely noncombustible and may not exceed 24
feet above the roof deck. A registered professional engineer's analysis of the
sign or roof structure may be required where it appears warranted.
   (c)   Wall signs.
      (1)   Wall signs are outdoor advertising displays attached or affixed to
the wall of any building, when such sign shall project not more than 12 inches
from the building.
      (2)   Wall signs are not permitted in single-family residential
districts.
      (3)   Refer to the building code for complete construction details.
      (4)   Wall signs must be constructed of noncombustible materials,
including the face, except where they are attached to a combustible wall
surface. In that case they may be faced with the same material with which the
wall is faced.
   (d)   Projection signs.
      (1)   Projection signs are outdoor advertising displays which are affixed
to any building wall or structure and extend beyond the building wall or
structure more than 12 inches.
      (2)   Projection signs are prohibited in all residential districts. A
projecting sign may not extend above the roofline in any district.
      (3)   Refer to the building code for complete construction details.
   (e)   Marquee signs.
      (1)   Marquee signs are prohibited in all residential districts.
      (2)   Refer to the building code for complete construction details.
      (3)   Marquee signs must be constructed entirely of metal or approved
plastic faces and must be at least eight feet above grade or sidewalk level and
not more than six feet above the marquee. They may not exceed eight feet in the
vertical dimension in any case.
   (f)   Portable signs.
      (1)   Portable signs are signs which are not attached to the ground or to
a structure and are readily moveable.
      (2)   Portable signs are permitted only in business districts.
      (3)   Portable signs shall not be placed so that any part is nearer to a
street right-of-way than eight feet back of curb and shall not be placed in a
triangle formed by the intersection of two rights-of-way and line joining
points 24 feet back from the point of intersection.
      (4)   Portable signs shall not have flashing lights nor shall any red or
green light bulbs be allowed on portable signs located closer than 20 feet to
curbline or pavement edge.
   (g)   Spectacular signs. Spectacular signs are prohibited in all districts.
   (h)   Signs for sexual businesses. It shall be unlawful for the owner or
operator of any enterprise, or any other person to erect, construct or maintain
any sign for the enterprise other than one attached sign. In addition, this one
attached sign shall not contain any flashing lights or moving parts, shall be
rectangular in shape and shall not exceed 50 square feet in area. It shall
contain no photographs, silhouettes, drawings or pictorial representations of
any manner and shall not advertise either graphically or verbally, either by
explicit or literal expression, connotation or implied reference, any specified
sexual activities or specified anatomical areas. The sign may contain only the
name of the enterprise and/or one or more of the following phrases: "adult
bookstore," "adult movie theater," "adult lounge, parlor or cabaret," "adult
novelties," "adult entertainment," "adult modeling studio," "adult video."
   (i)   Off-premises directional signage. Off-premises directional signage for
businesses or industries may be requested for those businesses or industries
that have a high volume of traffic that is generated from delivery vehicles,
tourist traffic or a combination thereof. A request for directional signage
shall be made in writing to the building official. Final consideration to allow
the directional signage at the proposed location will be addressed by the city
council.
   (j)   Billboards. Billboards are not permitted anywhere in the city.
   (k)   Off-premises commercial signs. Off-premises commercial signs are
prohibited in the city.
   (l)   Off-premises temporary signs. All off-premises temporary signs shall
conform to the following:
      (1)   Location. Off-premises temporary advertising signs shall be
permitted only in those areas adjacent to thoroughfares described in subsection
(l)(2) of this section, and, provided that, the property is zoned Retail
District (R), Office District (O), General Business District (GB) or Commercial
Services District (CS) pursuant to the terms of chapter 46.
      (2)   Placement of off-premises advertising signs in the Retail District
(R), Office District (O), General Business District (GB) or Commercial Services
District (CS) in any location other than within the areas adjacent to
thoroughfares below is prohibited.
         a.   Property designated as "Area A": U.S. Highway 75 from the
corporate limits on the south to the corporate limits on the north.
         b.   Property designated as "Area B": U.S. Highway 21 from the
corporate limits on the east to the corporate limits on the west.
         c.   Property designated as "Area C": U.S. Highway 90 from the
corporate limits on the south to the corporate limits on the north.
      (3)   All off-premises temporary signs shall be approved or disapproved
by the building official contingent on length of time to display sign, where
sign will be located and payment of a permit fee of $5.0. A fine of $10.00 will
be assessed per sign not removed by date of the end of the permit. The maximum
number of off-premises temporary signs is three.
(Code 2014, § 34-116; Ord. No. 642, §§ 1-3, 1-9, 7-9-2007; Ord. No. 813, § 1,
10-9-2018)
Sec. 34-117. General permitting standards for garage sales signs.
A permit will be required for garage sales. Definitions pertaining to garage
sales can be found in article X of chapter 2. Each sign must have a name, date
and address on the sign and such signs shall be removed within 24 hours after
the sale.
(Ord. No. 813, § 2, 10-9-2018)
Sec. 34-118. Regulations by zoning districts.
   (a)   Single-family residential districts.
      (1)   Temporary "for sale" or "for rent" signs up to eight square feet in
area may be placed on the premises advertised. No permit is required.
      (2)   Development ground signs up to 300 square feet may be permitted for
up to six months and extended to such time as the original developer's sales
are substantially complete.
      (3)   Spectacular signs are not permitted.
   (b)   Multifamily residential districts.
      (1)   Wall signs may be placed in multifamily districts.
      (2)   Spectacular signs are not permitted.
      (3)   Temporary "for sale" or "for rent" sign up to eight square feet in
area may be placed without permit or modification of use permit, but such signs
pertaining to the ongoing rental or lease of individual units are not
considered temporary signs in this context.
   (c)   Office, retail, commercial district.
      (1)   All signs except spectacular signs are permitted in the office,
retail, commercial district.
      (2)   Temporary "for sale" signs up to 15 square feet may be placed
without a permit. Signs may exceed the 15-foot limit if they meet all
requirements for permanent signs in the district and a permit is issued.
   (d)   Industrial district. All signs except spectacular signs are permitted
in industrial districts. Temporary "for sale" signs up to 15 square feet may be
placed without a permit. Signs in excess of 15 feet may be permitted if they
meet all requirements for permanent signs in the district and a permit is
issued.
   (e)   Signs within the extraterritorial jurisdiction. This article shall
apply to signs within the city's extraterritorial jurisdiction. Off-premises
commercial signs and billboards shall be prohibited in the extraterritorial
jurisdiction of the city. All signs which are in compliance with V.C.T.A.,
Transportation Code ch. 394 at the date of enactment of the ordinance from
which this article is derived shall be permitted in accordance with said
Transportation Code.
(Code 2014, § 34-117; Ord. No. 642, § 1-10, 7-9-2007)
Chapter 36 SOLID WASTE
ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL
Secs. 36-1—36-18. Reserved.
ARTICLE II. GARBAGE COLLECTION
Sec. 36-19. Definitions.
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have
the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly
indicates a different meaning:
   Garbage means all putrescible wastes, except sewage and body wastes, but
excluding recognized industrial byproducts, and includes all such substances
from all public and private establishments and from all residences.
   Refuse means and includes all nonputrescible wastes.
(Code 2014, § 36-19; Ord. No. 140, § 1, 9-10-1963)
Sec. 36-20. Garbage and refuse collection service.
No owner or lessee of any public or private premises shall permit to accumulate
upon his premises any garbage or refuse except in covered containers approved
by the city council. Such containers shall be as required in the franchise with
the collection service.
(Code 2014, § 36-20; Ord. No. 140, § 2, 9-10-1963)
Sec. 36-21. Collection of garbage and refuse.
   (a)   Placing of containers. No garbage or refuse shall be collected by any
collection service or authorized agency or person unless it is placed as
designated by the city council.
   (b)   Individual disposal. The disposal of garbage and refuse in any place
within the city limits or within 1,000 feet outside of the city limits, except
as provided in this article and the franchise adopted by the city, is
prohibited.
(Code 2014, § 36-21; Ord. No. 140, § 3, 9-10-1963)
Sec. 36-22. Dead animals.
All dead animals shall be disposed of at the expense of the owner or person
having same in his charge. Only animals which expire in the city limits shall
be disposed of at the city's landfill.
(Code 2014, § 36-22; Ord. No. 180, § 3, 7-16-1973)
Sec. 36-23. Other accumulations.
Heavy accumulations such as brick, broken concrete, lumber, ashes, clinkers,
cinders, dirt and plaster, sand and gravel, dead trees, other bulky and heavy
material, pieces of wood, barrels, crates, scraps of iron, wire, or other
metals shall be disposed of at the expense of the owner or person controlling
same under the direction of the superintendent of the garbage department.
(Code 2014, § 36-23; Ord. No. 180, § 4, 7-16-1973)
Sec. 36-24. Monthly garbage collection rates.
From and after March 1, 2012, the following monthly garbage collection rates
shall be charged by the city to all residents, businesses and other entities
with its boundaries for garbage collection services provided under contract
with the city, regardless of whether such services are used (see section
36-28):
      (1)   Pickup at the street at the prevailing rate.
      (2)   Pickup at the back door at the prevailing rate.
(Code 2014, § 36-24; Ord. No. 715, § 1, 2-13-2012)
Sec. 36-25. Prohibiting of usage from other services.
All city residents, businesses and other entities are prohibited from engaging
the services of or using any solid waste disposal services other than the
services other than the services provided under contract to the city. The city
is authorized to pursue all civil remedies to which it is entitled under
authority of statutes or other ordinances for any violation of this section.
(Code 2014, § 36-25; Ord. No. 715, § 2, 2-13-2012)
Sec. 36-26. Composite billing.
A composite billing presently used by the city to itemize the charges for water
and for sanitary sewer service shall include the garbage collection fee. The
total of such amounts shall be due and payable to the city on or before the
first day of the month following the month in which the services are rendered,
and shall be delinquent if not paid by that time.
(Code 2014, § 36-26; Ord. No. 312, § 3, 9-14-1992; Ord. No. 715, § 3, 2-13-
2012)
Sec. 36-27. Discontinuance of service.
The city shall have the right to discontinue water and sanitary sewer service,
as well as garbage collection service, to the premises of any person, business
or other entity who fails or refuses to make timely payment of water services,
sanitary sewer services, or garbage collection services. In the event such
services are discontinued by the city because of non-payment of such services,
such services shall not be restored until all delinquent charges have been
paid.
(Code 2014, § 36-27; Ord. No. 312, § 4, 9-14-1992; Ord. No. 715, § 4, 2-13-
2012)
Sec. 36-28. Reserved.
Editor's note(s)—Ord. No. 855, § 2(Exh. A), adopted Sep. 12, 2022, repealed §
36-28, which pertained to rate schedule and derived from Ord. No. 715, att. A,
adopted Feb. 13, 2012.
Chapter 38 STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND
OTHER PUBLIC PLACES
State law reference(s)—Authority of city to control streets and rights-of-way,
V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 311.001; authority of city to regulate and
remove obstructions and encroachments on streets and rights-of-way, V.T.C.A.,
Transportation Code § 311.001.
ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL
Secs. 38-1—38-40. Reserved.
ARTICLE II. STREETS
State law reference(s)—Obstructing highway or other way prohibited, V.T.C.A.,
Penal Code § 42.03; sidewalk cafes, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 316.0026;
use of streets for private purposes, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 316.020.
DIVISION 1. GENERALLY
Sec. 38-41. Obstructions and impediments.
It shall be unlawful for any person to obstruct or impede the ordinary use of
the streets and sidewalks of the city by assembling in a crowd thereon
(Code 2014, § 38-41; Ord. No. 145, § I, 8-14-1965)
State law reference(s)—Obstructing highway or other way, V.T.C.A., Penal Code §
42.03; sidewalk cafes, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 316.0026; use of streets
for private purposes, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 316.020; disorderly
assembly, riot, V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 42.02.
Sec. 38-42. Unlawful gatherings.
It shall be unlawful for persons to gather together in squads or crowds on the
sidewalks or in the streets or at street corners to the annoyance of the owners
or occupants of the premises abutting the same. Any person who shall violate
the provisions of this section, after being warned by a police officer or the
owner or occupant of such premises to remove, shall be subject to prosecution.
(Code 2014, § 38-42; Ord. No. 145, § II, 8-14-1965)
State law reference(s)—Obstructing highway or other way, V.T.C.A., Penal Code §
42.03; sidewalk cafes, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 316.0026; use of streets
for private purposes, V.T.C.A., Transportation Code § 316.020; disorderly
assembly, riot, V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 42.02.
Sec. 38-43. Violation.
Every person violating any provision of sections 38-41 and 38-42 shall, upon
conviction, be fined as provided in section
1-16.
(Code 2014, § 38-43; Ord. No. 145, § IV, 8-14-1965)
Secs. 38-44—38-61. Reserved.
DIVISION 2. STREETLIGHTS
Sec. 38-62. Fee for streetlight service.
The charge for streetlight services is on file in the city secretary's office
for residential customers and for commercial customers.
(Code 2014, § 38-62; Ord. No. 585, § 1, 1-14-2003)
Secs. 38-63—38-82. Reserved.
ARTICLE III. EXCAVATION
DIVISION 1. GENERALLY
Secs. 38-83—38-100. Reserved.
DIVISION 2. PERMIT
Sec. 38-101. Required.
It shall be unlawful for any person or corporation, other than city-owned
utilities, to make any excavation or openings in any street, alley, or public
highway of the city without first having obtained a permit.
(Code 2014, § 38-83; Ord. No. 326, § 1, 12-12-1994)
Sec. 38-102. Application.
The application for a permit to make any excavation or opening in any of the
streets, alleys, or public highways of the city shall be made to the building
inspector and state clearly the name of the street or highway in which it is
proposed to make such an opening; the exact location in said highway wherein it
is proposed to make such opening; the purpose of making the opening; and the
name of the person who proposes to make such excavation or opening.
(Code 2014, § 38-84; Ord. No. 326, § 2, 12-12-1994)
Sec. 38-103. Written bond.
The building inspector shall require the applicant to file a written bond in
the amount of $500.00 with two good and sufficient sureties, or to pay a cash
bond in the amount of $500.00, to cover such costs of repair to ensure that the
street shall be restored in as good a condition as it was before the excavation
or opening therein was made. The bond shall be approved by the building
inspector which shall be expressly conditioned as follows:
      (1)   All work done shall be done in a good and workmanlike manner.
      (2)   Such person shall at all times and in all respects strictly and
fully comply with all Charter provisions, ordinances of the city which have
been passed and which shall from time to time be passed that in any way pertain
to the work to be done by such person.
      (3)   The city shall be fully indemnified in full and held harmless from
any and all costs, expenses, or damage on account of any injury done to any
person or property in the prosecution of such work, or that may arise out of or
be occasioned by the performance of such work.
      (4)   he person shall, without any additional cost to the one for whom
the work is done, maintain all the structures, appurtenances, curbs, gutters,
streets or other concrete work so constructed, reconstructed or repaired for a
period of 24 months from the date of such construction, reconstruction or
repair to the satisfaction of the building inspector and shall perform any
additional work required by the building inspector within the 24-month period
to reconstruct or repair the work performed upon 30 days' written notice from
the building inspector. The opinion and request of the building inspector shall
be final and binding on the parties in all respects.
      (5)   Upon the failure of the person so requested to repair or
reconstruct the work as requested by the building inspector to repair, replace
or reconstruct the same, or make a diligent attempt to do so, within 30 days of
the written notice to do the same, the building inspector shall accept bids
from three bonded cement contractors and award the work to the lowest bidder.
Upon acceptance of the work by the building inspector, the bonding company
shall be liable for the payment of the costs of such work. The opinion of the
building inspector as to the necessity of accepting bids and awarding the work
to another contractor pursuant to this subsection shall be final and binding on
the parties in all respects.
      (6)   If the bond shall be decreased on account of any recovery arising
out of the violation of any condition of the same, the city council shall
require upon notice to it that an additional amount be deposited so that the
unexhausted amount of the bond at all times is $500.00.
      (7)   The bonding company shall be liable for cleanup costs of the site
should the person doing the work fail to do the same.
(Code 2014, § 38-85; Ord. No. 326, § 3, 12-12-1994)
Sec. 38-104. Issuance.
When the cash bond required in section
38-103 shall have been accepted by the building inspector, the building
inspector shall then issue a permit for the excavation or opening named in the
application, and the applicant may then proceed with the work in the exact
location named in his application, and in no other place.
(Code 2014, § 38-86; Ord. No. 326, § 4, 12-12-1994)
Sec. 38-105. Supervision of excavation activities.
All the work of excavating or making any character of opening in any of the
streets, alleys, or public highways of the city shall at all times be under the
supervision of the building inspector; and the person doing such work shall do
the same in the manner directed by him to the end that the streets and highways
of the city shall not be unduly disturbed and traffic thereon obstructed.
(Code 2014, § 38-87; Ord. No. 326, § 5, 12-12-1994)
Sec. 38-106. Backfill of excavation.
After the excavation or opening shall have been made, the person or corporation
so making it shall backfill the excavation with such materials and in such
manner as may be required by the building inspector, and leave the street or
highway in at least the same condition as it was before the opening therein was
made.
(Code 2014, § 38-88; Ord. No. 326, § 6, 12-12-1994)
Sec. 38-107. Compliance.
The conditions of the bond required by section
38-103 shall not be considered to have been complied with until the building
inspector shall have accepted the street or highway as being in good condition.
(Code 2014, § 38-89; Ord. No. 326, § 7, 12-12-1994)
Sec. 38-108. Violation.
Any person or corporation who violates any of the provisions of this article or
fails to comply therewith or with any of the requirements thereof, shall be
guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be liable to a fine of not more than $200.00.
(Code 2014, § 38-90; Ord. No. 326, § 9, 12-12-1994)
Secs. 38-109—38-130. Reserved.
ARTICLE IV. PUBLIC PLACES
DIVISION 1. GENERALLY
Secs. 38-131—38-150. Reserved.
DIVISION 2. PUBLIC BUILDINGS
Sec. 38-151. Smoking prohibited in certain areas.
   (a)   Reasonably sized signs shall be placed at all entrances to the city
municipal building and all places smoking is prohibited stating "No
Smoking—City of Madisonville Ordinance." The universal emblem for "No Smoking"
will be used in addition to the wording.
   (b)   The areas which are exempt from the "No Smoking" restrictions are the
shop area, along with the offices located in the shop area, the areas occupied
and designated as the city volunteer fire department meeting room and garage
area, and the office of the city manager.
   (c)   A person commits an offense if the person smokes or possesses a
burning tobacco product or other plant product or operates an e-cigarette in
the "No Smoking" areas of the municipal building of the city.
(Code 2014, §§ 38-130, 38-131(a); Ord. No. 288-A, § 1, 8-14-1989; Ord. No.
288B, 6-10-1991)
State law reference(s)—Smoking prohibited in certain places, V.T.C.A., Penal
Code § 48.01.
Sec. 38-152. Violation of division.
Any person, agent or employee who violates any of the provisions of division
shall be fined and amount as provided in section
1-16. Each day that a violation is permitted to exist shall constitute a
separate offense.
(Code 2014, § 38-131(b); Ord. No. 288-A, §§ 2, 3, 8-14-1989)
State law reference(s)—Penalty in state law, V.T.C.A., Penal Code § 48.01(f).
Chapter 40 SUBDIVISIONS
State law reference(s)—Subdivisions, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 212.001
et seq.
ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL
Sec. 40-1. Authority.
The ordinance from which this chapter derived is adopted under the authority of
the constitution and laws of the state, including particularly V.T.C.A., Local
Government Code § 212.001 et seq., as amended.
(Code 2014, § 40-1; Ord. No. 426, exh. A(§ 1-3), 3-9-1998)
Sec. 40-2. Purpose.
   (a)   It is the purpose of this chapter to provide for the orderly, safe and
healthful development of the area within the city and within its
extraterritorial jurisdiction, and to promote the health, safety, and general
welfare of the community.
   (b)   It is the purpose of this chapter to provide for adequate improvements
within and adjacent to subdivisions of land hereunder without increasing the
property tax liability of the citizens of the city.
   (c)   These shall be the minimum requirements for administration,
enforcement, procedures, restrictions, standards, uses, variances, and all
other areas addressed by this chapter, and, if any other existing ordinance or
regulation allows lesser regulation, this chapter shall govern so that, in all
cases, the more restrictive limitation or requirement shall govern.
   (d)   It is not the purpose of this chapter to place unreasonable demands
upon anyone wishing to develop land in the city and the city council reserves
the right to grant and/or negotiate variances from the provisions of this
chapter.
(Code 2014, § 40-2; Ord. No. 426, exh. A(§ 1-4), 3-9-1998)
Sec. 40-3. Definitions.
   (a)   The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter,
shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the
context clearly indicates a different meaning:
   Accessory use means a use subordinate to and incidental to the primary use
of the main building or to the primary use of the premises.
   Airport, landing field, orheliport means a landing facility for fixed and
rotary wing aircraft. Such facility is subject to approval by the city and
includes a terminal, fueling and repair facilities, and storage facilities.
   Alley means a public space or access way which affords only secondary means
of access to property whose principal frontage is on a public street or
officially approved place.
   Amusement, commercial (indoors), means an amusement enterprise wholly
enclosed in a building that is treated acoustically so the noise generated by
the enterprise is not perceptible at the bounding property line. Such
enterprises include, but are not limited to, bowling alleys or billiard
parlors.
   Amusement, commercial (outdoors), means an amusement enterprise offering
entertainment or games of skill to the general public for a fee or charge
wherein any portion of the activity takes place in the open. Such enterprises
include, but are not limited to, golf driving ranges, archery ranges and
miniature golf courses.
   Antique shop means an establishment offering for sale, within a building,
articles, including, but not limited to, glass, china, furniture or similar
furnishings and decorations which have value and significance as a result of
age, design or sentiment.
   Apartment means a room or suite or rooms in a multifamily dwelling or
apartment house arranged, designed or occupied as a place of residence by a
single-family, individual or group of individuals.
   Apartment house means any building or portion thereof, which is designed,
built, rented, leased or let to be occupied as three or more dwelling units or
apartments, or which is occupied as a home or place of residence by three or
more families living in independent dwelling units.
   Area of the lot means the area of the lot is the net area of the lot, not
including portions of streets and alleys.
   Art gallery ormuseum means an institution for the collection, display and
distribution of objects of art or science. Such institution is sponsored by a
public or quasi-public agency and is open to the general public.
   Arterial street means a street designed to facilitate rapid and heavy
traffic movements and which primarily provides vehicular circulation to various
sections of the city in such a manner as to facilitate movement and limit
access.
   Automobile repair garage means any building or part thereof in which
automobiles and light trucks are repaired or maintained. The term "automobile
repair garage" does not include any facility at which customer's vehicles are
refueled.
   Automobile salvage or wrecking yard means a yard or building where
automobiles or machinery are stored dismantled and/or offered for sales as
whole units, as salvaged parts or as processed metal.
   Automobile service station means a building or parcel of land at which
customer's vehicles are refueled from a system of underground tanks and pipes
and at which other automotive service is available. The term "automobile
service station" includes activities allowed at an automobile repair garage.
   Automobile storage yard means a building or parcel of land used for long-
term storage of vehicles and small boats. The term "automobile storage yard"
does not include any parcel on which any of the following activities are
regularly conducted: sales, wholesale or retail; hourly or daily parking;
repairs, maintenance or fueling; vehicle dismantling; and junkyards.
   Automobile wrecking yard. See Automobile salvage yard.
   Base flood means the flood having a one percent chance of being equaled or
exceeded in any given year.
   Basement means a building story which is partly underground, but having at
least one-half of its height above the average level of the adjoining ground.
The term "basement" shall be counted as a story in computing building height.
   Block means an area enclosed by streets and occupied by or intended for
buildings. The term "block," used as a term of measurement, means the distance
along a side of a street between the nearest two streets which intersect said
street on said side.
   Board means the zoning board of adjustment, as provided for in article XXXII
of chapter 46.
   Boardinghouse means a building other than a hotel, where lodging and meals
for four or more persons are served for compensation.
   Building means any structure built for the support, shelter and enclosure of
persons, animals, chattels or movable property of any kind. When subdivided in
