case. The design storm will have a ten-year return frequency. Example: Street
width 41 feet to 49 feet—two 12-foot traffic lanes to remain clear.
               (ii)   Residential collector streets (41 foot B-B). The flow of
water in gutters or a residential collector street shall be limited so that one
standard lane will remain clear during the peak runoff from the design storm.
Inlets shall be located at low points or wherever the flow exceeds the one
standard lane requirement. Gutter depression at the inlet is discouraged, but
shall not exceed five inches in any case. The design storm will have a ten-year
return frequency. Example: Street width 41 feet—one 12-foot traffic lane to
remain clear.
         d.   Residential street (33 feet B-B). The flow of water in gutters of
a residential street shall be limited to a flow at the curb of six inches or
wherever the street is just covered, whichever is the least depth. Outlets
shall be located at low points, or wherever the gutter flow exceeds the
permissible spread of water. In no case shall the gutter depression at the
inlet exceed five inches. The design storm will have a ten-year return
frequency.
      (9)   Detention ponds.
         a.   A detention pond shall be required when the director of public
works concludes that such installation is necessary. The design will be
approved by the director of public works.
         b.   Construction, installation and maintenance of the detention pond
shall be at the developer's expenses and shall conform to city standard
specifications.
         c.   Ponds will provide for a temporary storage of stormwater runoff
and shall be designed with post-development peak rates of discharge being the
same as pre development peak rates of discharge for a ten-year storm event or
frequency at each point of discharge from the site. Runoff is released at a
controlled rate which shall not exceed the capacities of the existing drainage
systems or the predeveloped peak runoff rate of the site, whichever is less.
         d.   A barrier-type fence, at least six feet in height, is required to
prevent access to a detention pond facility. A detention pond facility shall
have interior slopes greater than 4H:1V. A gate, a minimum of 12 feet in width,
is required to allow access for maintenance equipment.
         e.   A ten-foot maintenance access strip is required around the
perimeter of the detention pond facility. This ten-foot strip shall not have a
post-construction slope greater than 15 percent. A permanent maintenance
equipment access ramp is also required with a slope not exceeding 4H:1V. The
minimum ramp width is ten feet.
         f.   Corrective maintenance is required if a pond does not drain
completely within 60 hours of the cessation of stormwater inflow. No standing
water is allowed.
   (l)   Bridges.
      (1)   Where bridges are needed to serve minor streets, the total cost of
the bridge shall be paid by the developer.
      (2)   For other thoroughfares, the cost of bridges shall be the
responsibility of the developer, unless other cost-sharing programs with city
are in effect.
   (m)   Crosswalks/ways.
      (1)   Crosswalks/ways ten feet in width shall be dedicated where deemed
necessary by the director of public works to provide circulation or access to
schools, playgrounds, shopping centers, and transportation and other community
facilities, or to provide pedestrian circulation within the subdivision.
      (2)   Crosswalks/ways shall be provided with a concrete sidewalk four
feet wide, with the expense of such construction borne by the developer, and to
be constructed according to city standard specifications.
   (n)   Streetlight placement, standards and development policy.
      (1)   Street type. Streetlights shall be placed in accordance with the
following:
         a.   Typical location of lights shall be at the intersection of two
arterial streets; at the intersection of an arterial and a collector street;
and at the intersection of two collector streets, as reflected on the city's
current major thoroughfare street plan;
         b.   In the turnaround of cul-de-sacs where cul-de-sac length is
longer than 300 feet;
         c.   At alley/street intersections, as recommended by the director of
public works.
      (2)   Safety considerations. Streetlights shall be placed in accordance
with the following safety considerations:
         a.   To illuminate street curves; significant topographic conditions,
alleys or other safety hazards to the public, as recommended by the director of
public works, chief of police or fire chief;
         b.   To illuminate documented high-crime areas, as recommended by the
chief of police;
         c.   To illuminate streets at locations where the traffic count
exceeds 5,000 vehicles per day, or a location with significant accident
history, as recommended by the director of public works.
      (3)   Spacing. Streetlights shall be placed in accordance with the
following spacing consideration:
         a.   Typical spacing of lights shall be; one per intersection at the
intersections described in subsection (n)(1) of this section;
         b.   Additional lights shall be provided along arterial and collector
streets, with a minimum spacing between lights of 300 feet provided;
         c.   If resulting block length is over 600 feet but less than
increments of 300 feet, the light shall be placed in mid-block to the degree
practical;
         d.   In a cul-de-sac turn-around, if the cul-de-sac length is longer
than 300 feet.
      (4)   Street type; light size; light type relationship.
 
Street Type                             Light Size/Lumens Light Type
Thoroughfare (heavy traffic)            400w/50,000       HPS
Arterial (medium traffic)               200w/22,000       HPS
Collector (residential and low traffic) 150w/16,500       HPS
 
      (5)   Timing of streetlight installation.
         a.   New subdivisions.
            1.   The developer shall submit a street light plan as a part of
the final subdivision plat package in conjunction with the utility plans and in
conformance with these standards.
            2.   The staff shall review, coordinate with Gulf States Utility
(Energy), and recommend street light plans to the city council.
            3.   The developer shall pay an additional increment required for
any additional charges: underground; metal pole; special fixture; additional
electricity charge for installation, in conjunction with the final plat phase.
Gulf States Utility will prepare an estimate of the cost difference between
standard overhead street lighting and special developer requirements. Developer
will be responsible for making a nonrefundable payment as aid-to-construction
to the utility, in advance of construction, based on the estimate.
            4.   Installation will be coordinated with building permits issued
in the areas, with priority given to arterial and collector streets in the
subdivision to facilitate circulation; within each block face, when 50 percent
of lots have been permitted, lights shall be installed. This light installation
schedule may be accelerated in accordance with an agreement made with the
developer whereby the developer pays the city the full cost of power during the
time period necessary to reach this level of permitting.
            5.   The city council may disapprove any subdivision where the
developer fails to comply with the standards defined in subsections (n)(5)a.1
through 4 of this section.
         b.   Sparsely developed areas.
            1.   A request shall be submitted to the office of the director of
public works in conformance with the criteria.
            2.   Installation will be attempted as soon as possible, provided
the city council budgets the funds to allow installation.
      (6)   Other locations. In those instances when the criteria of subsection
(n)(5)a and b of this section do not warrant streetlight placement in a
particular location where property owners or residents desire a streetlight,
the city encourages privately-funded and privately-maintained lights by
neighborhood residents. All privately-funded lights shall be totally owned and
maintained by the private property owners or residents. All utilities shall be
entirely paid for by the private property owner or residents. The city shall
never be obligated to pay for the maintenance or utilities of any privately-
funded light.
      (7)   Administration. The administrator of this section shall be the
director of public works. The administrator shall make the final determination
whether a street light is warranted under these criteria and will establish a
procedure for review of requests.
      (8)   Appeal. The decision of the director of public works may, within 30
days of that decision, be appealed to the city council by submitting a written
notice of appeal to the city manager.
(Code 2014, § 40-73; Ord. No. 426, exh. A(§ 3-3), 3-9-1998)

Secs. 40-75—40-91. Reserved.
ARTICLE IV. PROCEDURES
Sec. 40-92. Time.
It shall be the responsibility of the applicant to provide ample time to meet
all requirements and provisions of this article.
(Code 2014, § 40-92; Ord. No. 426, exh. A(§ 4-1), 3-9-1998)
Sec. 40-93. Preliminary conference.
Prior to the official filing of a preliminary plat, the developer shall consult
with and present a proposed sketch plan of the subdivision to the director of
public works for review, comment, and guidance on procedures, city
specifications, and standards required by the city for the subdivision of land.
(Code 2014, § 40-93; Ord. No. 426, exh. A(§ 4-2), 3-9-1998)
Sec. 40-94. Preliminary plat.
   (a)   General requirements.
      (1)   The developer shall cause a preliminary plat to be prepared by a
surveyor in accordance with this article.
      (2)   Formal filing and presentation of the preliminary plat for approval
shall be made by the developer or his agent to the city council at an official
meeting.
      (3)   Simultaneous with filing of the preliminary plat for a subdivision
within the extraterritorial jurisdiction (ETJ) of the city, the developer shall
file a petition for annexation of the subdivision by the city. Such petition
shall conform to V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 43.028.
   (b)   Procedure.
      (1)   The director of public works shall check the preliminary plat as to
its conformity with the comprehensive plan, major street plan, land use plan,
zoning districts and the standards and specifications set forth or referred to
herein.
      (2)   The director of public works shall call a meeting of the
subdivision review committee to review the plats which have been presented.
      (3)   Final recommendations shall be presented to the city council.
      (4)   The city council shall cause the developer to be informed in
writing of any necessary changes in a preliminary plat.
      (5)   Within 60 days after formal filing of the preliminary plat, the
city council shall approve or disapprove such plat (or conditionally approve it
with modifications).
      (6)   Written notification of the city council action shall be given the
developer within ten days after such action is taken.
   (c)   Approval.
      (1)   Approval of a preliminary plat by the city council shall be deemed
an approval of the layout submitted on the preliminary plat as a guide to the
installation of streets, water, sewer and other required improvements and
utilities and to the preparation of the final plat.
      (2)   Approval of a preliminary plat shall not constitute automatic
approval of the final plat.
      (3)   Approval of a preliminary plat does not constitute approval to
allow installation of utilities.
      (4)   Approval of a preliminary plat shall be effective for two years,
unless reviewed by the city council in the light of significant information
which would necessitate a revision of the preliminary plat.
(Code 2014, § 40-94; Ord. No. 426, exh. A(§ 4-3), 3-9-1998)
Sec. 40-95. Final plat.
   (a)   General provisions.
      (1)   All notices shall be by certified mail to the property owner at the
address as shown on the preliminary plat.
      (2)   The final plat may constitute only that portion of the approved
preliminary plat which the developer proposes to record and develop, if
approved by the city council.
      (3)   The portion referred to in subsection (a)(2) of this section shall
conform to all the requirements of this article.
      (4)   All fees including the recording fees as required by the county
clerk's office shall be paid by the developer prior to final plat consideration
by the city council.
      (5)   Taxes for the land shown on the final plat must be paid and
current, and a certificate indicating that taxes have been paid must accompany
final plat submission.
   (b)   Procedures.
      (1)   As soon as practical after the developer is notified of the
approval of the preliminary plat, he or his agent shall submit to the director
of public works the final plat of the subdivision or portion thereof, along
with all required accompanying data.
      (2)   The formal final plat submittal shall be made to the city council
within two years of the date of approval of a preliminary plat, otherwise the
approval of the city council shall become null and void, unless an extension of
time is applied for and granted by the city council.
      (3)   Within 60 days after the final plat is formally filed, the city
council shall approve or disapprove such plat.
      (4)   After the final plat has been approved, the director of public
works shall cause the final plat and other required instruments to be recorded
with the county clerk in the county in which the subdivision lies.
      (5)   The director of public works shall also cause the check for the
recordation fee deposited at the time the final plat was filed for approval to
be delivered with the final plat to the county clerk.
   (c)   Amending plats.
      (1)   The city council may approve and issue an amending plat, which may
be recorded and is controlling over the preceding plat without vacation of that
plat, if the amending plat is signed by the applicants only and is solely for
one or more of the following purposes:
         a.   To correct an error in a course or distance shown on the
preceding plat.
         b.   To add a course or distance that was omitted on the preceding
plat.
         c.   To correct an error in a real property description shown on the
preceding plat.
         d.   To indicate monuments set after the death, disability, or
retirement from practice of the engineer or surveyor responsible for setting
monuments.
         e.   To show the location or character of a monument that has been
changed in location or character or that is shown incorrectly as to location or
character on the preceding plat.
         f.   To correct any other type of scrivener or clerical error or
omission previously approved by the municipal authority responsible for
approving plats, including lot numbers, acreage, street names, and
identification of adjacent recorded plats.
         g.   To correct an error in courses and distances of lot lines between
two adjacent lots if:
            1.   Both lot owners join in the application of amending the plat;
            2.   Neither lot is abolished;
            3.   The amendment does not attempt to remove recorded covenants or
restrictions; and
            4.   The amendment does not have a material adverse effect on the
property rights of the other owners in the plat.
         h.   To relocate a lot line to eliminate an inadvertent encroachment
of a building or other improvement on a lot line or easement.
         i.   To relocate one or more lot lines between one or more adjacent
lots if:
            1.   The owners of all those lots join in the application for
amending the plat;
            2.   The amendment does not attempt to remove recorded covenants or
restrictions; and
            3.   The amendment does not increase the number of lots.
         j.   To make necessary changes to the preceding plat to create six or
fewer lots in the subdivision or a part of the subdivision covered by the
preceding plat if:
            1.   The changes do not affect applicable zoning and other
regulations of the city;
            2.   The changes do not attempt to amend or remove any covenants or
restrictions; and
            3.   The area covered by the changes is located in an area that the
city council or other appropriate governing body of the city has approved,
after a public hearing, as a residential improvement area.
         k.   To replat one or more lots fronting on an existing street if:
            1.   The owners of all those lots join in the application for
amending the plat;
            2.   The amendment does not attempt to remove recorded covenants or
restrictions;
            3.   The amendment does not increase the number of lots; and
            4.   The amendment does not create or require the creation of a new
street or make necessary the extension of municipal facilities.
      (2)   The director of public works may not disapprove the amending plat
and shall refer any amending plat he refuses to approve to the city council.
      (3)   Notice to and the approval of other lot owners are not required for
the approval and issuance of an amending plat.
(Code 2014, § 40-95; Ord. No. 426, exh. A(§ 4-4), 3-9-1998)
Sec. 40-96. Subdivision; unit of a larger tract.
   (a)   Where the proposed subdivision constitutes a unit of a larger tract
owned by the developer or any related entity or person, or in which the
developer or any related entity or person owns a controlling interest, the
preliminary plat shall be accompanied by area layout material covering the
larger tract as specified in section
40-39.
   (b)   The area layout of the larger tract containing the material specified
in section
40-39, if approved by the city council, shall be attached to and filed with a
copy of the approved subdivision plat in the permanent files of the director of
public works.
   (c)   Thereafter, plats of subsequent units of such subdivision shall
conform to such approved overall layout, unless said changes have been approved
by the city council.
   (d)   Except where the developer agrees to such change, the city council may
change such approved overall layout only when the city council determines:
      (1)   That adherence to the previously approved overall layout will
hinder the orderly subdivision of other land in the area in accordance with the
provisions of this article; or
      (2)   That adherence to the previously approved overall layout will be
detrimental to the public health, safety or welfare, or will be injurious to
other property in the area.
(Code 2014, § 40-96; Ord. No. 426, exh. A(§ 4-5), 3-9-1998)
Sec. 40-97. Minor subdivision.
   (a)   The director of public works may certify a subdivision or a
resubdivision plat as a minor subdivision if he finds that it meets the
standards for minor subdivisions set forth in section
40-41.
   (b)   Minor subdivision procedure.
      (1)   Each applicant for minor subdivision approval shall present a
sketch plan for the same to the director of public works. A sketch plan is
preparatory to the preparation of a final plat to enable the developer and/or
owner to save time and expense in reaching agreement with the director of
public works as to the requirements of the final plat and the objectives of
these regulations. It shall include those items set forth in section
40-41.
      (2)   Upon a finding that the proposed plan meets the minor subdivision
standards set forth in section
40-41, the director of public works may certify the sketch plan submitted as
the final plat of a minor subdivision and may, by affixing a notation to that
effect and his signature thereto, recommend final subdivision approval.
      (3)   The director of public works may approve the plat of a minor
subdivision, but the building inspector may not disapprove such a plat. If the
director of public works refuses to approve a plat of a minor subdivision or if
the director of public works elects to present the plat to the city council,
the plat shall be presented to the city council at its next regularly scheduled
meeting for final approval.
(Code 2014, § 40-97; Ord. No. 426, exh. A(§ 4-6), 3-9-1998)
Sec. 40-98. Improvements.
   (a)   Guarantee of improvements.
      (1)   If the developer chooses to file security bond and a maintenance
bond in lieu of completing construction of required improvements prior to
issuance of building permits, he may only utilize the methods of posting
security provided in this section.
      (2)   If the developer chooses to file security, building permits shall
not be issued unless the developer has done one of the following:
         a.   He has filed with the director of public works a performance bond
executed by a surety company holding a license to do business in the state, and
acceptable to the director of public works, in an amount equal to the cost of
the improvements required by this article as estimated by the developer's
engineer, and approved by the director of public works.
            1.   Such bond shall be conditioned that the developer will
complete such improvement within 180 days after approval of such plat.
            2.   Such bond shall be approved as to form and legality by the
city attorney.
            3.   In the event that such improvements are not completed to the
satisfaction of the director of public works within the specified time period,
then the surety company shall complete such improvements within such additional
time period as required by the director of public works.
         b.   The developer has placed on deposit in a bank within the
corporate limits of the city in a trust or escrow account a sum of money equal
to the estimated cost of such site improvements.
            1.   The estimated cost of any such site improvement shall be that
estimated by the registered professional engineer retained by said developer to
prepare the construction plans for such site improvement and then approved by
the director of public works.
            2.   The escrow agreement made pursuant to said deposit and by and
between said developer and the escrow agent designated by said bank shall
provide, among other things, that as the construction of any such site
improvement proceeds in accordance with the plans and specifications therefor,
said developer may at reasonable times and subject to the written approval of
said director of public works withdraw sums from said escrow account in amounts
equal to the total amount of the work performed on such project, less ten
percent of the amount thereof less all such previous withdrawals, which said
sum so retained in said escrow account, until the completion of such
installation by said developer and approval thereof by said director of public
works.
            3.   The escrow agreement shall also provide that the developer
will complete such improvements within 180 days after approval of the plat.
            4.   Said escrow agreement shall be further conditioned as may be
reasonable and shall be in the form prescribed by the city attorney.
            5.   If the required site improvements are not completed according
to the provisions of this section, the city manager is empowered to demand
immediate payment of the total amount of funds remaining in said escrow account
to the city. This empowerment shall be expressly stated in the subdivision
documents.
   (b)   Inspection and review.
      (1)   All improvement construction shall be inspected periodically while
in progress by the appropriate city department, and must be approved or
rejected upon completion by the director of public works.
      (2)   The director of public works shall notify the developer in writing
as to his acceptance or rejection of the construction.
   (c)   Inspection rejected.
      (1)   The director of public works shall reject such construction on the
basis of whether it fails to comply with the standards and specifications
contained or referenced herein.
      (2)   If the director of public works rejects such construction, the city
attorney shall, on the direction of the city council, proceed to enforce the
guarantees provided for in this article to ensure that corrective action is
taken.
   (d)   Improvements approved.
      (1)   If approved, the developer shall then file with the director of
public works and payable to the city, a bond, executed by a surety company
holding a license to do business in the state, or an escrow account payable to
the city, and acceptable to him, in an amount equal to ten percent of the cost
of the improvements required, as estimated by the developer's engineer and
approved by the director of public works, conditioned that the developer will
maintain such improvements in good condition for a period of one year after
acceptance of the improvements by the city.
      (2)   Such bond shall be approved as to form and legality by the city
attorney.
   (e)   Time extensions.
      (1)   Where good cause exists, the director of public works may grant one
extension of time for completion under this section for an additional period of
time not to exceed six months if the developer has not completed the required
site improvements or has not completed such improvements in compliance with
this article.
      (2)   No such extension shall be granted unless security as provided in
this section has been provided by the developer covering the extended period of
time.
      (3)   No building permit shall be issued for any construction in the
subdivision during the extension period.
   (f)   The developer and his engineer shall submit to the public works
department "as built" sepias and plans for all improvements constructed under
the terms of this article as a condition for acceptance of said improvements.
   (g)   No certificate of occupancy shall be issued for any structure built
under the provisions of this section until all required site improvements have
received final acceptance by the director of public works.
(Code 2014, § 40-98; Ord. No. 426, exh. A(§ 4-7), 3-9-1998)
Sec. 40-99. Reservations.
   (a)   No land contained in the proposed subdivision shall be reserved for
any use other than a use permitted by the comprehensive zoning chapter for the
district in which the land to be reserved is located.
   (b)   The specific use for which each parcel of land is to be reserved shall
be shown by appropriate label or description on the plat.
   (c)   When it is indicated by the city comprehensive plan or the city park
plan that a tract of land planned to be used for a park is contained, in whole
or in part, within the area encompassed by the proposed subdivision, the
developer shall convey such tract for a park site to the city by general
warranty deed subject to the conditions hereinafter set forth.
      (1)   The tract to be conveyed to the city shall be described by metes
and bounds furnished by the developer.
      (2)   Proposed park sites shall be submitted to the city council for
approval prior to submission of the preliminary plat to the city council.
      (3)   The city council may accept or reject such proposed conveyance
prior to the action by the city council on the preliminary plat and shall make
such recommendations to the city council as it deems necessary and appropriate.
      (4)   Conveyance of such land, subject only to such liens or indebtedness
as may cover the entire subdivision, shall be a prerequisite to approval of any
final plat of the subdivision or part thereof.
   (d)   The developer shall indicate on the preliminary plat the manner in
which the tract will be developed if the city fails to purchase or rejects the
property.
(Code 2014, § 40-99; Ord. No. 426, exh. A(§ 4-8), 3-9-1998)
Sec. 40-100. Modifications and variations.
   (a)   Where the city council finds that compliance with these regulations
would cause unusual hardship or extraordinary difficulties because of
exceptional and unique conditions of access, location, shape, size, drainage or
other physical features of the site, the requirements may be modified to
mitigate the hardship, provided that the public interest is protected and the
development is in keeping with the general spirit and intent of this article.
   (b)   This section shall, not be interpreted to permit the development of
land which is inherently unsuitable for the use proposed.
   (c)   Whenever any improvement required by this article is waived or an
exception made thereto, the city council shall not by reason of such waiver or
exception, be stopped or prevented from subsequently requiring the installation
or provision of such improvement where upon the recommendation of the director
of public works it appears that the condition or reason for such previous
waiver or exception no longer exists.
(Code 2014, § 40-100; Ord. No. 426, exh. A(§ 4-9), 3-9-1998)
Secs. 40-101—40-128. Reserved.
ARTICLE V. FEES
Sec. 40-129. Application fee.
All submissions required under this article shall be accompanied by the payment
of fees in accordance with the current subdivision fee schedule maintained in
the office of the director of public works. The subdivision fee schedule shall
be approved by the city council and may be changed from time to time by the
city council without notice.
(Code 2014, § 40-129; Ord. No. 426, exh. A(§ 5-1), 3-9-1998)
Sec. 40-130. Payment and reimbursement of fee.
   (a)   The city council shall take no action until all required fees have
been paid.
   (b)   The required fees shall not be refunded should the plat be
disapproved.
   (c)   Resubmission of revised preliminary plats having substantial changes
shall, at the discretion of the director of public works, require complete
reapplication and payment of fees.
   (d)   The recording fee for each plat filed in the county is separate. It
shall be paid following approval of the final plat and the plat will be filed
for record by the city.
(Code 2014, § 40-130; Ord. No. 426, exh. A(§ 5-2), 3-9-1998)
Secs. 40-131—40-158. Reserved.
ARTICLE VI. ADMINISTRATION
Sec. 40-159. Authority.
   (a)   The city council and the office of the director of public works have
been established.
   (b)   Pursuant to the express provisions of this article, the city council
and the office of the director of public works shall have the powers and duties
necessary to carry out the functions assigned to them under this article and
the laws of the state.
(Code 2014, § 40-159; Ord. No. 426, exh. A(§ 6-1), 3-9-1998)
Sec. 40-160. Director of public works.
   (a)   The director of public works is hereby authorized and directed to
promulgate rules, regulations, standards, specifications and construction
drawings for the construction, installation, design, location and arrangement
of streets, curbs, street lights, street signs, alleys, utility layouts,
utility easements, gates for utility easements, sidewalks, water supply and
water distribution systems, fire hydrants, sewage disposal systems, water
wells, monuments, criteria for drainage easement requirements, drainage
facilities and crosswalks/ways.
   (b)   The director of public works shall file same with the city secretary
at least ten days before they become effective.
   (c)   The director of public works may amend the same from time to time,
provided that an amendment must be filed with the city secretary at least ten
days before it becomes effective.
(Code 2014, § 40-160; Ord. No. 426, exh. A(§ 6-2), 3-9-1998)
Secs. 40-161—40-188. Reserved.
ARTICLE VII. FLOOD HAZARD AREAS
Sec. 40-189. General provisions.
   (a)   Any flood hazard analysis required under this article shall utilize
the methods of flood hazard analysis specified by ordinance of the city, as
amended, which is incorporated herein by reference.
   (b)   All submissions required under the provisions of this article shall be
reviewed by the director of public works and receive his approval prior to
formal filing of the final plat with the city council.
(Code 2014, § 40-189; Ord. No. 426, exh. A(§ 7-1), 3-9-1998)
Sec. 40-190. Purpose.
   (a)   It is the purpose of this article to promote the public health, safety
and welfare.
   (b)   It is the purpose of this article to minimize the losses caused by the
cumulative effect of obstructions in floodplains causing increases in flood
heights and velocities, and the occupancy of flood hazard areas by uses
vulnerable to floods, or hazardous to other lands, which are inadequately
elevated or otherwise protected from flood damages.
   (c)   It is the purpose of this article to minimize losses caused by the
conditions described in subsection (b) of this section, by provisions designed
to:
      (1)   Restrict or prohibit subdivision of lands for uses which are
dangerous to health, safety or property in times of flood or which, with
reasonably anticipated improvements, will cause excessive increases in flood
heights or velocities.
      (2)   Require that each subdivision lot in an area vulnerable to floods
be provided with a safe building site (i.e., slab/foundation elevations must be
established by a registered professional land surveyor) with adequate access,
and that public facilities which serve such uses be installed with protection
against flood damages at the time of initial construction.
      (3)   Protect individuals from buying lands which are unsuited for
intended purposes because of flood hazards by prohibiting the subdivision of
unprotected flood hazard lands, requiring that flood hazard areas be delineated
on the final plat, and reserving through deed restrictions areas not suitable
for development.
(Code 2014, § 40-190; Ord. No. 426, exh. A(§ 7-2), 3-9-1998)
Sec. 40-191. Application.
   (a)   This article shall apply to all lands within jurisdiction of the city
delineated as flood hazard areas on the flood insurance rate maps and flood
hazard boundary-floodway maps of the city, as amended.
   (b)   This article shall also apply to all lands within the extraterritorial
jurisdiction of said city determined as flood hazard areas by extension of
floodplains shown on said maps.
(Code 2014, § 40-191; Ord. No. 426, exh. A(§ 7-3), 3-9-1998)
Sec. 40-192. Disclaimer and liability limitation.
   (a)   The degree of flood protection required under this article is
considered reasonable for regulatory purposes and is based on engineering and
scientific methods of study.
   (b)   This article does not imply that areas outside the delineated flood
hazard areas or land uses permitted within such areas will be free from
flooding or flood damages.
   (c)   This article shall not create liability on the part of the city or any
officer or employee thereof for any flood damages that result from reliance on
this article or any administrative decision lawfully made thereunder.
(Code 2014, § 40-192; Ord. No. 426, exh. A(§ 7-4), 3-9-1998)
Sec. 40-193. Land suitability.
In determining the appropriateness of land subdivision at a site, the city
council shall consider the objectives of this section and:
      (1)   The danger to life and property due to the increased flood heights
or velocities caused by subdivision fill, roads, and intended uses.
      (2)   The danger that intended uses may be swept onto other lands or
downstream to the injury of others.
      (3)   The adequacy of proposed water supply and sanitation systems and
the ability of these systems to prevent disease, contamination and unsanitary
conditions under flood conditions.
      (4)   The susceptibility of the proposed facility and its contents to
flood damage and the effect of such damage on the individual owner.
      (5)   The importance of the services provided by the proposed facility to
the community.
      (6)   The requirements of the subdivision for a waterfront location.
      (7)   The availability of alternative locations not subject to flooding
for the proposed subdivision and land uses.
      (8)   The compatibility of the proposed uses with existing development
and development anticipated in the foreseeable future.
      (9)   The relationship of the proposed subdivision to the comprehensive
plan and floodplain management program for the area.
      (10)   Safety of access to the property for emergency vehicles in times
of flood.
      (11)   The expected heights, velocity, duration, rate of rise and
sediment transport of the floodwaters expected at the site.
      (12)   The costs of providing governmental services during and after
flood conditions including maintenance and repair of public utilities and
facilities such as sewer, gas, electrical and water systems, and streets and
bridges.
(Code 2014, § 40-193; Ord. No. 426, exh. A(§ 7-5), 3-9-1998)
Sec. 40-194. Improvements.
   (a)   No subdivision or part thereof shall be approved if the proposed
subdivision, levees, fills, structures, improvements or other features will
individually or collectively increase flood flows, heights, or damages.
   (b)   The city council may approve preliminary and final plats if developers
improve lands consistent with the standards of this article and other
applicable ordinances to make subdivision areas, in the opinion of the city
council, suitable for their intended uses.
   (c)   The city council may approve preliminary and final plats if developers
agree to make suitable improvements and place a sum in escrow pursuant to this
article to guarantee performance.
(Code 2014, § 40-194; Ord. No. 426, exh. A(§ 7-6), 3-9-1998)
Sec. 40-195. Development limitation.
If the city council determines that any part of a proposed plat can be safely
developed, it shall limit development to that part, and shall require that
development proceed consistent with this determination.
(Code 2014, § 40-195; Ord. No. 426, exh. A(§ 7-7), 3-9-1998)
Sec. 40-196. Deed restrictions.
   (a)   When the developer does not intend to develop the plat himself, and
the city council determines that additional use controls are required to ensure
safe development, it may require the developer to impose appropriate deed
restrictions on the land.
   (b)   All deed restrictions shall be inserted in every deed and such deed
restrictions noted on the face of the final recorded plat.
(Code 2014, § 40-196; Ord. No. 426, exh. A(§ 7-8), 3-9-1998)
Sec. 40-197. Floor elevation.
Where required by the director of public works, lots deemed to be impacted by
flood hazards shall designate a minimum finished floor elevation on the final
plat, and such designation shall be reviewed for accuracy by the director of
public works.
(Code 2014, § 40-197; Ord. No. 426, exh. A(§ 7-9), 3-9-1998)
Sec. 40-198. Floodproofing.
   (a)   The city council may, as a condition of approving any plat for an area
subject to flooding, require floodproofing of intended uses.
   (b)   Floodproofing plans must be individually approved by the city council
before such uses are constructed.
   (c)   Floodproofing measures may include:
      (1)   Anchorage to resist flotation and lateral movement.
      (2)   Installation of watertight doors, bulkheads, and shutters, or
similar methods of closure.
      (3)   Reinforcement of walls to resist water pressures.
      (4)   Use of paints, membranes, or mortars to reduce seepage of water
through walls.
      (5)   Addition of mass or weight to structures to resist flotation.
      (6)   Installation of pumps to lower water levels in structures.
      (7)   Construction of water supply and waste treatment systems so as to
prevent the entrance of floodwaters.
      (8)   Installation of pumps or comparable facilities for subsurface
drainage systems to relieve external foundation wall and basement flood
pressures.
      (9)   Building design and construction to resist rupture or collapse
caused by water pressure or floating debris.
      (10)   Installation of valves or controls on sanitary and storm drains
which permit the drains to be closed to prevent backup of sewage and
stormwaters into buildings or structures.
      (11)   Location and installation of all electrical equipment, circuits
and electrical appliances so that they are protected from inundation by the
regulatory flood.
      (12)   Location of storage facilities for chemicals, explosives, buoyant
materials, flammable liquids or other toxic materials which could be hazardous
to public health, safety and welfare at elevation above the height associated
with the regulatory protection elevation; or design of such facilities to
prevent flotation of storage containers, or damage to storage containers which
could result in the escape of toxic materials into floodwaters.
(Code 2014, § 40-198; Ord. No. 426, exh. A(§ 7-10), 3-9-1998)
Sec. 40-199. Drainage facilities.
   (a)   Storm drainage facilities shall be designated to store and convey the
flow of surface waters without damage to persons or property from storms
according to frequencies indicated in the comprehensive plan and city standard
specifications.
   (b)   Storm drainage facilities plans shall be consistent with local and
regional drainage plans.
   (c)   The system shall ensure drainage at all points along streets, and
provide positive drainage away from buildings and on-site waste disposal sites.
   (d)   City council.
      (1)   Plans shall be subject to approval by the city council.
      (2)   The city council may require a primarily underground system to
accommodate frequent floods and a secondary surface system to accommodate less
frequent floods.
(Code 2014, § 40-199; Ord. No. 426, exh. A(§ 7-11), 3-9-1998)
Sec. 40-200. Streets.
   (a)   The finished top of curb elevation of proposed streets shall be no
lower than one foot above the base flood elevation.
   (b)   The city council may require, when deemed necessary, profiles and
elevations of streets to determine compliance with this requirement.
   (c)   Street drainage openings shall be sufficient to collect flood flows
without unduly increasing flood heights.
(Code 2014, § 40-200; Ord. No. 426, exh. A(§ 7-12), 3-9-1998)
Sec. 40-201. Erosion and sediment control.
The developer shall be required by the director of public works to utilize
grading techniques, subdivision design, landscaping, sedimentation basins,
special vegetation cover, and other measures to reduce erosion and sediment in
flood hazard areas and all other areas of the subdivision.
(Code 2014, § 40-201; Ord. No. 426, exh. A(§ 7-13), 3-9-1998)
Secs. 40-202—40-225. Reserved.
ARTICLE VIII. ENFORCEMENT
Sec. 40-226. Penalties.
   (a)   Any person violating any provision of this article within the
corporate limits of the city shall be guilty of a Class C misdemeanor, and,
upon conviction shall be fined an amount not exceeding the maximum amount
allowed by state law.
   (b)   Each day that such violation continues shall be a separate offense.
(Code 2014, § 40-226; Ord. No. 426, exh. A(§ 8-1), 3-9-1998)
Sec. 40-227. Bar to relief.
Prosecution or conviction under this provision shall never be a bar to any
other remedy or relief for violation of this article.
(Code 2014, § 40-227; Ord. No. 426, exh. A(§ 8-2), 3-9-1998)
Sec. 40-228. Remedies.
   (a)   Any violation of this article or of any condition or requirement
adopted pursuant hereto may be restrained, corrected or abated by injunction or
other appropriate proceeding pursuant to state law.
   (b)   The city may seek enforcement as provided by state law and this
article.
   (c)   The city may seek enforcement of this article as provided in chapter
46, article VIII, said article being incorporated herein by reference.
(Code 2014, § 40-228; Ord. No. 426, exh. A(§ 8-3), 3-9-1998)
Sec. 40-229. Other powers and actions.
   (a)   In addition to other enforcement provisions contained in this article,
the city may exercise any and all enforcement powers granted to it by state
law.
   (b)   Nothing in this article shall prohibit the continuation of previous
enforcement actions undertaken pursuant to valid resolution and law.
(Code 2014, § 40-229; Ord. No. 426, exh. A(§ 8-4), 3-9-1998)
Sec. 40-230. Remedies cumulative.
   (a)   All remedies provided herein shall be cumulative.
   (b)   To the extent that state law may limit the availability of a
particular remedy set forth herein for a certain violation or a part thereof,
such remedy shall remain available for other violations or other parts of the
same violation.
(Code 2014, § 40-230; Ord. No. 426, exh. A(§ 8-5), 3-9-1998)
Chapter 42 TAXATION
ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL

ARTICLE II. SALES AND USE TAX
Editor's note(s)—The one percent sales tax was adopted by referendum and an
additional one-half cent was adopted by referendum on November 3, 1987.
State law reference(s)—Sales tax authority, V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 321.001 et
seq.
Sec. 42-19. Tax on consumption of gas and electricity retained.
The city, by majority vote of its governing body, hereby votes to retain the
taxes authorized by the Local Sales and Use Tax Act, V.T.C.A., Tax Code §
321.001 et seq., on the receipts from the sale, production, distribution,
lease, or rental of, and the use, storage, or other consumption of gas and
electricity for residential use, as authorized by V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 321.103.
(Code 2014, § 42-19; Ord. No. 212, § 1, 2-26-1978)
State law reference(s)—Authority to adopt, V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 321.103.
Sec. 42-20. Tax on telecommunications retained.
The city has retained the tax authorized by the Local Sales and Use Tax Act,
V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 321.210 on the receipts from the sale, production,
distribution, lease, or rental of, and the use, storage, or other consumption
of telecommunications, as authorized by V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 321.210.
State law reference(s)—Authority to repeal the exemption for the tax on
telecommunications services and retain the tax, V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 321.210.
Secs. 42-21—42-41. Reserved.
ARTICLE III. HOTEL/MOTEL OCCUPANCY TAX
State law reference(s)—Hotel occupancy tax, V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 351.001 et
seq.
Sec. 42-42. Definitions.
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have
the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly
indicates a different meaning:
   Consideration means the cost of the room, sleeping space, bed, or other
facility in such hotel/motel and shall not include the cost of any food served
or personal services rendered to the occupant of such room not related to the
cleaning and readying of such room, sleeping space, bed or other facility for
occupancy.
   Hotel means any building, trailer or facility, in which the public may, for
a consideration, obtain sleeping accommodations. The term "hotel" includes
hotels, motels, tourist homes, houses or courts, lodginghouses, inns,
roominghouses, or other buildings where rooms are furnished for a
consideration, but the term "hotel" shall not be defined so as to include
hospitals, sanitariums or nursing homes.
   Occupancy means the use or possession, or the right to the use or possession
of any room, sleeping space, bed, or other facility in a hotel for any purpose.
   Occupant means anyone who, for a consideration, uses, possesses, or has a
right to use or possess any room, sleeping space, bed or other facility in a
hotel under any lease, concession, permit, right of access, license, contract
or agreement.
   Permanent resident means any occupant who has or shall have the right to
occupancy of any room or sleeping space or other facility in a hotel for at
least 30 consecutive days so long as there is no interruption of payment for
the period.
   Person means any individual, company, corporation or association owning,
operating, managing or controlling any hotel.
   Quarterly period means the regular calendar quarters of the year, the first
quarter being composed of the months of January, February and March; the second
quarter being the months of April, May and June; the third quarter being the
months of July, August, and September; and the fourth quarter being the months
of October, November, and December.
(Code 2014, § 42-42; Ord. No. 239, § I, 12-14-1981)
Sec. 42-43. Levy of tax; rate; exceptions.
   (a)   There is hereby levied a tax upon the cost of occupancy of any room or
space furnished by a hotel/motel where such cost of occupancy is at the rate of
$2.00 or more per day. Such tax shall be equal to seven percent of the
consideration paid by the occupant of such room to such hotel.
   (b)   No tax shall be imposed hereunder upon a permanent resident.
   (c)   No tax shall be imposed hereunder upon a corporation or association
organized and operated exclusively for religious, charitable or educational
purposes no part of the net earnings of which inures to the benefit to any
private shareholder or individual.
   (d)   Every person required to collect the tax imposed in subsection (a) of
this section shall, upon the timely filing of the report required by this
article and payment of the required tax, be entitled to a discount of one
percent of the total tax, which such person may deduct from the amount remitted
to the city.
(Code 2014, § 42-43; Ord. No. 239, § II, 12-14-1981; Ord. No. 239A, § II, 5-12-
1986; Ord. No. 340, § II, 7-18-1996)
State law reference(s)—Exemptions, V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 351.006.
Sec. 42-44. Collection.
Every person owning, operating, managing or controlling any hotel/motel shall
collect the tax imposed in section
42-43 for the city.
(Code 2014, § 42-44; Ord. No. 239, § III, 12-14-1981)
Sec. 42-45. Reports.
On the last day of the month following each quarterly period, every person
required hereby to collect the tax imposed by this article shall file a report
with the city secretary showing the consideration paid for all room occupancies
in the preceding quarter, the amount of tax collected on the city's behalf on
such occupancies, and any other information as the city secretary may
reasonably require. Such person shall pay over the tax due on such occupancies
at the time of filing such report. There shall also be furnished to the city
secretary at the time of payment of such tax, a copy of the quarterly tax
report filed with the state comptroller in connection with the state hotel
occupancy tax.
(Code 2014, § 42-45; Ord. No. 239, § IV, 12-14-1981)
Sec. 42-46. Rules and regulations.
The city secretary shall have the power to make such rules and regulations as
are necessary to effectively collect the tax levied herein and shall, upon
reasonable notice, have access to books and records necessary to enable him to
determine the correctness of any report filed as required by this article and
the amount of taxes due under the provisions of this article.
(Code 2014, § 42-46; Ord. No. 239, § V, 12-14-1981)
Sec. 42-47. Violations.
If any person, required by the provisions of this article to collect the tax
imposed herein, makes reports as required herein, and pays to the city
secretary the tax imposed herein shall fail to collect such tax, shall fail to
file such report, or shall fail to pay such tax, or if such person shall file a
false report, such person shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon
conviction shall be punished by a fine not to exceed $200.00.
(Code 2014, § 42-47; Ord. No. 239, § VI, 12-14-1981)
Sec. 42-48. Expenditure of collections.
The city council may, by interlocal contract, designate an agency or
organization to undertake all legal solicitation and operating programs on
behalf of the city.
(Code 2014, § 42-48; Ord. No. 239, § VII, 12-14-1981)
Sec. 42-49. Penalties.
If any person shall fail to file a report as required herein or shall fail to
pay to the city secretary the tax as imposed herein when said report or payment
is due, he shall forfeit five percent of the amount due as a penalty, and after
the first 30 days he shall forfeit an additional five percent of such tax;
provided, however, that the penalty shall never be less than $1.00. Delinquent
taxes shall draw interest at the rate of ten percent per annum beginning 60
days from the date due.
(Code 2014, § 42-49; Ord. No. 239, § VIII, 12-14-1981)
Secs. 42-50—42-71. Reserved.
ARTICLE IV. TAX ABATEMENT
State law reference(s)—Tax abatement, V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 312.001 et seq.
Sec. 42-72. Definitions.
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have
the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly
indicates a different meaning:
   Abatement means the full or partial exemption from ad valorem taxes of
certain real and personal property in a reinvestment zone designated by an
affected jurisdiction for economic development purposes.
   Affected jurisdiction means the city and the county all of which is located
in the county, that levy ad valorem taxes upon and provides services to
property located within the proposed or existing reinvestment zone designated
by the city council.
   Agreement means a contractual agreement between a property owner and/or a
lessee and an affected jurisdiction for the purposes of tax abatement.
   Base year value means the assessed value of eligible property on January 1
preceding the execution of this agreement, plus the agreed-upon value of
eligible property improvements made after January 1 but before the execution of
the agreement.
   Deferred maintenance means improvements necessary for continued operations
that do not improve productivity or alter the process technology.
   Distribution center facility means buildings and structures, including
machinery and equipment, used or to be used primarily to receive, store,
service, or distribute goods or materials owned by the facility operator, where
a majority of the goods or services are distributed to points at least 50 miles
from its location in the county.
   Expansion means the addition of buildings, structures, machinery, or
equipment for purposes of increasing production capacity and/or number of
employees.
   Facility means property improvements completed or in the process of
construction which together comprise an integral whole.
   Fixed machinery and equipment or fixed machinery or equipment means
machinery and/or equipment that cannot be removed without injuring a building
or structure, and does not include movable machinery and equipment.
(Code 2014, § 42-72; Ord. No. 569, exh. A, § 1, 8-9-2002)
Sec. 42-73. Abatement authorized.
   (a)   Authorized facility. A facility may be eligible for abatement if it is
used for manufacturing, research, distribution, regional service industry,
regional entertainment, or other basic industry.
   (b)   Creation of new value. Abatement may only be granted for the
additional value of eligible property improvements made subsequent to and
specified in an abatement agreement between the affected jurisdiction and the
property owner or lessee, subject to the limitations as the governing body of
the affected jurisdiction may require.
   (c)   New and existing facilities. Abatement may be granted for new
facilities and/or improvements to existing facilities for purposes of
modernization or expansion.
   (d)   Eligible property. Abatement may be extended to the increased value of
land, buildings, structures, machinery, and equipment, inventories, tools, and
site improvements, plus that office space and related fixed improvements
necessary to the operation and administration of the facility.
   (e)   Ineligible property. The following types of property shall be fully
taxable and ineligible for abatement: current value of land; housing; hotel
accommodations; retail facilities; deferred maintenance; investments; property
to be rented or leased, except as provided in subsection (f) of this section;
property owned or used by the state or its political subdivisions or by any
organization owned, operated, or directed by a political subdivision of the
state.
   (f)   Owned/leased facilities. If a leased facility is granted abatement,
the agreement shall be executed with the lessor and the lessee. Publicly-owned
land leased to private entities shall be eligible if otherwise qualified.
   (g)   Value and term of agreement.
      (1)   Abatement shall be granted effective with January 1 valuation date
immediately following the date of execution of the agreement. The tax abatement
percentage shall be determined and property taxes may be abated using the
following guidelines:
 
New Employment Criteria
No. of    Abatement Period Reduction
Employees
1—20    Five years       33 percent in 4th year, 67 percent in 5th year
21—50   Seven years      33 percent in 6th year, 67 percent in 7th year
50 plus   Ten years        33 percent in 9th year, 67 percent in 10th year
 
 
New Investment in Buildings, Machinery, and/or Equipment Criteria
Dollar Value       Abatement Period Reduction
$500,000.00—     Five years       33 percent in 4th year, 67 percent in 5th
$749,999.00                         year
$750,000.00—     Seven years      33 percent in 6th year, 67 percent in 7th
$999,999.00                         year
$1,000,000.00 plus Ten years        33 percent in 9th year, 67 percent in 10th
                                    year
 
The abatement criteria used will be the one that abates the larger amount.
      (2)   If a modernization project includes facility replacement, the value
eligible for abatement shall be the value of the new units less the value of
the old units.
   (h)   Economic qualification. In order to be eligible for designation as a
reinvestment zone and receive tax abatement, the planned improvements:
      (1)   Must increase the value of the property a minimum of $500,000.00;
      (2)   Must be expected to create, retain, or prevent the loss of
employment on a permanent basis in the county;
      (3)   Must not be expected to solely or primarily have the effect of
transferring employment from one part of the county to another; and
      (4)   Must be necessary because capacity cannot be provided efficiently
utilizing existing property.
   (i)   Taxability. From the execution of the abatement contract to the end of
the agreement period, taxes shall be payable as follows:
      (1)   The value of ineligible property, as provided in subsection (e) of
this section, shall be fully taxable;
      (2)   The value of existing eligible property in the base year shall be
determined each year and shall be fully taxable; and
      (3)   The additional value of new eligible property shall be taxable in
the same manner described in subsection (g) of this section.
(Code 2014, § 42-73; Ord. No. 569, exh. A, § 2, 8-9-2002)
Sec. 42-74. Application.
   (a)   Any present or potential owner of taxable property in an affected
jurisdiction may request the creation of a reinvestment zone and tax abatement
by filing a written application with the presiding officer of the governing
body of the affected jurisdiction.
   (b)   The application shall consist of a completed application form
accompanied by a general description of proposed use and the general nature and
extent of the modernization, expansion, or new improvements to be undertaken; a
descriptive list of the improvements which will be part of the facility; a map
and property description; and a time schedule for undertaking and completing
the planned improvements. In the case of modernization, a statement of the
assessed value of the real and personal property of the facility shall be given
for the tax year immediately preceding the application. The application form
may require such financial and other information as the governing body of the
affected jurisdiction deems appropriate for evaluating the financial capacity
and other factors of the applicant.
   (c)   Upon receipt of a completed application, the officer with whom the
application was filed shall notify in writing the presiding officer of the
governing body of each affected jurisdiction. Before acting upon the
application, each affected jurisdiction shall through a public hearing afford
the applicant and the designated representative of any affected jurisdiction
the opportunity to show cause why the abatement should or should not be
granted. Notice of the public hearing shall be clearly identified on an agenda
of the governing body to be posted at least 30 days prior to the hearing.
   (d)   After receipt of an application for creation of a reinvestment zone
and application for abatement, the affected jurisdiction shall prepare or cause
to be prepared a feasibility study setting out the impact of the proposed
reinvestment zone and tax abatement. The feasibility study shall include, but
not be limited to, an estimate of the economic effect of the creation of the
zone and the abatement of the taxes and the benefit to the eligible
jurisdiction and the property to be included in the zone. The costs of such
feasibility study shall be borne by the Madison County Economic Development
Corporation (MCEDC).
   (e)   The governing body of the affected jurisdiction shall not establish a
reinvestment zone for the purpose of abatement if it finds that the request for
the abatement was filed after the commencement of construction, alteration, or
installation of improvements related to a proposed modernization, expansion, or
new facility.
   (f)   Variance. Requests for variance from the provisions of section
42-73 (a) and (g) may be made in writing to the presiding officer of the
governing body of the affected jurisdiction. Such request shall include a
complete description of the circumstances explaining why the applicant should
be granted a variance. Approval of a request for a variance requires a two-
thirds vote of the governing body.
(Code 2014, § 42-74; Ord. No. 569, exh. A, § 3, 8-9-2002)
Sec. 42-75. Reinvestment zone advisory committee.
   (a)   There is hereby created a reinvestment zone advisory committee (RZAC).
The committee shall be composed of seven members. Two members shall be members
of the county economic development corporation, two members shall be from the
county commissioners court (county judge and a county commissioner or their
designees), two members shall be from the city council (mayor and the city
manager or their designees), and one member shall be appointed by the county
chamber of commerce. The initial members of the RZAC shall be appointed as soon
as possible after the adoption of these guidelines and criteria, and the RZAC
shall hold its initial meeting as soon as a majority of its membership has been
appointed. The RZAC may select from one of its members a chairperson and a
vice-chairperson and any other officers that the RZAC deems necessary to
perform its functions and duties.
   (b)   It shall be the duty of the RZAC to provide assistance and advice to
all governing bodies of taxing entities in the county and to the county
economic development corporation, and the county Chamber of Commerce on matters
related to tax abatement and reinvestment zones created in the county. The RZAC
shall also provide information and assistance to applicants and potential
applicants for tax abatements and reinvestment zones. The RZAC may make an
initial review of each application for tax abatement made under these
guidelines and criteria and make recommendations to the governing bodies
regarding the sufficiency of the application and the value and term of
abatement to be authorized.
(Code 2014, § 42-75; Ord. No. 569, exh. A, § 4, 8-9-2002)
Sec. 42-76. Public hearing.
   (a)   Should any affected jurisdiction be able to show cause in the public
hearing why the granting of abatement will have a substantial adverse effect on
its bonds, tax revenue, service capacity, or the provision of service, that
showing shall be reason for the governing body to deny any designation of the
reinvestment zone, the granting of abatement, or both.
   (b)   Neither a reinvestment zone nor abatement agreement shall be
authorized if it is determined that:
      (1)   There would be a substantial adverse effect on the provision of
services or on the tax base;
      (2)   The applicant has insufficient financial capacity;
      (3)   Planned or potential use of the property would constitute a hazard
to public safety, health, or morals; or
      (4)   A planned or potential use of the property would constitute a
violation of other codes or laws.
(Code 2014, § 42-76; Ord. No. 569, exh. A, § 5, 8-9-2002)
Sec. 42-77. Assignment.
Abatement may be transferred and assigned by the holder to a new owner or
lessee of the same facility upon the approval of the governing body, subject to
the financial capacity of the assignee and, provided that all conditions and
obligations in the abatement agreement are guaranteed by the execution of a new
contractual agreement with the affected jurisdiction. No assignment or transfer
shall be approved if the parties to the existing agreement, the new owner or
new lessee are liable to the county or any affected jurisdiction for
outstanding taxes or other obligations. Approval shall not be unreasonably
withheld.
(Code 2014, § 42-77; Ord. No. 569, exh. A, § 8, 8-9-2002)
Sec. 42-78. Duration/review.
   (a)   These guidelines and criteria are effective upon the date of the
ordinance from which they are derived and will remain in force for two years,
at which time all reinvestment zones and tax abatement contracts created
pursuant to its provisions will be reviewed by the governing body to determine
whether the goals have been achieved. Based on that review, the guidelines and
criteria will be renewed, modified, or eliminated, providing that such action
will not affect existing contracts.
   (b)   This policy is mutually exclusive of existing industrial district
contracts and owners of real property in areas deserving of special attention,
as agreed by the affected jurisdictions.
(Code 2014, § 42-78; Ord. No. 569, exh. A, § 9, 8-9-2002)
Secs. 42-79—42-99. Reserved.
ARTICLE V. AD VALOREM TAXATION
State law reference(s)—Property tax code, V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 1.01 et seq.
DIVISION 1. GENERALLY
Secs. 42-100—42-126. Reserved.
DIVISION 2. TANGIBLE PERSONAL PROPERTY
Sec. 42-127. Goods-in-transit.
   (a)   Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this
division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except
where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:
   Bailee and warehouse have the meanings assigned by V.T.C.A., Business and
Commerce Code § 7.102.
   Dealer's motor vehicle inventory, dealer's vessel and outboard motor
inventory, dealer's heavy equipment inventory, and retail manufactured housing
inventory have the meanings assigned by V.T.C.A., Tax Code ch. 23, subch. B
(V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 23.11 et seq.).
   Goods-in-transit means tangible personal property that:
      (1)   Is acquired in or imported into the state to be forwarded to
another location in the state or outside this state;
      (2)   Is stored under a contract of bailment by a public warehouse
operator at one or more public warehouse facilities in the state that are not
in any way owned or controlled by the owner of the personal property for the
account of the person who acquired or imported the property;
      (3)   Is transported to another location in the state or outside the
state not later than 175 days after the date the person acquired the property
in or imported the property into the state; and
      (4)   Does not include oil, natural gas, petroleum products, aircraft,
dealer's motor vehicle inventory, dealer's vessel and outboard motor inventory,
dealer's heavy equipment inventory, or retail manufactured housing inventory.
   Location means a physical address.
   Petroleum product means a liquid or gaseous material that is an immediate
derivative of the refining of oil or natural gas.
   Public warehouse operator means a person that:
      (1)   Is both a bailee and a warehouse; and
      (2)   Stores under a contract of bailment, at one or more public
warehouse facilities, tangible personal property that is owned by other persons
solely for the account of those persons and not for the operator's account.
   (b)   A person is entitled to an exemption from taxation of the appraised
value of that portion of the person's property that consists of goods-in-
transit.
   (c)   The exemption provided by subsection (b) of this section is subtracted
from the market value of the property determined under V.T.C.A., Tax Code §
23.01 or 23.12, as applicable, to determine the taxable value of the property.
   (d)   Except as provided by subsections (f) and (g) of this section, the
chief appraiser shall determine the appraised value of goods-in-transit under
this subsection. The chief appraiser shall determine the percentage of the
market value of tangible personal property owned by the property owner and used
for the production of income in the preceding calendar year that was
contributed by goods-in-transit. For the first year in which the exemption
applies to a taxing unit, the chief appraiser shall determine that percentage
as if the exemption applied in the preceding year. The chief appraiser shall
apply that percentage to the market value of the property owner's tangible
personal property used for the production of income for the current year to
determine the appraised value.
   (e)   In determining the market value of goods-in-transit that in the
preceding year were stored in the state, the chief appraiser shall exclude the
cost of equipment, machinery, or materials that entered into and became
component parts of the goods-in-transit but were not themselves goods-in-
transit or that were not transported to another location in the state or
outside the state before the expiration of 175 days after the date they were
brought into the state by the property owner or acquired by the property owner
in the state. For component parts held in bulk, the chief appraiser may use the
average length of time a component part was held by the owner of the component
parts during the preceding year at a location in the state that was not owned
by or under the control of the owner of the component parts in determining
whether the component parts were transported to another location in the state
or outside the state before the expiration of 175 days.
   (f)   If the property owner was not engaged in transporting goods-in-transit
to another location in the state or outside the state for the entire preceding
year, the chief appraiser shall calculate the percentage of the market value
described in subsection (d) of this section, for the portion of the year in
which the property owner was engaged in transporting goods-in-transit to
another location in the state or outside the state.
   (g)   If the property owner or the chief appraiser demonstrates that the
method provided by subsection (d) of this section significantly understates or
overstates the market value of the property qualified for an exemption under
subsection (b) of this section, in the current year, the chief appraiser shall
determine the market value of the goods-in-transit to be exempt by determining,
according to the property owner's records and any other available information,
the market value of those goods-in-transit owned by the property owner on
January 1 of the current year, excluding the cost of equipment, machinery, or
materials that entered into and became component parts of the goods-in-transit
but were not themselves goods-in-transit or that were not transported to
another location in the state or outside the state before the expiration of 175
days after the date they were brought into the state by the property owner or
acquired by the property owner in the state.
   (h)   The chief appraiser, by written notice delivered to a property owner
who claims an exemption under this section, may require the property owner to
provide copies of property records so the chief appraiser can determine the
amount and value of goods-in-transit and that the location in the state where
the goods-in-transit were detained for storage was not owned by or under the
control of the owner of the goods-in-transit. If the property owner fails to
deliver the information requested in the notice before the 31st day after the
date the notice is delivered to the property owner, the property owner forfeits
the right to claim or receive the exemption for that year.
   (i)   Property that meets the requirements of this section constitutes
goods-in-transit regardless of whether the person who owns the property on
January 1 is the person who transports the property to another location in the
state or outside the state.
   (j)   The governing body of a taxing unit, in the manner required for
official action by the governing body, may provide for the taxation of goods-
in-transit exempt under subsection (b) of this section and not exempt under
other law. The official action to tax the goods-in-transit must be taken before
January 1 of the first tax year in which the governing body proposes to tax
goods-in-transit. Before acting to tax the exempt property, the governing body
of the taxing unit must conduct a public hearing as required by section 1-n(d),
article VIII, of the state constitution. If the governing body of a taxing unit
provides for the taxation of the goods-in-transit as provided by this
subsection, the exemption prescribed by subsection (b) of this section does not
apply to that unit. The goods-in-transit remain subject to taxation by the
taxing unit until the governing body of the taxing unit, in the manner required
for official action, rescinds or repeals its previous action to tax goods-in-
transit, or otherwise determines that the exemption prescribed by subsection
(b) of this section will apply to that taxing unit.
      (1)   Notwithstanding this subsection (j) or official action that was
taken under that subsection before October 1, 2011, to tax goods-in-transit
exempt under subsection (b) of this section and not exempt under other law, a
taxing unit may not tax such goods-in-transit in a tax year that begins on or
after January 1, 2012, unless the governing body of the taxing unit takes
action on or after October 1, 2011, in the manner required for official action
by the governing body, to provide for the taxation of the goods-in-transit. The
official action to tax the goods-in-transit must be taken before January 1 of
the first tax year in which the governing body proposes to tax goods-in-
transit. Before acting to tax the exempt property, the governing body of the
taxing unit must conduct a public hearing as required by section 1-n(d),
article VIII, of the state constitution. If the governing body of a taxing unit
provides for the taxation of the goods-in-transit as provided by this
subsection, the exemption prescribed by subsection (b) of this section does not
apply to that unit. The goods-in-transit remain subject to taxation by the
taxing unit until the governing body of the taxing unit, in the manner required
for official action, rescinds or repeals its previous action to tax goods-in-
transit or otherwise determines that the exemption prescribed by subsection (b)
of this section will apply to that taxing unit.
      (2)   Notwithstanding subsection (j)(1) of this section, if under
subsection (j) of this section, the governing body of a taxing unit, before
October 1, 2011, took action to provide for the taxation of goods-in-transit
and pledged the taxes imposed on the goods-in-transit for the payment of a debt
of the taxing unit, the tax officials of the taxing unit may continue to impose
the taxes against the goods-in-transit until the debt is discharged, if
cessation of the imposition would impair the obligation of the contract by
which the debt was created.
(Code 2014, § 42-127; Ord. No. 700, 10-11-2011)
Secs. 42-128—42-154. Reserved.
ARTICLE VI. OCCUPATION TAX
State law reference(s)—Occupation tax, V.T.C.A., Tax Code § 191.081 et seq.
DIVISION 1. GENERALLY
Secs. 42-155—42-176. Reserved.
DIVISION 2. COIN-OPERATED MACHINES
Editor's note(s)—Ord. No. 839, adopted September 14, 2020, amended division 2
in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former division 2, §§ 42-177—42-186,
pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from Code 2014, §§ 42-177—42-
186; Ord. No. 78, §§ 1, 2, 4—10, 6-28-1948.
State law reference(s)—Coin-operated machines, V.T.C.A., Occupations Code §
2153.001 et seq.
SUBDIVISION 1. GENERALLY
Sec. 42-177. Definitions.
For the purposes of this article, the following shall apply:
   Coin-operated machine. The term "coin-operated machine" means every machine
or device of any kind or character which is operated by or with a coin, any
U.S. currency, metal slug, token, electronic card, check or similar object.
Music coin-operated machine and skill or pleasure coin-operated machines, as
hereinafter defined, including, but not limited to, coin-operated video games,
shall be included in the term "coin-operated machine".
   Music coin-operated machine. The term "music coin-operated machine" shall
mean and include every coin-operated machine of any kind or character which
dispenses or vends, or which is used or operated for dispensing or vending
music and which is operated by or with coins, metal slugs, tokens, checks or
similar objects. The following are expressly included within such terms: Coin-
operated phonographs, pianos, gramophones, radios and all other coin-operated
machines which dispense or vend music.
   Operator. The term "operator" shall mean and include any person, firm,
company, association or corporation who exhibits, displays or permits to be
exhibited or displayed, in his or its place of business or upon premises under
his or its control, any coin-operated machine in the city.
   Owner. The term "owner" means any person, individual, firm, association,
business organization or corporation owning any "coin-operated machine" in this
city. Owner is solely responsible for paying to the city the occupation tax on
each coin-operated machine exhibited or displayed with the city and for
securing the city decal evidencing payment of such tax on each coin-operated
machine.
   Service coin-operated machine. The term "service coin-operated machine"
means pay toilets, pay telephones and all other machines or devices which
dispense service only and not merchandise, music, skill or pleasure.
   Skill or pleasure coin-operated machine. The term "skill or pleasure coin-
operated machine" means every coin-operated machine or device of any kind or
character that is used or capable of use for pleasure or requires or is capable
of rewarding or recognizing some degree of user skill in its use or operation
or for any purpose other than dispersing or vending or merchandise, music or
service exclusively as those terms are defined herein. The following are
expressly included within such term: Electronic video games, marble machines or
marble table machines, pin ball machines, marble shooting machines, pachinko
machines, miniature golf machines, miniature bowling machines, coin-operated
billiard or pool table and all or any other coin-operated machines which
satisfy some sense of skill or pleasure, including but not limited to every
coin-operated machine or device that dispenses or vends merchandise, prizes,
trinkets, novelties, commodities or confections or that plays music with or in
addition to such games or devices.
(Ord. No. 839, § 42-177, 9-14-2020)
Sec. 42-178. Tax imposed; amount; registration.
   (a)   Every "owner," save an owner holding an import license and holding
coin-operated machines solely for resale, who exhibits, displays or who permits
to be exhibited or displayed in this state any coin-operated machine shall pay,
and there is hereby levied on each coin-operated machine, except those that are
exempt under section
42-180, an annual fee the maximum percentage of the State of Texas' annual
occupation tax for such devices that a city in Texas may charge, (which at this
