ARTICLE VI. WATER AND SEWER MAINS
Sec. 44-217. Water and sewer main extensions inside the city limits.
The city recognizes that new homes and businesses are often constructed within
the city as the city continues to grow and develop. In the event a citizen,
developer, business person or other individual wishes to extend water and or
sewer mains inside the city, the following policy shall apply:
      (1)   City to pay for first 100 feet. The city shall lay or construct
water or sewer lines to the property line of the property in question and shall
pay for the first 100 feet of water and sewer main extension. The balance of
the cost shall be paid by the individual, business, or corporation requesting
the water or sewer tap and requesting that the utility main be extended.
      (2)   Director of utilities or engineer to calculate cost. The director
of utilities and/or the city engineer shall calculate the overall cost of
extending the water and sewer mains and shall provide the cost estimate to the
individual, business or corporation requesting the water or sewer extension.
      (3)   Director of utilities to determine if utilities are available. The
director of utilities shall also first determine if utilities are available in
the area where water and sewer taps are requested before the city accepts
payment for the water and sewer taps. In the event water and sewer mains are
available, the city shall accept the funds for the water and sewer taps. Water
and sewer taps are then to be scheduled by the director of utilities.
      (4)   If mains are unavailable. In the event water and sewer mains are
not available and the individual, business, or corporation wishes to have the
mains extended, then in that event the individual requesting the water and
sewer tap shall then place the full amount of funds required for the main
extensions in an escrow account with the city before any work shall begin.
      (5)   Payment of additional funds. Once the lines are completed, the
individual, business or corporation requesting the extension shall pay any
difference in funds should the cost exceed the cost estimate prior to the time
any water or sewer tap is made. In no event shall the amount due the city
exceed ten days. The city shall not be required to connect any sewer lines or
provide any sewer service until full payment has been received by the city.
      (6)   Reimbursement if required. If the initial deposit is more than the
amount of funds required to lay the line, the city shall reimburse the
individual, business or corporation requesting the extension the full amount of
overpayment. In no event shall the amount of the overpayment due to the
individual, business or corporation exceed ten days.
      (7)   Engineering and cost. All engineering if required shall be
completed by the city engineer. All construction cost, engineering cost,
surveying, staking, or other related cost shall be included in calculating the
overall cost of the project.
      (8)   Development agreement required. A development agreement shall be
prepared in all instances whereby the city is required to extend water and
sewer mains. All development agreements shall be prepared by the city attorney
and shall be approved by the city council prior to the commencement of any work
involving the extension of water and sewer mains inside the city.
      (9)   Capital improvement projects (CIP). The city may conduct capital
improvement projects as may be approved from time to time by the city council.
In the event that the city council elects to conduct specific capital
improvement projects, these CIPs may be financed by the city without cost to a
particular individual, business or corporation. Funding recommendations shall
be made by the city manager and financial advisor with the final approval of
the city council.
(Code 2014, § 44-217; Ord. No. 662, § I, 2-9-2009)
Sec. 44-218. Water and sewer main extensions outside the city limits.
The city recognizes that new homes and businesses are often constructed outside
the city limits as the area continues to grow and develop. In the event a
citizen, developer, business person or other individual wishes to extend water
and or sewer mains outside the city limits, the following policy shall apply:
      (1)   Payment of 100 percent of all cost. The city shall lay or construct
water or sewer lines to the property line of the property in question; however,
the individual, business, corporation or developer requesting that the water
and sewer main be extended shall be responsible for paying for 100 percent of
all cost associated with extending the water and sewer mains.
      (2)   Director of utilities or engineer to calculate cost. The director
of utilities and/or the city engineer shall calculate the overall cost of
extending the water and sewer mains and shall provide the cost estimate to the
individual, business or corporation requesting the water or sewer extension.
      (3)   Director of utilities to determine if utilities are available. The
director of utilities shall also first determine if utilities are available in
the area where water and sewer taps are requested before the city accepts
payment for the water and sewer taps. In the event water and sewer mains are
available, the city shall accept the funds for the water and sewer taps. Water
and sewer taps are then to be scheduled by the director of utilities.
      (4)   If mains are unavailable. In the event water and sewer mains are
not available and the individual, business, or corporation wishes to have the
mains extended, the individual requesting the water and sewer tap shall then
place the full amount of funds required for the main extension in an escrow
account with the city.
      (5)   Payment of additional funds. Once the lines are completed, the
individual, business, or corporation requesting the extension shall pay any
difference in funds should the cost exceed the cost estimate prior to the time
any water or sewer tap is made. In no event shall the amount due the city
exceed ten days. The city shall not be required to connect any sewer lines or
provide any sewer service until full payment has been received by the city.
      (6)   Reimbursement if required. If the initial deposit is more than the
amount of funds required to lay the line, the city shall reimburse the
individual, business or corporation requesting the extension the full amount of
overpayment. In no event shall the amount due exceed ten days.
      (7)   Engineering and cost. All engineering if required shall be
completed by the city engineer. All construction cost, engineering cost,
surveying, staking, or other related cost shall be included in calculating the
overall cost of the project.
      (8)   Development agreement required. A development agreement shall be
prepared in all instances whereby the city is required to extend water and
sewer mains. All development agreements shall be prepared by the city attorney
and shall be approved by the city council prior to the commencement of any work
involving the extension of water and sewer mains outside the city.
      (9)   Capital improvement projects (CIP). The city may conduct capital
improvement projects as may be approved from time to time by the city council.
In the event that the city council elects to conduct specific capital
improvement projects, these projects may be financed by the city without cost
to a particular individual, business or corporation. Funding recommendations
shall be made by the city manager and financial advisor with the final approval
of the city council.
(Code 2014, § 44-218; Ord. No. 662, § II, 2-9-2009)
Chapter 46 ZONING
State law reference(s)—Zoning, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 211.001 et
seq.
ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL
Sec. 46-1. Title.
This chapter shall be known and may be cited as the "City of Madisonville
Zoning Ordinance."
(Code 2014, § 46-1; Ord. No. 629, § 01.01.002, 12-1-2006)
Sec. 46-2. Purpose.
The zoning regulations and districts as herein established have been made in
accordance with adopted guiding principles for the purpose of promoting the
health, safety, morals, and general welfare of the city (hereinafter referred
to as "city"). They have been designed to lessen the congestion in the streets;
to secure safety from fire, panic, and other dangers; to ensure adequate light
and air; to prevent the overcrowding of land; to avoid undue concentration of
population; to facilitate the adequate provision of transportation, water,
sewerage, schools, parks, and other public regulations. They have been made
with reasonable consideration, among other things, for the character of the
district, and its suitability and compatibility for the particular uses
specified; and with a view to conserving the value of buildings and
neighborhoods, and encouraging the most appropriate use of land throughout the
city.
(Code 2014, § 46-2; Ord. No. 629, § 01.01.003, 12-1-2006)
Sec. 46-3. Repeal.
Existing ordinances and parts of ordinances in conflict with this chapter are
repealed.
(Code 2014, § 46-3; Ord. No. 629, § 01.01.004, 12-1-2006)
Secs. 46-4—46-24. Reserved.
ARTICLE II. GENERAL COMPLIANCE
Sec. 46-25. Required.
   (a)   All land, buildings, structures, or appurtenances located thereon
within the city which are hereafter occupied, used, erected, altered, removed,
placed, demolished, or converted shall be occupied, used, erected, altered,
removed, placed, demolished, or converted in conformance with the zoning
regulations prescribed for the zoning district in which such land or building
is located as hereinafter provided or be subject to penalties as stated in
section
46-986.
   (b)   All dwellings moved in the city must have prior approval of the city
manager or his designee.
   (c)   Approved old dwellings moved in the city shall comply with the masonry
regulations of the zoning district and underpinned completely of masonry or
stone within 60 days after moved in to give appearance of looking new.
   (d)   Unless specifically provided for in this chapter, all buildings shall
obtain a building permit from the city.
(Code 2014, § 46-25; Ord. No. 629, § 01.02.001, 12-1-2006)
Sec. 46-26. Regulations for the lot.
   (a)   No yard, setback, or other open space provided around any building for
the purpose of complying with provisions of this chapter and the city's
subdivision regulations set forth in chapter 40 shall be considered as
providing a yard or open space for a building on any other lot.
   (b)   Any single-family residence with the "Retail District (R)”, "Office
District (O)”, “General Business District (GB)” or “Commercial Services
District (CS)" that has been used as a commercial building may be returned to a
single-family residence should the commercial use no longer be in use. The
building shall be inspected by the Building Official first and a new
certificate of occupancy issued before being occupied as a single-family
residence.
(Code 2014, § 46-26; Ord. No. 629, § 01.02.002, 12-1-2006; Ord. No. 794, §
01.02.002, 6-12-2017)
Sec. 46-27. Portable and temporary buildings during construction.
Portable or temporary buildings shall be permitted for uses incidental to
constructing permanent structures on the premises. Such portable or temporary
buildings shall conform to and comply with all applicable ordinances, and shall
be removed no later than 30 days after the completion or abandonment of
construction work. No temporary living quarters shall be permitted in such
portable or temporary buildings.
(Code 2014, § 46-27; Ord. No. 629, § 01.02.003, 12-1-2006)
Sec. 46-28. Manufactured homes prohibited on certain property.
   (a)   One manufactured home or principal building is allowed per lot in the
Manufactured Home Residential District (MH).
   (b)   All lots or property with a street frontage address located in a non-
manufactured home zone residential district shall not have a manufactured home
on that property or lot, even if that property or lot extends to other property
owned by the same owner that is located in a lot that is within a Manufactured
Home Residential District (MH). The address will define the zone.
   (c)   Any person or corporation violating any of the provisions of this
section shall, upon conviction, be fined any sum not exceeding $1,000.00 for
each and every day that the provisions of this section are violated and each
violation shall constitute a separate and distinct offense. In addition to said
penalty provided for, the right is hereby conferred and extended upon any
property owner owning property in any district, where such property owner may
be affected or invaded, by a violation of the terms of this section, to bring
suit in such court having jurisdiction thereof and obtain such remedies as may
be available by law and equity in the protection of the rights of such property
owners.
(Ord. No. 816, §§ 1, 2, 1-14-2019)
Sec. 46-29. Manufactured home replacement.
An owner of a manufactured home presently as of the effective date of this
Ordinance on a city lot shall be allowed to remove the manufactured home from
its location and place another manufactured home on the same property, provided
that the replacement is a newer manufactured home no older than 20 years of age
from the date of the installation of the manufactured home, and is at least as
large in living space as the prior manufactured home. Other than in the case of
a fire or natural disaster, replacement of a manufactured home by an owner is
limited to a single replacement. A mobile home may not be replaced by a
manufactured home. Any permit for replacement or removal of a manufactured home
required by law shall be in addition to the requirements of this ordinance.
(Ord. No. 851, § 1, 6-13-2022)
Editor's note(s)—Ord. No. 851, § 1, adopted June 13, 2022, set out new
provisions but did not specify manner of inclusion. Therefore, at the
discretion of the editor, these provisions have been included as §
46-29.
Secs. 46-30—46-57. Reserved.
ARTICLE III. ESTABLISHMENT OF ZONING DISTRICTS AND BOUNDARIES
State law reference(s)—Districts, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 211.035 et
seq.
Sec. 46-58. Zoning district map.
The boundaries of zoning districts set out herein are delineated upon a zoning
district map of the city, adopted as part of this article as fully as if the
same were set forth herein in detail.
      (1)   One original of the zoning district map shall be filed in the
office of the city secretary. This document shall be the official zoning
district map and shall bear the signature of the mayor and attestation of the
city secretary. This copy shall not be changed in any manner. In case of any
question, this document, together with any amending ordinances, shall be
controlling.
      (2)   A copy of the original zoning district map shall be placed in the
office of the city manager or a designee. The copy shall be used for reference
and shall be maintained up to date by posting thereon all subsequent amendments
and shall be identified as the zoning map. Reproductions for informational
purposes may be made of the zoning map.
(Code 2014, § 46-58; Ord. No. 629, § 01.03.001, 12-1-2006)
Sec. 46-59. Zoning district boundaries.
The zoning district boundary lines shown on the zoning district map are usually
along streets, alleys, property lines, or extensions thereof. Where uncertainty
exists as to the boundaries of districts as shown on the zoning district map,
the following rules shall apply:
      (1)   Boundaries indicated as approximately following the centerline of
streets, highways, or alleys shall be construed to follow such centerline.
      (2)   Boundaries indicated as approximately following platted lot lines
shall be construed as following such lot lines.
      (3)   Boundaries indicated as approximately following city limits shall
be construed as following city limits.
      (4)   Boundaries indicated as following railroad lines shall be construed
to be midway between the right-of-way lines.
      (5)   Boundaries indicated as parallel to or extensions of features
indicated in subsections (1) through (4) of this section shall be so construed.
Distances not specifically indicated on the original zoning map shall be
determined by the scale of the map.
      (6)   Whenever any street, alley, or other public way is vacated by
official action of the city council or whenever such area is franchised for
building purposes, the zoning district line adjoining each side of such street,
alley, or other public way shall be automatically extended to the centerline of
such vacated street, alley, or way and all areas so involved shall then and
henceforth be subject to all regulations of the extended districts.
      (7)   The zoning classification applied to a tract of land adjacent to a
street shall extend to the centerline of the street unless as a condition of
zoning approval it is stated that the zoning classification shall not apply to
the street.
      (8)   Where physical features on the ground are at variance with
information shown on the official zoning district map or when there arises a
question as to how or whether a parcel of property is zoned and such question
cannot be resolved by the application of subsections (1) through (7) of this
section, the property shall be considered as classified Rural/Agricultural
District (RA), in the same manner as provided for newly annexed territory.
      (9)   Permanent zoning changes made after the date of passage of the
ordinance from which this article is derived are indicated in approximate
locations on the zoning district map. For exact legal descriptions, refer to
the adopting ordinance amendment for each particular permanent zoning change.
(Code 2014, § 46-59; Ord. No. 629, § 01.03.002, 12-1-2006)
State law reference(s)—Districts, V.T.C.A., Local Government Code § 211.035 et
seq.
Sec. 46-60. Zoning upon annexation.
   (a)   Any territory hereafter annexed to the city and brought within its
corporate limits shall be assigned a zoning classification upon annexation
appropriate to its existing use in accordance with the procedures required by
state law and this article, or shall be governed by the following regulations
pending establishment of permanent zoning on such territory. In the event that
these temporary regulations become applicable and no requests for permanent
zoning classification have been made by the property owners within one year of
the date of annexation, the planning and zoning commission shall initiate a
request for permanent classification using the procedures established in this
article.
   (b)   The following regulations are applicable to all property not assigned
a permanent zoning classification at the time of annexation:
      (1)   No person shall erect, construct, proceed, or continue with the
erection or construction of any building or structure, or cause the same to be
done in any newly-annexed territory to the city without first applying for and
obtaining a building permit or certificate of occupancy.
      (2)   No permit for the construction of a building or use of land shall
be issued other than a permit which will allow the construction of a building
or use permitted in the Rural/Agricultural District (RA), unless and until such
territory has been classified in a zoning district other than the Rural/
Agricultural District (RA), by the city council in the manner prescribed by
this article.
      (3)   The planning and zoning commission shall hold a public hearing on
original zoning for all territory recently annexed or proposed for annexation.
At least 15 days' notice of the time and place of such hearing shall be
published in the official paper of the city and written notice of all such
public hearings shall be sent to all owners of real property lying within 200
feet of the property on which the original zoning is proposed not less than ten
days before the day set for the hearing.
      (4)   After such hearing, the planning and zoning commission shall make
its recommendation to the city council regarding the original zoning of the
annexed territory.
      (5)   After receiving the recommendation of the planning and zoning
commission, the city council shall hold a public hearing at the earliest
practicable time at which parties in interest and citizens shall have an
opportunity to be heard. At least 15 days' notice of the time and place of such
hearing shall be published in the official paper of the city.
      (6)   Except as provided in this article, the procedure for the zoning of
annexed areas shall be the same as is provided by law for the adoption of
original zoning regulations.
(Code 2014, § 46-60; Ord. No. 629, § 01.03.003, 12-1-2006)
Sec. 46-61. Districts established.
For the purpose of this article, the city is hereby divided into districts as
follows:
Residential
RA   Rural/Agricultural District (RA)
ES   Estate Single-Family Residential District (ES)
SF-1 Large Lot Single-Family Residential District (SF-1)
SF-2 Urban Lot Single-Family Residential District (SF-2)
MH   Manufactured Home Residential District (MH)
MF   Multifamily Residential District (MF)
Office, Retail, Commercial
O    Office District (O)
R    Retail District (R)
GB   General Business District (GB)
CS   Commercial Services District (CS)
Industrial
GI   General Industrial District (GI)
HI   Heavy Industrial District (HI)
Special Districts
DT   Downtown District (DT)
CO   Corridor Overlay District (CO)
PD   Planned Development District (PD)
 
(Code 2014, § 46-61; Ord. No. 629, § 01.03.004, 12-1-2006)
Sec. 46-62. Restrictive hierarchy of districts established.
For purposes of this article, the city council can consider zoning districts of
any intensity in cases of assigning original zoning to a property. However, in
the case of a request to change the zoning assigned to a property, the council
can consider only the zoning requested, an equivalent zoning district, or a
more restrictive district.
(Code 2014, § 46-62; Ord. No. 629, § 01.03.005, 12-1-2006)
Secs. 46-63—46-82. Reserved.
ARTICLE IV. RURAL/AGRICULTURAL DISTRICT (RA)
Sec. 46-83. Purpose.
The RA district is intended to provide a location for principally undeveloped
or vacant land situated on the fringe of an urban area and used primarily for
agricultural purposes, but may become an urban area in the future. Generally,
the Rural/Agricultural District (RA) will be near development, therefore the
agricultural activities conducted in the Rural/Agricultural District (RA)
should not be detrimental to urban land uses. The types of uses, area, and
intensity of uses permitted in this district encourage and protect agricultural
uses until urbanization is warranted and the appropriate change in district
classification is made. The Rural/Agricultural District (RA) is also intended
to protect areas that may be unsuitable for development because of physical
problems, lack of infrastructure, space constraints, or potential health or
safety hazards, such as flooding, as well as providing for preservation of
natural open space areas.
(Code 2014, § 46-83; Ord. No. 629, § 01.04.001, 12-1-2006)
Sec. 46-84. Permitted uses.
The uses permitted in the Rural/Agriculture District (RA) are as follows:
      (1)   Accessory structures (refer to section
46-734).
      (2)   Accessory dwelling units (refer to section
46-735).
      (3)   Detached dwelling.
      (4)   Essential municipal uses.
      (5)   Farm, gardening, ranch, and agricultural operations, including
field crops, orchards, horticulture, animal husbandry, but not including feed
lots and poultry farms.
      (6)   Home occupations.
      (7)   Landscape service (with open storage).
      (8)   Nursery (greenhouse).
      (9)   Place of worship.
      (10)   Servant's quarters and quarters used by bona fide farm workers, or
other accessory buildings such as barns, sheds, and other structures necessary
for farming operations may be permitted; provided, however, that no such
accessory building or quarters to be used by servants or farm workers shall be
occupied as a place of abode or dwelling by anyone other than a bona fide
servant or farm worker actually regularly employed on the premises by the
landowner or occupant of the main building.
      (11)   Stables, commercial (subject to the rules and regulations of the
state health department).
      (12)   Stables, private (subject to the rules and regulations of the
state health department).
      (13)   Buildings shall be removed upon the completion or abandonment of
construction work.
(Code 2014, § 46-84; Ord. No. 629, § 01.04.002, 12-1-2006; Ord. No. 818, § 1,
2-11-2019)
Sec. 46-85. Conditional uses.
The following are conditional uses in the Rural/Agricultural District (RA):
      (1)   Bed and breakfast;
      (2)   Manufactured homes on individual lots;
      (3)   Municipal services support facilities;
      (4)   Produce stand (seasonal);
(Code 2014, § 46-85; Ord. No. 629, § 01.04.003, 12-1-2006; Ord. No. 818, § 1,
2-11-2019)
Sec. 46-86. Density regulations.
One principal building is allowed per lot in the Rural/Agricultural District
(RA).
(Code 2014, § 46-86; Ord. No. 629, § 01.04.004, 12-1-2006)
Sec. 46-87. Height regulations.
The following height regulations apply in the Rural/Agricultural District (RA):
      (1)   The maximum allowable height is 35 feet.
      (2)   No agricultural structure shall exceed 60 feet in height.
(Code 2014, § 46-87; Ord. No. 629, § 01.04.005, 12-1-2006)
Sec. 46-88. Setback regulations.
The following setback regulations apply in the Rural/Agricultural District
(RA):
      (1)   Front setback shall have a minimum of 25 feet.
      (2)   Side setback shall have a minimum of 20 feet.
      (3)   Side setback adjacent to a street shall have a minimum of 25 feet.
      (4)   Rear setback shall have a minimum of 25 feet.
(Code 2014, § 46-88; Ord. No. 629, § 01.04.006, 12-1-2006)
Sec. 46-89. Lot regulations.
The following lot regulations apply in the Rural/Agricultural District (RA):
      (1)   The minimum lot size shall be five acres.
      (2)   The minimum lot width shall be 150 feet.
      (3)   The minimum lot depth shall be 300 feet.
(Code 2014, § 46-89; Ord. No. 629, § 01.04.007, 12-1-2006)
Sec. 46-90. Off-street parking regulations.
The applicable off-street parking regulations for the Rural/Agricultural
District (RA) are as provided in article XIX of this chapter.
(Code 2014, § 46-90; Ord. No. 629, § 01.04.008, 12-1-2006)
Sec. 46-91. Regulations specific to this district.
The following regulations are specific to the Rural/Agricultural District (RA):
      (1)   Livestock and poultry shall be confined to the boundaries of the
property.
      (2)   No temporary structures, such as recreational vehicles, travel
trailers, construction trailers, or mobile homes may be used for on-site
dwelling purposes.
(Code 2014, § 46-91; Ord. No. 629, § 01.04.009, 12-1-2006)
Sec. 46-92. Landscaping regulations.
The applicable landscaping regulations for the Rural/Agricultural District (RA)
are as provided in article XX of this chapter.
(Code 2014, § 46-92; Ord. No. 629, § 01.04.010, 12-1-2006)
Sec. 46-93. Sign regulations.
The applicable sign regulations for the Rural/Agricultural District (RA) are as
provided in sections 34-116 and 34-117.
Secs. 46-94—46-112. Reserved.
ARTICLE V. ESTATE SINGLE-FAMILY RESIDENTIAL DISTRICT (ES)
Note(s)—H.B. 2439 of the 86th legislative session has removed a municipalities
ability to require that certain building materials are used in construction.
Sec. 46-113. Purpose.
The Estate Single-Family Residential District (ES) is intended to be composed
of detached, single-family dwelling units on estate-sized and ranchette-style
lots. Single-family dwellings are designed primarily for residential use and do
not easily lend themselves to other types of nonresidential uses. Other uses
may be permitted in this district which are compatible to single-family uses
and occupy structures designed for their intended use and do not infringe upon
the residential uses.
(Code 2014, § 46-113; Ord. No. 629, § 01.05.001, 12-1-2006)
Sec. 46-114. Permitted uses.
The uses permitted in the Estate Single-Family Residential District (ES) are as
follows:
      (1)   Accessory structures (refer to section
46-734).
      (2)   Detached dwelling units.
      (3)   Essential municipal uses.
      (4)   Group home/community homes.
      (5)   Government (federal or state) owned structures, facilities, and
uses.
      (6)   Home occupations.
      (7)   Livestock/poultry.
      (8)   Places of worship.
      (9)   Private utilities (no storage yards).
      (10)   Real estate sales offices during the development of residential
subdivisions, but not to exceed three years.
      (11)   Schools.
      (12)   Temporary structures for uses incidental to construction work on
the premises, which said buildings shall be removed upon the completion or
abandonment of construction work.
(Code 2014, § 46-114; Ord. No. 629, § 01.05.002, 12-1-2006)
Sec. 46-115. Conditional uses.
The conditional uses permitted in the Estate Single-Family Residential District
(ES) are as follows:
      (1)   Accessory dwelling unit (refer to section
46-735).
      (2)   Accessory structure if greater than the standards set forth in
section
46-734.
      (3)   Bed and breakfast.
      (4)   Boardinghouse (lodginghouse).
      (5)   Child care, Class B.
      (6)   Country club or golf course.
      (7)   Duplex.
      (8)   Funeral home/mortuary.
      (9)   Neighborhood services.
      (10)   Nursing home (retirement home).
      (11)   Police station.
      (12)   Professional office.
      (13)   Community center/recreation center.
(Code 2014, § 46-115; Ord. No. 629, § 01.05.003, 12-1-2006)
Sec. 46-116. Density regulations.
One principal building is allowed per lot in the Estate Single-Family
Residential District (ES).
(Code 2014, § 46-116; Ord. No. 629, § 01.05.004, 12-1-2006)
Sec. 46-117. Height regulations.
The maximum allowable height is 35 feet in the Estate Single-Family Residential
District (ES).
(Code 2014, § 46-117; Ord. No. 629, § 01.05.005, 12-1-2006)
Sec. 46-118. Setback regulations.
The setback requirements in the Estate Single-Family Residential District (ES)
are as follows:
      (1)   Front setback shall have a minimum of 25 feet.
      (2)   Side setback shall have a minimum of 20 feet.
      (3)   Side setback adjacent to a street shall have a minimum of 25 feet.
      (4)   Rear setback shall have a minimum of 25 feet.
(Code 2014, § 46-118; Ord. No. 629, § 01.05.006, 12-1-2006)
Sec. 46-119. Lot regulations.
The lot regulations in the Estate Single-Family Residential District (ES) are
as follows:
      (1)   The minimum lot size shall be one acre.
      (2)   The minimum lot width shall be 100 feet.
      (3)   The minimum lot depth shall be 150 feet.
(Code 2014, § 46-119; Ord. No. 629, § 01.05.007, 12-1-2006)
Sec. 46-120. Off-street parking regulations.
The off-street parking regulations for the Estate Single-Family Residential
District (ES) are as provided in article XIX of this chapter.
(Code 2014, § 46-120; Ord. No. 629, § 01.05.008, 12-1-2006)
Sec. 46-121. Building regulations for residential uses.
Building regulations for residential uses in the Estate Single-Family
Residential District (ES) are as follows:
      (1)   No residential dwelling in the Estate Single-Family Residential
District (ES) shall be constructed or moved in which contains less than 1,500
square feet within the living area.
      (2)   Outside wall areas of a site-built or modular residential dwelling
shall have a minimum of 50 percent masonry construction consisting of stucco,
brick, ledge stone, field stone or native types of stone veneer.
      (3)   Must include a concrete, asphalt or slag driveway/parking area in
the residential districts.
      (4)   Garage conversions are permitted; however, a concrete, asphalt or
slag driveway/parking area is required in the residential districts.
(Code 2014, § 46-121; Ord. No. 629, § 01.05.009, 12-1-2006; Ord. No. 845, §§ 2,
3, 8-8-2021)
Sec. 46-122. Building regulations for nonresidential uses.
Building regulations for nonresidential uses in the Estate Single-Family
Residential District (ES) are as follows:
      (1)   Temporary buildings and buildings for agricultural purposes in the
Estate Single-Family Residential District (ES) shall be a maximum size of 750
square feet.
      (2)   Nonresidential principal buildings shall be a minimum size of 1,500
square feet.
      (3)   Outside wall areas of a site built or modular structure shall have
a minimum of 50 percent masonry construction consisting of stucco, brick, ledge
stone, field stone or native types of stone veneer.
(Code 2014, § 46-122; Ord. No. 629, § 01.05.010, 12-1-2006)
Sec. 46-123. Regulations specific to this district.
The following regulations are applicable to the Estate Single-Family
Residential District (ES):
      (1)   Personal livestock and poultry shall be confined to the boundaries
of the property. Livestock shall be limited to one with an additional one per
acre of land.
      (2)   Domestic animals over the age of six months shall be limited to
three per species and a total of six per household.
      (3)   Open storage is prohibited, except for materials for the resident's
personal use or consumption i.e., firewood, gardening materials, etc.
      (4)   No temporary structures, such as recreational vehicles, travel
trailers, construction trailers, or mobile homes may be used for on-site
dwelling purposes.
      (5)   Duplex dwellings permitted conditionally in this district shall
conform to standards as specified in article XXIV of this chapter.
(Code 2014, § 46-123; Ord. No. 629, § 01.05.011, 12-1-2006; Ord. No. 743, § 1,
4-14-2014)
Sec. 46-124. Landscaping regulations.
The applicable landscaping regulations for the Estate Single-Family Residential
District (ES) are as provided in article XX of this chapter.
(Code 2014, § 46-124; Ord. No. 629, § 01.05.012, 12-1-2006)
Sec. 46-125. Sign regulations.
The applicable sign regulations for the Estate Single-Family Residential
District (ES) are as provided in sections
34-116 and
34-117.
Secs. 46-126—46-146. Reserved.
ARTICLE VI. LARGE SINGLE-FAMILY RESIDENTIAL DISTRICT (SF-1)
Note(s)—H.B. 2439 of the 86th legislative session has removed a municipalities
ability to require that certain building materials are used in construction.
Sec. 46-147. Purpose.
The Large Single-Family Residential District (SF-1) is intended to be composed
of detached dwelling units on lots of not less than 8,000 square feet. Detached
dwelling units are designed primarily for residential use and do not easily
lend themselves to other types of nonresidential uses. Other uses may be
permitted in this district which are compatible to residential uses and occupy
structures designed for their intended use and do not infringe upon the
residential uses.
(Code 2014, § 46-147; Ord. No. 629, § 01.06.001, 12-1-2006)
Sec. 46-148. Permitted uses.
Permitted uses for the Large Single-Family Residential District (SF-1) are as
follows:
      (1)   Accessory structures (refer to section
46-734).
      (2)   Detached dwelling units.
      (3)   Essential municipal uses.
      (4)   Group home/community homes.
      (5)   Government (federal or state) owned structures, facilities, and
uses.
      (6)   Home occupations.
      (7)   Places of worship.
      (8)   Private utilities (no storage yards).
      (9)   Real estate sales offices during the development of residential
subdivisions, but not to exceed three years.
      (10)   Schools.
      (11)   Temporary structures for uses incidental to construction work on
the premises, which said buildings shall be removed upon the completion or
abandonment of construction work
(Code 2014, § 46-148; Ord. No. 629, § 01.06.002, 12-1-2006)
Sec. 46-149. Conditional uses.
Conditional uses for the Large Single-Family Residential District (SF-1) are as
follows:
      (1)   Accessory dwelling unit (refer to section
46-735).
      (2)   Accessory structure (if greater than the standards set forth in
section
46-734).
      (3)   Bed and breakfast.
      (4)   Boardinghouse (lodginghouse).
      (5)   Child care, Class C.
      (6)   Country club or golf course.
      (7)   Duplex.
      (8)   Funeral home/mortuary.
      (9)   Neighborhood services.
      (10)   Nursing home (retirement home).
      (11)   Patio home (zero lot line dwelling).
      (12)   Police station.
      (13)   Professional offices.
      (14)   Community center/recreation center.
      (15)   Townhouses.
(Code 2014, § 46-149; Ord. No. 629, § 01.06.003, 12-1-2006; Ord. No. 704, §
01.06.003, 8-13-2012)
Sec. 46-150. Density regulations.
One principal building is allowed per lot in the Large Single-Family
Residential District (SF-1).
(Code 2014, § 46-150; Ord. No. 629, § 01.06.004, 12-1-2006)
Sec. 46-151. Height regulations.
The maximum allowable height in the Large Single-Family Residential District
(SF-1) is 35 feet.
(Code 2014, § 46-151; Ord. No. 629, § 01.06.005, 12-1-2006)
Sec. 46-152. Setback regulations.
Setback regulations in the Large Single-Family Residential District (SF-1) are
as follows:
      (1)   Front setback shall have a minimum of 25 feet.
      (2)   Side setback shall have a minimum of ten feet.
      (3)   Side setback adjacent to a street shall have a minimum of 15 feet.
      (4)   Rear setback shall have a minimum of ten feet.
(Code 2014, § 46-152; Ord. No. 629, § 01.06.006, 12-1-2006)
Sec. 46-153. Lot regulations.
The lot regulations for the Large Single-Family Residential District (SF-1) are
as follows:
      (1)   The minimum lot size shall be 8,000 square feet.
      (2)   The minimum lot width shall be 60 feet.
      (3)   The minimum lot depth shall be 125 feet.
(Code 2014, § 46-153; Ord. No. 629, § 01.06.007, 12-1-2006)
Sec. 46-154. Off-street parking regulations.
See article XIX of this chapter for off-street parking regulations.
(Code 2014, § 46-154; Ord. No. 629, § 01.06.008, 12-1-2006)
Sec. 46-155. Building regulations for residential uses.
The building regulations for residential uses in the Large Single-Family
Residential District (SF-1) are as follows:
      (1)   No residential dwelling shall be constructed or moved in which
contains less than 1,200 square feet within the living area.
      (2)   Outside wall areas of a site-built or modular residential dwelling
shall have a minimum of 50 percent masonry construction consisting of stucco,
brick, ledge stone, field stone or native types of stone veneer.
      (3)   Must include a concrete, asphalt or slag driveway/parking area in
the residential districts.
      (4)   Garage conversions are permitted; however, a concrete, asphalt or
slag driveway/parking area is required in the residential districts.
(Code 2014, § 46-155; Ord. No. 629, § 01.06.009, 12-1-2006; Ord. No. 845, §§ 2,
3, 8-8-2021)
Sec. 46-156. Building regulations for nonresidential uses.
The building regulations for nonresidential uses for the Large Single-Family
Residential District (SF-1) are as follows:
      (1)   Temporary buildings and buildings for agricultural purposes shall
be a maximum size of 750 square feet.
      (2)   Nonresidential principal buildings shall be a minimum size of 1,200
square feet.
(Code 2014, § 46-156; Ord. No. 629, § 01.06.010, 12-1-2006; Ord. No. 704, §
01.006.010, 8-13-2012)
Sec. 46-157. Regulations specific to this district.
The regulations specific to the Large Single-Family Residential District (SF-1)
are as follows:
      (1)   Domestic animals over the age of six months shall be limited to
three per species and a total of six per household.
      (2)   Livestock associated with approved student projects sponsored by
FFA (Future Farmers of America), 4H, and other agricultural education programs
are permitted.
      (3)   No temporary structures, such as recreational vehicles, travel
trailers, construction trailers, or mobile homes may be used for on-site
dwelling purposes.
      (4)   Open storage is prohibited, except for materials for the resident's
personal use or consumption i.e., firewood, gardening materials, etc.
      (5)   Duplex, patio home, and townhouse dwellings permitted conditionally
in this district shall conform to standards as specified in article XXIV of
this chapter.
(Code 2014, § 46-157; Ord. No. 629, § 01.06.011, 12-1-2006; Ord. No. 743, § 1,
4-14-2014)
Sec. 46-158. Landscaping regulations.
The applicable landscaping regulations for the Large Single-Family Residential
District (SF-1) are as provided in article XX of this chapter.
(Code 2014, § 46-158; Ord. No. 629, § 01.06.012, 12-1-2006)
Sec. 46-159. Sign regulations.
The applicable sign regulations for the Large Single-Family Residential
District (SF-1) are as provided in sections
34-116 and
34-117.
Secs. 46-160—46-184. Reserved.
ARTICLE VII. URBAN SINGLE-FAMILY RESIDENTIAL DISTRICT (SF-2)
Note(s)—H.B. 2439 of the 86th legislative session has removed a municipalities
ability to require that certain building materials are used in construction.
Sec. 46-185. Purpose.
The Urban Single-Family Residential District (SF-2) is intended to provide for
standard urban-sized lots that allow for low density single-family residential
developments at a more compact urban scale. Other uses, such as religious and
educational facilities, and open spaces, are provided to maintain a balanced,
orderly, convenient, and attractive residential area.
(Code 2014, § 46-185; Ord. No. 629, § 01.07.001, 12-1-2006)
Sec. 46-186. Permitted uses.
   Any use permitted in Urban Single-Family Residential District (SF-1) is
permitted in the SF-2 Urban Single-Family Residential District.
(Code 2014, § 46-186; Ord. No. 629, § 01.07.002, 12-1-2006)
Sec. 46-187. Conditional uses.
Any conditional use listed in Large Single-Family Residential District (SF-1),
with the addition of halfway house, is permitted in the Urban Single-Family
Residential District (SF-2).
(Code 2014, § 46-187; Ord. No. 629, § 01.07.003, 12-1-2006)
Sec. 46-188. Density regulations.
One principal building is allowed per lot in the Urban Single-Family
Residential District (SF-2).
(Code 2014, § 46-188; Ord. No. 629, § 01.07.004, 12-1-2006)
Sec. 46-189. Height regulations.
The maximum allowable height in the Urban Single-Family Residential District
(SF-2) is 35 feet.
(Code 2014, § 46-189; Ord. No. 629, § 01.07.005, 12-1-2006)
Sec. 46-190. Setback regulations.
The setback regulations in the Urban Single-Family Residential District (SF-2)
are as follows:
      (1)   Front setback shall have a minimum of 25 feet.
      (2)   Side setback shall have a minimum of five feet.
      (3)   Side setback adjacent to a street shall have a minimum of 15 feet.
      (4)   Rear setback shall have a minimum of ten feet.
(Code 2014, § 46-190; Ord. No. 629, § 01.07.006, 12-1-2006)
Sec. 46-191. Lot regulations.
The lot regulations in the Urban Single-Family Residential District (SF-2) are
as follows:
      (1)   The minimum lot size shall be 5,000 square feet.
      (2)   The minimum lot width shall be 50 feet.
      (3)   The minimum lot depth shall be 100 feet.
      (4)   All corner lots shall consist of 1,000 square feet more than the
minimum interior lot size.
(Code 2014, § 46-191; Ord. No. 629, § 01.07.007, 12-1-2006)
Sec. 46-192. Off-street parking regulations.
The off-street parking regulations for the Urban Single-Family Residential
District (SF-2) are as provided in article XIX of this chapter.
(Code 2014, § 46-192; Ord. No. 629, § 01.07.008, 12-1-2006)
Sec. 46-193. Building regulations for residential uses.
The building regulations for residential uses in the Urban Single-Family
Residential District (SF-2) are as follows:
      (1)   No residential dwelling shall be constructed or moved in which
contains less than 1,000 square feet within the living area.
      (2)   Must include a concrete, asphalt or slag driveway/parking area in
the residential districts.
      (3)   Garage conversions are permitted; however, a concrete, asphalt or
slag driveway/parking area is required in the residential districts.
(Code 2014, § 46-193; Ord. No. 629, § 01.07.009, 12-1-2006; Ord. No. 845, §§ 2,
3, 8-8-2021)
Sec. 46-194. Building regulations for nonresidential uses.
The building regulations for nonresidential uses in the Urban Single-Family
Residential District (SF-2) are as follows:
      (1)   Temporary buildings and buildings for agricultural purposes shall
be a maximum size of 500 square feet.
      (2)   Nonresidential principal buildings shall be a minimum size of 1,000
square feet.
      (3)   Nonresidential uses, in this district, with the exception of parks,
shall be located on a corner lot with driveway access directly onto a collector
or arterial street.
(Code 2014, § 46-194; Ord. No. 629, § 01.07.010, 12-1-2006)
Sec. 46-195. Regulations specific to this district.
The regulations to this district Urban Single-Family Residential District (SF-
2) are as follows:
      (1)   Domestic animals over the age of six months shall be limited to
three per species and a total of six per household.
      (2)   Open storage is prohibited, except for materials for the resident's
personal use or consumption, i.e., firewood, gardening materials, etc.
      (3)   Livestock associated with approved student projects sponsored by
FFA, 4H, and other agricultural education programs are permitted.
      (4)   No temporary structures, such as recreational vehicles, travel
trailers, construction trailers, or mobile homes may be used for on-site
dwelling purposes.
      (5)   Duplex, patio home, and townhouse dwellings permitted conditionally
in this district shall conform to standards as specified in article XXIV of
this chapter.
(Code 2014, § 46-195; Ord. No. 629, § 01.07.011, 12-1-2006; Ord. No. 743, § 1,
4-14-2014)
Sec. 46-196. Landscaping regulations.
The applicable landscaping regulations for the Urban Single-Family Residential
District (SF-2) are as provided in article XX of this chapter.
(Code 2014, § 46-196; Ord. No. 629, § 01.07.012, 12-1-2006)
Sec. 46-197. Sign regulations.
The applicable sign regulations for the Urban Single-Family Residential

ARTICLE VIII. MANUFACTURED HOME RESIDENTIAL DISTRICT (MH)
Note(s)—H.B. 2439 of the 86th legislative session has removed a municipalities
ability to require that certain building materials are used in construction.
State law reference(s)—Manufactured housing regulations, V.T.C.A., Occupations
Code § 1201.001 et seq.; regulation of manufactured home communities, V.T.C.A.,
Local Government Code § 214.906.
Sec. 46-216. Purpose.
The Manufactured Home Residential District (MH) is a special and unique zoning
district which will be appropriate to smaller lots in relatively few areas of
the city. The uses in the MH district are envisioned to be primarily single-
family detached dwellings. Due to the age, previous platting, and subdivision
patterns, and location of these areas, they contain a variety of residential
types and uses. This district allows manufactured homes on individual lots and
certain other dwelling types. Most of the areas zoned for MH already have a
high percentage of mixed residential uses. The use of this district is limited
predominantly to areas platted and containing a variety of residential uses.
(Code 2014, § 46-216; Ord. No. 629, § 01.08.001, 12-1-2006)
Sec. 46-217. Permitted uses.
   All uses permitted in a SF-2 zoning district with the addition of:
manufactured homes on individual lots.
(Code 2014, § 46-217; Ord. No. 629, § 01.08.002, 12-1-2006; Ord. No. 798, §
01.08.002, 9-11-2017)
Sec. 46-218. Conditional uses.
   All uses permitted in a SF-2 zoning district with the addition of: temporary
purposes to allow the owner of a tract or lot of land to place a manufactured
home during the construction of a permanent dwelling, not to exceed 365 days.
(Code 2014, § 46-218; Ord. No. 629, § 01.08.003, 12-1-2006; Ord. No. 798, §
01.08.003, 9-11-2017)
Sec. 46-219. Density regulations.
   (a)   One manufactured home or principal building is allowed per lot in the
Manufactured Home Residential District (MH).
   (b)   Any lot or property located in the Manufactured Home Residential
District (MH) shall not be subdivided, in any way without written approval of
both the city planning and zoning commission and the city council in accordance
with the provisions of the city's zoning ordinances.
   (c)   All lots or property with a street frontage address located in a non-
manufactured home zone residential district shall not have manufactured home on
that property or lot, even if that property or lot extends to other property
owned by the same owner that is located in a lot that is within a Manufactured
Home Residential District (MH). The address will define the zone.
   (d)   Any person or corporation violating any of the provisions of this
section shall, upon conviction, be fined any sum not exceeding $1,000.00 for
each and every day that the provisions of this section are violated and each
violation shall constitute a separate and distinct offense. In addition to the
penalty provided for, the right is hereby conferred and extended upon any
property owner owning property in any district, where such property owner may
be affected or invaded, by a violation of the terms of this section, to bring
suit in such court or courts having jurisdiction thereof and obtain such
remedies as may be available by law and equity in the protection of the rights
of such property owners.
(Code 2014, § 46-219; Ord. No. 629, § 01.08.004, 12-1-2006; Ord. No. 816, §§ 1,
2, 1-14-2019)
Sec. 46-220. Height regulations.
The maximum allowable height in the Manufactured Home Residential District (MH)
is 35 feet.
(Code 2014, § 46-220; Ord. No. 629, § 01.08.005, 12-1-2006)
Sec. 46-221. Setback regulations.
The setback regulations for the Manufactured Home Residential District (MH) are
follows:
      (1)   Front setback shall have a minimum of 25 feet.
      (2)   Side setback shall have a minimum of five feet.
      (3)   Side setback adjacent to a street shall have a minimum of 15 feet.
      (4)   Rear setback shall have a minimum of ten feet.
(Code 2014, § 46-221; Ord. No. 629, § 01.08.006, 12-1-2006)
Sec. 46-222. Lot regulations.
The lot regulations for the Manufactured Home Residential District (MH) are as
follows:
      (1)   The minimum lot size shall be 5,000 square feet.
      (2)   The minimum lot width shall be 50 feet.
      (3)   The minimum lot depth shall be 100 feet.
      (4)   All corner lots shall consist of 1,000 square feet more than the
minimum interior lot size.
(Code 2014, § 46-222; Ord. No. 629, § 01.08.007, 12-1-2006)
Sec. 46-223. Off-street parking regulations.
The off-street parking regulations for the Manufactured Home Residential
District (MH) are as provided in article XIX of this chapter.
(Code 2014, § 46-223; Ord. No. 629, § 01.08.008, 12-1-2006)
Sec. 46-224. Building regulations for nonresidential uses.
The building regulations for nonresidential uses in the Manufactured Home
Residential District (MH) are as follows:
      (1)   Temporary buildings and buildings for agricultural purposes shall
be a maximum size of 500 square feet.
      (2)   Nonresidential principal buildings shall be a minimum size of 1,000
square feet.
      (3)   Nonresidential uses in this district, with the exception of parks,
shall be located on a corner lot with driveway access directly onto a collector
or arterial street.
      (4)   No residential dwelling shall be constructed or moved into the
district which contains less than 1,000 square feet within the living area
except for manufactured homes.
(Code 2014, § 46-224; Ord. No. 629, § 01.08.009, 12-1-2006; Ord. No. 753, 1, 1-
12-2015)
Sec. 46-225. Regulations specific to this district.
The regulations specific to this Manufactured Home Residential District (MH)
are as follows:
      (1)   All manufactured homes shall be securely tied down, blocked and
completely skirted prior to occupancy as provided in the installation standards
adopted pursuant to V.T.C.A., Occupation Code §§ 1201.251 and 1201.252.
      (2)   All manufactured homes in the city shall comply with all
regulations of the state.
      (3)   Domestic animals over the age of six months shall be limited to
three per species and a total of six per household.
      (4)   Open storage is prohibited, (except for materials for the
resident's personal use or consumption i.e., firewood, gardening materials,
etc.).
      (5)   No temporary structures, such as recreational vehicles, travel
trailers, construction trailers, or mobile homes may be used for on-site
dwelling purposes.
      (6)   Duplex, patio home, and townhouse dwellings permitted conditionally
in this district shall conform to standards as specified in article XXIV of
this chapter.
(Code 2014, § 46-225; Ord. No. 629, § 01.08.010, 12-1-2006; Ord. No. 743, § 1,
4-14-2014; Ord. No. 740, § 1, 9-9-2014)
State law reference(s)—Uniform standards for the construction or installation
of manufactured homes, V.T.C.A., Occupation Code § 1201.2521 local government
powers regarding standards, V.T.C.A., Occupation Code § 1201.252.
Sec. 46-226. Landscaping regulations.
The applicable landscaping regulations for the Manufactured Home Residential
District (MH) are as provided in article XX of this chapter.
(Code 2014, § 46-226; Ord. No. 629, § 01.08.011, 12-1-2006)
Sec. 46-227. Sign regulations.
The applicable sign regulations for the Manufactured Home Residential District
(MH) are as provided in sections
34-116 and
34-117.
Secs. 46-228—46-245. Reserved.
ARTICLE IX. MULTIPLE-FAMILY RESIDENTIAL DISTRICT (MF)
Note(s)—H.B. 2439 of the 86th legislative session has removed a municipalities
ability to require that certain building materials are used in construction.
Sec. 46-246. Purpose.
The Multiple-Family Residential District (MF) is a residential district
intended to provide the highest residential density of a maximum of 25 dwelling
units per acre. The principal permitted land uses will include low-rise
multiple-family dwellings, garden apartments, condominiums, duplexes, and
townhouses. Recreational, religious, health and educational uses normally
located to service residential areas are also permitted in this district. This
district should be located adjacent to an arterial or collector, as shown on
the mayor thoroughfare plan, and serve as a buffer between retail/commercial
development or heavy automobile traffic, and medium or low density residential
development.
(Code 2014, § 46-246; Ord. No. 629, § 01.09.001, 12-1-2006)
Sec. 46-247. Permitted uses.
Any use permitted in the Urban Single-Family Residential District (SF-2) is
permitted in the Multiple-Family Residential District (MF), with the addition
of:
      (1)   Boardinghouse (lodginghouse).
      (2)   Child care, Class B.
      (3)   Common open space, community center, recreational building, and
other facilities or amenities, provided they are intended for use by the
residents of the multifamily apartment complex.
      (4)   Duplex.
      (5)   Essential municipal uses.
      (6)   Laundromat (self-service washateria).
      (7)   Multiple-family dwelling (apartment building, triplex, fourplex),
greater than two dwelling units per structure.
      (8)   Nursing home (retirement home).
      (9)   Townhouse.
(Code 2014, § 46-247; Ord. No. 629, § 01.09.002, 12-1-2006)
Sec. 46-248. Conditional uses.
Any use permitted in the Urban Single-Family Residential District (SF-2) is
permitted in the Multiple-Family Residential District (MF), with the addition
of:
      (1)   Dormitory.
      (2)   Fitness center.
      (3)   Fraternity and sorority house.
      (4)   Funeral home/mortuary.
      (5)   Manufactured housing land lease community.
      (6)   Municipal services support facility.
      (7)   Non-paid parking for nonresidential use.
      (8)   Police station.
(Code 2014, § 46-248; Ord. No. 629, § 01.09.003, 12-1-2006)
Sec. 46-249. Density regulations.
The density regulations of the Multiple-Family Residential District (MF) are as
follows:
      (1)   A maximum of 25 units is allowed per gross acre.
      (2)   One single-family detached dwelling unit or one nonresidential
principal building is allowed per lot.
(Code 2014, § 46-249; Ord. No. 629, § 01.09.004, 12-1-2006)
Sec. 46-250. Height regulations.
The height regulations of the Multiple-Family Residential District (MF) are as
follows:
      (1)   The maximum allowable height is 35 feet.
      (2)   Structures over 35 feet in height are permitted with the additional
setback of one foot for each two feet in height over 35 feet.
(Code 2014, § 46-250; Ord. No. 629, § 01.09.005, 12-1-2006)
Sec. 46-251. Setback regulations.
The setback regulations of the Multiple-Family Residential District (MF) are as
follows:
      (1)   Front setback shall have a minimum of 25 feet.
      (2)   Side setback shall have a minimum of ten feet.
      (3)   Side setback adjacent to a street shall have a minimum of 15 feet.
      (4)   Rear setback shall have a minimum of 25 feet.
(Code 2014, § 46-251; Ord. No. 629, § 01.09.006, 12-1-2006)
Sec. 46-252. Lot regulations.
The lot regulations of the Multiple-Family Residential District (MF) are as
follows:
      (1)   The minimum lot size shall be 12,000 square feet.
      (2)   The minimum lot width shall be 100 feet.
      (3)   The minimum lot depth shall be 150 feet.
(Code 2014, § 46-252; Ord. No. 629, § 01.09.007, 12-1-2006)
Sec. 46-253. Off-street parking regulations.
The off-street parking regulations for the Multiple-Family Residential District
(MF) are as provided in article XIX of this chapter.
(Code 2014, § 46-253; Ord. No. 629, § 01.09.008, 12-1-2006)
Sec. 46-254. Building regulations.
The building regulations of the Multiple-Family Residential District (MF) are
as follows:
      (1)   Apartments shall contain a minimum square footage of living area as
follows:
 
Studio unit      450 square feet of living area
One bedroom unit 650 square feet of living area
Two bedroom unit 730 square feet of living area
Each additional bedroom requires a maximum of 80 square feet of living area.
 
      (2)   Triplex and fourplex buildings shall contain a minimum of 900
square feet of living area per unit.
      (3)   The outside wall area of all buildings constructed shall include a
minimum of 25 percent masonry consisting of stucco, brick, ledge stone, field
stone or native types of stone veneer except for temporary uses relating to
construction and to public utilities.
      (4)   Nonresidential principal buildings shall be a minimum size of 1,500
square feet.
      (5)   Temporary buildings shall not exceed 1,000 square feet.
(Code 2014, § 46-254; Ord. No. 629, § 01.09.009, 12-1-2006)
Sec. 46-255. Regulations specific to this district.
The regulations specific to this Multiple-Family Residential District (MF) are
as follows:
      (1)   Domestic animals over the age of six months shall be limited to two
per species and a total of four per household.
      (2)   Detached dwelling units constructed in this district shall conform
to Large Single-Family Residential District (SF-1) standards.
      (3)   No temporary structures, such as travel trailers, recreational
vehicles, construction trailers, or mobile homes may be used for on-site
dwelling purposes.
      (4)   Open storage is prohibited.
      (5)   A paved walkway shall connect the front door of each multifamily
ground floor unit to a parking area.
      (6)   Refer to article XXIV of this chapter for patio home, townhouse,
and duplex development criteria.
(Code 2014, § 46-255; Ord. No. 629, § 01.09.010, 12-1-2006)
Sec. 46-256. Landscaping regulations.
The applicable landscaping regulations for the Multiple-Family Residential
District (MF) are as provided in article XX of this chapter.
Sec. 46-257. Sign regulations.
The applicable sign regulations for the Multiple-Family Residential District
(MF) are as provided in sections
34-116 and
34-117.
Secs. 46-258—46-273. Reserved.
ARTICLE X. OFFICE DISTRICT (O)
Note(s)—H.B. 2439 of the 86th legislative session has removed a municipalities
ability to require that certain building materials are used in construction.
Sec. 46-274. Purpose.
The Office District (O) is established to create a flexible district for low-
intensity office and professional uses generally in smaller buildings. Some
light-intensity retail uses are also permitted. Permitted uses should be
compatible with adjacent residential areas by limiting heights to two stories
and utilizing buffers and landscape materials. Adaptive reuse of existing
structures is encouraged. Sites zoned office may be built over two stories,
subject to certain restrictions, if located such that they will not adversely
impact any properties zoned or used for a detached dwelling use. Buildings and
structures in this district should strive for architectural compatibility.
(Code 2014, § 46-274; Ord. No. 629, § 01.10.001, 12-1-2006)
Sec. 46-275. Permitted uses.
The permitted uses for the Office District (O) are as follows:
      (1)   Accessory or incidental uses to the main use (snack or food bars,
automatic teller machines, etc.).
      (2)   Accessory structure (refer to section
46-734).
      (3)   Banks, savings and loans or credit union offices.
      (4)   Child care, Class B.
      (5)   Child care, Class C.
      (6)   Essential municipal uses.
      (7)   Recreational/community center.
      (8)   Fraternal/service organization.
      (9)   General office use (professional, administrative).
      (10)   Government (federal or state) owned structures, facilities, or
uses.
      (11)   Hospital.
      (12)   Kiosk.
      (13)   Laboratory (scientific, research, medical, optical).
      (14)   Medical facilities or clinics.
      (15)   Museum/art gallery.
      (16)   Personal service shop or custom personal services.
      (17)   Pharmacies.
      (18)   Photography studio.
      (19)   Police station.
      (20)   Private utility office (no repair or outside storage).
      (21)   Radio or television broadcasting studio (without tower).
      (22)   Nursing home (retirement home).
      (23)   School.
      (24)   Temporary structures for uses incidental to construction work on
the premises, which said buildings shall be removed upon the completion or
abandonment of construction work.
      (25)   Veterinary services (no outdoor pens or runs).
(Code 2014, § 46-275; Ord. No. 629, § 01.10.002, 12-1-2006)
Sec. 46-276. Conditional uses.
The conditional uses of the Office District (O) are as follows:
      (1)   College or university.
      (2)   Duplex.
      (3)   Fitness center.
      (4)   Funeral home/mortuary.
      (5)   Heliport or helistop.
      (6)   Multifamily dwelling.
      (7)   Municipal services support facility.
      (8)   Patio home (zero lot line dwelling).
      (9)   Place of worship.
      (10)   Restaurant or cafeteria.
      (11)   Reception hall.
      (12)   Studio.
      (13)   Townhouse.
(Code 2014, § 46-276; Ord. No. 629, § 01.10.003, 12-1-2006)
Sec. 46-277. Height regulations.
The height regulations of the Office District (O) are as follows:
      (1)   The maximum allowable height is 35 feet.
      (2)   Structures over 35 feet in height are permitted with the additional
setback of one foot for each two feet in height over 35 feet.
(Code 2014, § 46-277; Ord. No. 629, § 01.10.004, 12-1-2006)
Sec. 46-278. Setback regulations.
The setback regulations of the Office District (O) are as follows:
      (1)   Front setback shall have a minimum of 25 feet.
      (2)   Side setback shall have a minimum of ten feet.
      (3)   Side setback adjacent to a street shall have a minimum of 15 feet.
      (4)   Rear setback shall have a minimum of ten feet.
(Code 2014, § 46-278; Ord. No. 629, § 01.10.005, 12-1-2006)
Sec. 46-279. Lot regulations.
The lot regulations of the Office District (O) are as follows:
      (1)   The minimum lot size shall be 8,000 square feet.
      (2)   The minimum lot width shall be 70 feet.
      (3)   The minimum lot depth shall be 100 feet.
(Code 2014, § 46-279; Ord. No. 629, § 01.10.006, 12-1-2006)
Sec. 46-280. Off-street parking regulations.
See article XIX of this chapter for off-street parking regulations.
(Code 2014, § 46-280; Ord. No. 629, § 01.10.007, 12-1-2006)
Sec. 46-281. Building regulations.
The building regulations for the Office District (O) are as follows:
      (1)   No building shall contain a single continuous exterior wall that
exceeds 100 feet in length. All exterior walls shall be finished with at least
50 percent masonry, and consist of one or a combination of the following
materials: brick, native types of stone, and/or cast stone. Alternative
materials may be approved by the city manager if the alternative materials meet
or exceed the standards of the materials listed in this subsection.
      (2)   Awnings and canopies may be made of sheet metal or canvas membrane.
Plastic or vinyl awnings are not permitted.
      (3)   All ground-floor building faces shall utilize the similar
architectural treatments on all sides visible from the street or adjacent
residences.
      (4)   Pitched roofs shall be required on all buildings in this district.
The slope of the pitch shall be a minimum ratio of 4:13.
      (5)   Glazed openings shall account for at least 25 percent of the
overall wall surface along walls visible from a lot line. Glazing shall not
exceed 80 percent. Mirrored glass is not permitted.
(Code 2014, § 46-281; Ord. No. 629, § 01.10.008, 12-1-2006)
Sec. 46-282. Regulations specific to the district.
The regulations specific to the Office District (O) are as follows:
      (1)   Displays and merchandise shall be fully contained and displayed
within the building.
      (2)   A permanent structure with indoor facilities that include offices,
restroom facilities, etc. to comply with all building code regulations is
required.
      (3)   No drive-through facilities or walk-up facilities shall be
permitted.
      (4)   Open storage is prohibited.
      (5)   Establishments selling alcoholic beverages shall not be located
within:
         a.   300 feet of a public school, place of worship, or a public
hospital.
         b.   1,000 feet of a public school, if the city council receives a
request from the board of trustees of a school district under V.T.C.A.,
Education Code § 38.007; or
         c.   1,000 feet of a private school if the city council receives a
request from the governing body of the private school.
      (6)   No temporary structures, such as recreational vehicles, travel
trailers, construction trailers, or mobile homes may be used for on-site
dwelling purposes.
      (7)   Duplex, townhouse, and patio home dwellings permitted conditionally
in this district shall conform to standards as specified in article XXIV of
this chapter.
      (8)   Wireless telecommunications facilities shall be allowed only as
provided for in article XXV of this chapter.
      (9)   No use or operation, including those permitted by right, shall
create a dangerous, injurious, noxious, or reasonably objectionable condition
so as to adversely affect areas outside of the district.
(Code 2014, § 46-282; Ord. No. 629, § 01.10.009, 12-1-2006)
Sec. 46-283. Landscaping regulations.
The applicable landscaping regulations for the Office District (O) are as
provided in in article XX of this chapter.
(Code 2014, § 46-283; Ord. No. 629, § 01.10.010, 12-1-2006)
Sec. 46-284. Sign regulations.
The sign regulations for the Office District (O) are as provided in sections
34-116 and 34-117.
(Code 2014, § 46-284; Ord. No. 813, § 1, 10-9-2018)
Secs. 46-285—46-301. Reserved.
ARTICLE XI. RETAIL DISTRICT (R)
Note(s)—H.B. 2439 of the 86th legislative session has removed a municipalities
ability to require that certain building materials are used in construction.
Sec. 46-302. Purpose.
The Retail District (R) is established to provide locations for various types
of general retail trade, business and service uses, and to provide for a smooth
transition from the neighborhood to a more intensive land use which will
preserve the integrity and sustainability of the residential areas within the
neighborhood. The district allows shopping areas or uses which are generally
compatible near or adjacent to, but not usually directly in, residential
neighborhoods, allowing access to services by pedestrians and bicycles. These
shopping areas should utilize established landscape and buffering regulations.
(Code 2014, § 46-302; Ord. No. 629, § 01.11.001, 12-1-2006)
Sec. 46-303. Permitted uses.
Any use permitted in the Office District (O) will be permitted in the Retail
District (R), with the addition of:
      (1)   Bed and breakfast;
      (2)   Boardinghouse (lodginghouse);
      (3)   Business or trade school;
      (4)   College or university;
      (5)   Commercial amusement (indoor);
      (6)   Dance studio;
      (7)   Fitness center;
      (8)   Funeral home/mortuary;
      (9)   Grocery store;
      (10)   Parking lots or garages, commercial;
      (11)   Restaurant;
      (12)   Retail shops and service;
      (13)   Software sales, computer hardware sales, software development;
      (14)   Studio;
      (15)   Theater, indoor.
(Code 2014, § 46-303; Ord. No. 629, § 01.11.002, 12-1-2006)
Sec. 46-304. Conditional uses.
Any use conditionally permitted in the Office District (O) will be
conditionally permitted in the Retail District (R), with the addition of:
      (1)   Automobile parts and accessories sales.
      (2)   Automobile service station with minor automobile repair, under the
definitions provided in section
46-1112.
      (3)   Charitable uses.
      (4)   Convenience stores.
      (5)   Nurseries (greenhouses).
      (6)   Laundromats (self-service washaterias).
      (7)   Pitch and putt, miniature golf, nine-hole golf courses, not
including a driving ranges.
      (8)   Places of worship.
      (9)   Veterinarian or animal hospitals (no outdoor kennels).
      (10)   Single-family residential (SF-2).
(Code 2014, § 46-304; Ord. No. 629, § 01.11.003, 12-1-2006; Ord. No. 678, § 1,
8-9-2010; Ord. No. 704, § 01.11.003, 8-13-2012)

The height regulations for the Retail District (R) are as follows:

      (2)   Structures over 35 feet in height are permitted with the additional
setback of one foot for each two feet in height over 35 feet.
(Code 2014, § 46-305; Ord. No. 629, § 01.11.004, 12-1-2006)

The lot regulations of the Retail District (R) are as follows:

ARTICLE XII. GENERAL BUSINESS DISTRICT (GB)
Note(s)—H.B. 2439 of the 86th legislative session has removed a municipalities
ability to require that certain building materials are used in construction.
Sec. 46-343. Purpose.
The General Business District (GB) is to provide for business activities that
are typically large in scale and are designed to serve the community and the
region without negatively impacting the residents of the single-family
neighborhoods by locating these uses at activity nodes located at the
intersection of arterial roadways, or with direct access to major arterial
roadways. The GB district allows for more intensive retail, office, and
commercial land uses under architectural standards that result in consumer-
oriented, quality development that promotes economic development and regional
enterprise in a positive and sustainable manner for the city.
(Code 2014, § 46-343; Ord. No. 629, § 01.12.001, 12-1-2006)
Sec. 46-344. Permitted uses.
Any use permitted in the Retail District (R) are permitted in the General
Business District (GB), with the addition of:
   (1)   Automobile parts and accessories sales;
   (2)   Automobile repair/sales/rental;
   (3)   Convenience store;
   (4)   Laundromat (self-service washateria);
   (5)   Motel or hotel;
   (6)   Nursery (greenhouse);
   (7)   Pawnshop that has been licensed to transact business by the state
consumer credit commissioner under V.T.C.A., Finance Code ch. 371;
   (8)   Reception hall; and
   (9)   Veterinarian or animal hospital (no outdoor kennels).
(Code 2014, § 46-344; Ord. No. 629, § 01.12.002, 12-1-2006; Ord. No. 794, §
01.12.002, 6-12-2017)
Sec. 46-345. Conditional uses.
Any use conditionally permitted in the Retail District (R) will be

      (1)   Automobile repair/sales/rental.
      (2)   Boat repair/sales/rental.
      (3)   Commercial amusement (outdoor).
      (4)   Gaming establishments.
      (5)   Heating or air conditioning sales or service.
      (6)   Heliport or helistop.

      (12)   Nightclub or tavern (less than or equal to 5,000 square feet).
      (13)   Office, showroom/warehouse.
      (14)   Theater, outdoor.
      (15)   Printing company.
      (16)   Recycling collection point.
      (17)   Tattoo/piercing studio.
      (18)   Trade shop or office.
      (19)   Trailer rental.
      (20)   Truck rental.
(Code 2014, § 46-345; Ord. No. 629, § 01.12.003, 12-1-2006)

The height regulations for the General Business District (GB) are as follows:
      (1)   The maximum allowable height is 35 feet.
      (2)   Structures over 35 feet in height are permitted with the additional
setback of one foot for each two feet in height over 35 feet.
(Code 2014, § 46-346; Ord. No. 629, § 01.12.004, 12-1-2006)
Sec. 46-347. Setback regulations.
